column1: When Angel Amankwaah traveled from Denver to North Carolina Central University for incoming student orientation this summer
column2: she decided she had made the right choice.

column1: She had fun learning the chants that fans perform at football games. But she also saw that “there are students who look like me
column2: and professors who look like me” at the historically Black university
column3: said Amankwaah
column5: who is Black. “I knew that I was in a safe space.”

column1: This has in the last two years become an important consideration for college-bound students from all backgrounds and beliefs. With so much attention focused on these issues
column2: USA TODAY and The Hechinger Report present the first-of-its-kind College Welcome Guide showing state laws and institutional policies that affect college and university students
column3: from bans on diversity
column4: equity and inclusion initiatives and “critical race theory” to rules about guns on campus and whether student IDs are accepted as proof of residency for voting purposes.

column1: The digital tables also list
column2: for every four-year institution in the country
column3: such things as racial and gender diversity among students and faculty
column4: the number of student veterans enrolled
column5: the incidence of on-campus race-motivated hate crimes
column6: free-speech rankings and if the university or college serves many students from rural places.

column1: College Welcome Guide: Test it yourself.These tools new offer a new on campus life
Students have long picked schools based on their academic reputations and social life. But with campuses in the crosshairs of the culture wars
column2: many students are now also taking stock of attacks on diversity
column3: course content and speech and speakers from both ends of the political spectrum. They’re monitoring hate crimes
column4: anti-LGBTQ+ legislation
column5: state abortion laws and whether students like them ‒ Black
column6: rural
column7: military veterans
column8: LGBTQ+ or from other backgrounds ‒ are represented and supported on campus.

column1: “There’s no question that what’s happening at the state level is directly affecting these students
column2: ” said Alyse Levine
column3: founder and CEO of Premium Prep
column4: a private college admissions consulting firm in Chapel Hill
column5: North Carolina. When they look at colleges in various states now
column6: she said
column7: “There are students who are asking
column8: ‘Am I really wanted here?’”

column1: For some students on both sides of the political divide
column2: the answer is no. In the chaotic new world of American colleges and universities
column3: many say they feel unwelcome at certain schools
column4: while others are prepared to shut down speakers and report faculty with whose opinions they disagree.

column1: It’s too early to know how much this trend will affect where and whether prospective students end up going to college since publicly available enrollment data lags real time. But there are early clues that it’s having a significant impact.
One in 4 prospective students has already ruled out a college or university for consideration because of the political climate in its state
column2: according to a survey by the higher education consulting firm Art & Science Group.

column1: Among students who describe themselves as liberal
column2: the most common reason to rule out colleges and universities in a particular state
column3: that survey found
column4: is because it’s “too Republican” or has what they consider lax gun regulations
column5: anti-LGBTQ+ legislation
column6: restrictive abortion laws and a lack of concern about racism. Students who describe themselves as conservative are rejecting states they believe to be “too Democrat” and that have liberal abortion and gay rights laws.

column1: Sixty percent of prospective students of all backgrounds say new state restrictions on abortion would at least somewhat influence where they choose to go to college
column2: a separate poll by Gallup and the Lumina Foundation found. Of these
column3: 8 in 10 say they would prefer to go to a state with greater access to reproductive health services. (Lumina is among the funders of The Hechinger Report
column4: which produced this story.)

column1: “We have many young women who will not look at certain states
column2: ” said Levine. One of her own clients backed out of going to a university in St. Louis after Missouri banned almost all abortions following the Supreme Court’s Dobbs decision
column3: she said.

column1: Institutions in Alabama
column2: Florida
column3: Louisiana and Texas are the most likely to be knocked off the lists of liberal students
column4: according to the Art & Science Group survey. They’re generally most likely to steer clear of the South and Midwest
column5: while conservative students avoid California and New York.

column1: One in 8 high school students in Florida say they won’t go to a public university in their own state because of its education policies
column2: a separate poll
column3: by the college ranking and information website Intelligent.com
column4: found.

column1: With 494 anti-LGBTQ+ laws proposed or adopted this year
column2: according to the American Civil Liberties Union
column3: prospective students who are LGBTQ+ and have experienced significant harassment because of it are nearly twice as likely to say they don't plan to go to college at all compared with students who experienced lower levels of harassment
column4: according to a survey by GLSEN
column5: formerly the Gay
column6: Lesbian and Straight Education Network.

column1: “You are attacking kids who are already vulnerable
column2: ” said Javier Gomez
column3: an LGBTQ+ student in his first year at Miami Dade College. “And it’s not just queer students. So many young people are fed up.”

column1: It’s not yet evident whether the new laws are affecting where LGBTQ+ young people are choosing to go to college
column2: said Casey Pick
column3: director of law and policy at The Trevor Project
column4: which supports LGBTQ+ young people in crisis. But LGBTQ+ adults are moving away from states passing anti-LGBTQ+ laws
column5: she said. And “if adult employees are taking this into account when they decide where they want to live
column6: you can bet that college students are making the same decisions.”

column1: Since DeSantis takeover
column2: surge in dropouts at New College of Florida

column1: Meanwhile
column2: in an era of pushback against diversity
column3: equity and inclusion policies in many states
column4: and against affirmative action in college admissions nationwide
column5: Amankwaah is one of a growing number of Black students choosing what they see as the relative security of an HBCU. Enrollment at HBCUs increased by around 3% in 2021
column6: the last year for which the figure is available
column7: while the number of students at other universities and colleges fell.

column1: “The real attack here is on the feeling of belonging
column2: ” said Jeremy Young
column3: who directs the Freedom to Learn program at PEN America
column4: which tracks laws that restrict college and university diversity efforts and teaching about race. “What it really does is hoist a flag to say to the most marginalized students
column5: ‘We don’t want you here.’”

column1: More than 40% of university and college administrators say the Supreme Court ruling curbing the use of affirmative action in admissions will affect diversity on their campuses
column2: a Princeton Review poll found as the school year was beginning.

column1: College students of all races and political persuasions report feeling uncomfortable on campuses that have become political battlegrounds. Those on the left are bristling at new laws blocking programs in diversity
column2: equity and inclusion and the teaching of certain perspectives about race; on the right
column3: at conservative speakers being shouted down or canceled
column4: unpopular comments being called out in class and what they see as an embrace of values different from what they learned at home.

column1: More than 1 in 10 students at four-year universities now say they feel as if they downright don’t belong on their campus
column2: and another 2 in 10 neither agree nor strongly agree that they belong
column3: another Lumina and Gallup survey found. It found that those who answer in these ways are more likely to frequently experience stress and more likely to drop out.

column1: Military veterans who use their GI Bill benefits to return to school say one of their most significant barriers is a feeling that they won’t be welcome
column2: a survey by the D’Aniello Institute for Veterans and Military Families at Syracuse University found. Nearly two-thirds say that faculty and administrators don’t understand the challenges they face
column3: and 70% say the same thing about their non-veteran classmates.

column1: Colleges should be “safe and affirming spaces
column2: ” said Pick
column3: of the Trevor Project ‒ not places of isolation and alienation.

column1: Yet a significant number of students say they don’t feel comfortable sharing their views in class
column2: according to another survey
column3: conducted by College Pulse for the right-leaning Sheila and Robert Challey Institute for Global Innovation and Growth at North Dakota State University. Of those
column4: 72% say they worry their opinions would be considered unacceptable by classmates and 45%
column5: by their professors. Conservative students are less likely than their liberal classmates to believe that all points of view are welcome and less willing to share theirs.

column1: “Is that really an intellectually diverse environment?” asked Sean Stevens
column2: director of polling and analytics at the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression
column3: or FIRE
column4: which has launched a campus free-speech ranking based on students’ perceptions of comfort expressing ideas
column5: tolerance for speakers and other measures.

column1: “Anecdotally and from personal experience
column2: there’s certainly a pocket of students who are weighing these factors in terms of where to go to college
column3: ” Stevens said.

column1: Eighty-one percent of liberal students and 53% of conservative ones say they support reporting faculty who make comments that they find offensive
column2: the same survey found. It used sample comments such as
column3: “There is no evidence of anti-Black bias in police shootings
column4: ” “Requiring vaccination for COVID is an assault on individual freedom” and “Biological sex is a scientific fact.”

column1: A professor at Texas A&M University became the subject of an investigation when a student accused her of criticizing the state’s lieutenant governor during a lecture
column2: though she was ultimately exonerated. An anthropology lecturer at the University of Chicago who taught an undergraduate course called “The Problem of Whiteness” said she was deluged with hateful messages when a conservative student posted her photo and email address on social media.

column1: More than half of all freshmen say that colleges have the right to ban extreme speakers
column2: according to an annual survey by an institute at the University of California
column3: Los Angeles; the College Pulse poll says that sentiment is held by twice the proportion of liberal students as conservative ones.

column1: A group of Stanford students in March disrupted an on-campus speech by a federal judge whose judicial record they said was anti-LGBTQ+. When he asked for an administrator to intervene
column2: an associate dean for diversity
column3: equity and inclusion confronted him and asked: “Is it worth the pain that this causes and the division that this causes?” The associate dean was put on leave and later resigned.

column1: “Today it is a sad fact that the greatest threat to free speech comes from within the academy
column2: ” pronounced the right-leaning American Council of Trustees and Alumni
column3: which is pushing colleges to sign on to its Campus Freedom Initiative that encourages teaching students about free expression during freshman orientation and disciplining people who disrupt speakers or events
column4: among other measures.

column1: “I have to imagine that universities that have a bad track record on freedom of expression or academic freedom
column2: that it will affect their reputations
column3: ” said Steven Maguire
column4: the organization’s campus freedom fellow. “I do hear people saying things like
column5: ‘I’m worried about what kind of a college or university I can send my kids to and whether they’ll be free to be themselves and to express themselves.’”

column1: Some colleges are now actively recruiting students on the basis of these kinds of concerns. Colorado College in September created a program to ease the process for students who want to transfer away from institutions in states that have banned diversity
column2: equity and inclusion initiatives; Hampshire College in Massachusetts has offered admission to any student from New College in Florida
column3: subject of what critics have described as a conservative takeover. Thirty-five have so far accepted the invitation.

column1: Though many conservative critics of colleges and universities say faculty are indoctrinating students with liberal opinions
column2: incoming freshmen tend to hold left-leaning views before they ever set foot in a classroom
column3: according to that UCLA survey.

column1: Fewer than 1 in 5 consider themselves conservative. Three-quarters say abortion should be legal and favor stricter gun control laws
column2: 68% say wealthy people should pay more taxes than they do now and 86% that climate change should be a federal priority and that there should be a clear path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants.

column1: Prospective students say they are watching as new laws are passed and controversies erupt on campuses and actively looking into not just the quality of food and available majors at the colleges they might attend
column2: but state politics.

column1: “Once I decided I was going to North Carolina Central
column2: I looked up whether North Carolina was a red state or a blue state
column3: ” Amankwaah said. (North Carolina has a Democrat as governor but Republicans control both chambers of the legislature and hold a veto-proof supermajority in the state Senate.

column1: Florida’s anti-LGBTQ+ laws prompted Javier Gomez to leave his native state and move to New York to go to fashion school. But then he came back
column2: transferring to Miami Dade.

column1: “People ask me
column2: ‘Why the hell are you back in Florida?’” said Gomez. “The reason I came back was that there was this innate calling in me that you have to stick around and fight for the queer and trans kids here. It’s overwhelming at times. It can be very mentally depleting. But I wanted to stay and continue the fight and build community against hatred.”

column1: Thousands of Israelis and Palestinians have been killed and Palestinians have been ordered to evacuate from the northern Gaza Strip ahead of Israel's impending ground invasion
column2: leading to a humanitarian crisis that has brought protests from the United Nations and around the world.

column1: The U.N. said about 1 million Gaza residents have been displaced in just a week
column2: about half of them finding refuge in U.N. schools and other facilities where water supplies are diminishing. The war has claimed more than 4
column3: 000 lives since Hamas launched an unprecedented surprise attack Oct. 7.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the World Health Organization pleaded with Israel on Sunday to immediately reverse evacuation orders for hospitals in northern Gaza
column3: saying the deadlines are impossible to meet and risk additional loss of life. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warned that attacks on health care facilities are already causing deaths and injuries.

column1: The health situation in north Gaza is dire, Tedros wrote on social media. "Evacuation orders by Israel to hospitals are practically impossible to implement and are a death sentence for the sick and injured."
Here are several organizations that are providing aid to people caught in the conflict.
How to cope:The videos out of Israel
column2: Gaza are graphic
column3: but some can't look away

column1: The Alliance for Middle East Peace (ALLMEP) is a coalition of more than 170 nongovernmental organizations that includes tens of thousands of Palestinians and Israelis who share the goal of building peace between the two communities.

Our members are speaking loudly and clearly about the values that unite our community: Opposition to this horrific violence, and a commitment to Israeli/Palestinian partnership on the path to ending it, and achieving peace and equality, the agency said in a statement.

The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) is a humanitarian organization that aims to protect and aid victims of conflicts. The ICRC has been in Israel and the occupied territories since 1967. The organization is asking for donations to improve access to essential services like water and to support livelihood projects.
Doctors Without Borders is a nongovernmental organization that describes itself as an "independent
column2: impartial and neutral" charity that provides humanitarian aid to people affected by conflict
column3: disease outbreaks and natural and human-made disasters.

column1: The agency is seeking donations to continue to provide medical care in the area. The agency has reported overcrowding in hospitals
column2: a lack of medical supplies
column3: and dangerous working conditions as it tries to support the thousands injured by the fighting.

column1: UNRWA has designated shelters to host the estimated 127
column2: 000 people displaced in Gaza. The agency is seeking donations to support its work.

column1: The Jewish Agency for Israel North American Council
column2: an American charity organization
column3: is accepting donations to help victims of terrorism.

column1: Save the Children issued an emergency alert in response to the conflict
column2: noting that escalating violence has left 1.2 million children in need of humanitarian aid. The agency is accepting donations.

column1: National and international organizations that aid victims in the conflict include the Palestine Children's Relief Fund (PCRF)
column2: which works to provide lifesaving medical relief and humanitarian aid.

column1: Founded by former President Jimmy Carter and his wife
column2: Rosalynn Carter
column3: in partnership with Emory University
column4: The Carter Center is a humanitarian aid organization that has been promoting peace and a viable two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict for decades.

column1: A shaken mother on Tuesday called for the release of her daughter after Hamas released a video showing the French-Israeli hostage having her armed bandaged – the first sign of life from any of the hostages seized by Hamas in the first tumultuous hours of the war.
Keren Schem
column2: speaking at a news conference
column3: said she had not known if her 21-year-old daughter
column4: Mia
column5: was dead or alive until seeing the video Monday. Mia Schem was taken from a party at Kibbutz Reim where more than 260 revelers were killed and dozens more seized as part of the killing rampage by Hamas militants that rocked Israel and the world 10 days ago.

column1: The video was the first depicting any of the roughly 200 hostages Israel says were taken during the attack.
I’m begging the world to bring my baby back home, Keren Schem said. “This is a crime against humanity and we should all gather and stop this terror and bring everybody back home."
Israeli and French officials condemned the release of the video. John Kirby
column2: the spokesperson for the White House National Security Council
column3: expressed outrage Tuesday and called for immediate release of all hostages.

column1: It’s despicable, deplorable that they would take these hostages and then advertise how well they’re treating them when they’re the ones who hurt them in the first place, Kirby said on NBC’s “Today” show.

column1: Emotions have been running high far beyond the Middle East in the 10 days the war has raged. Maybe to alleviate guilt

Hamas – an acronym for Harakat al-Muqawama al-Islamiya
column2: or the Islamic resistance movement – was founded in 1987 by activists connected to the Muslim Brotherhood during the first Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of Gaza and the West Bank. The State Department designated Hamas a terrorist group in 1997
column3: and several other nations also consider Hamas a terrorist organization.

column2: Hamas won parliamentary elections
column3: and in 2007 the group violently seized control of Gaza from the Palestinian Authority
column4: which was controlled by the rival Fatah movement that still governs the West Bank. There have been no elections since. The group calls for establishment of an Islamic Palestinian state that would replace the current state of Israel and believes in the use of violence to carry out the destruction of Israel.

column1: Hamas receives financial

column4: the U.S. and other nations have said there is no evidence that Iran was directly involved in Hamas’ attack.

WASHINGTON — The speaker of the House is second in line to the presidency
column2: and the United States has gone two weeks without the crucial leader in the lower chamber.

column1: That could end on Tuesday as House lawmakers hold a vote at noon for a new speaker. While Rep. Patrick McHenry
column2: R-N.C.
column3: has served as speaker pro tempore
column4: it's not a role that has the same powers as the official leader.

column1: House Republicans nominated the chair of the House Judiciary Committee
column2: Rep. Jim Jordan
column3: R-Ohio
column4: to the speakership last week. But Jordan's chances of earning 217 votes – the magic number needed to become speaker – are unclear. Democrats aren't expected to lend their GOP colleagues any support
column5: so Republicans will have to figure out a way to coalesce around their next speaker.

column1: Follow along here for live updates as House Republicans attempt to settle their differences and select a new speaker for the American people.

column2: Jordan would need 217 votes to be elected speaker.

column1: But Jordan only needs a majority of voting lawmakers

Jim Jordan entered the House chamber and huddled into a corner of the floor with Rep. Mike Simpson, R-Idaho. Simpson is one of the handful of House Republicans who have either said they will not support Jordan or who have expressed hesitancy over voting for the Ohio Republican.
Jordan’s efforts to work the House floor to convince holdouts reflects the uphill battle he is facing to become speaker, as lawmakers prepare for what could be a long day of multiple ballots, reminiscent of McCarthy’s pursuit of the speakership back in January.
– Ken Tran
Acting speaker Rep. Patrick McHenry, R-N.C., has gaveled the House into session ahead of the speaker election, which is expected to take place after nominating speeches and a roll call vote to determine attendance.
– Ken Tran
If Jim Jordan is elected speaker of the House, he and President Joe Biden aren't expected to work closely together.
As chair of the House Judiciary Committee, Jordan is spearheading House Republicans’ impeachment inquiry into Biden. He also voted against certifying Biden’s victory in the 2020 election.
Biden hasn't gone out of his way to address the Republican infighting in the House.
White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said earlier this month that the White House views the process of choosing the speaker as an internal issue, but she said the president hopes that the House will quickly elect a speaker
column6: because the urgent challenges facing our nation will not wait."

The committee urged Democrats to show voters that the Republican Party lacks moderates and is unable to stand up to the ultra-conservatives within the caucus

column1: Because "if you're looking for a conversation that takes place in a shared experience in pain
column2: and then you go to someone with a conflicting experience from you to have that conversation
column3: you will be hurt
column4: Goldman says. And they will also probably be hurt." That said
column5: "if you must share information that you feel very strongly about
column6: it’s best to adopt a non-confrontational attitude – even if you believe you are right
column7:
says Cecille Ahrens, a licensed clinical social worker.
It may also be worth some introspection. We would be wise to remember that we are each a product of our own lived experience steeped in the culture that surrounds us
column8: says Laura Petiford, a licensed marriage and family therapist. Additionally
column9: we are influenced by the media's synthesis of information and the mediums we trust to deliver it to our screens and inboxes."

column1: Focus less on politics and more on the personal if you're aiming for a productive conversation. "Try and connect from a human perspective on fear and isolation
column2: and not being seen
column3: and all the other emotions that we all feel whenever there is war
column4:
Gurin-Malous says.
Abu-Sarah adds: Being vulnerable for each other and being willing to listen
column5: instead of being quick to fight and argue – this is true in all situations."

column1: He suggests focusing less on your position at the start of a dialogue and more on your story: "Before we start taking positions: 'Here why I stand (for Israel's) right to defend itself; here's why I stand for Palestinians' right to end occupation.' Before you say
column2: your position
column3: tell your story. It's more important."

column1: Consider
column2: too
column3: "is there any common ground from which you can start?" asks Regine Galanti
column4: a clinical psychologist. "Can you agree that all civilian deaths are terrible and tragic? That it's not OK to kidnap women and children? That it's terrible for people not to have access to basic utilities? Again
column5: if you have no common ground
column6: it might not be a conversation worth having right now."

column1: You are also allowed to hit pause if you're not ready to talk just yet. "It's OK to avoid conversations with friends or family if you're not  emotionally in the right place for these disagreements
column2: Galanti adds. I've been muting a lot of my Instagram stories – even of people that I agree with – because I go to Instagram to unwind
column3: and the constant barrage of videos on the Israeli-Gaza conflict make me anxious instead."

column1: Watch out:Israel
column2: Gaza and when your social media posts hurt more than help

column1: Some relationships may not survive disagreements of this nature. And that is OK
column2: too.

column1: For Gurin-Malous
column2: some wounds won't scar. They'll sit as open wounds.

column1: Some of the damage that has been done to me, and some of the relationships that I have around this, I think are irreparable, he says. "You can't unsay things you've said. And with that
column2: I also want to allow for the fact that this is a very hot button (issue) for everybody involved." Still
column3: "I want to also bring some compassion to the fact that sometimes we say things that we don't mean. And sometimes we out of fear lash out. And it is unfortunate
column4: I think that many
column5: many times
column6: we reserve our worst behavior for the people we love the most."

column1: Remember
column2: as Abu-Sarah says: "Behind every angry statement
column3: behind every talking point we throw at each other
column4: there's a hurt person."

column1: WASHINGTON − A bipartisan group of five U.S. senators in Tel Aviv were eating lunch in a hotel Sunday when sirens went off warning of incoming rockets.
The congressional delegation
column2: led by Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer
column3: D-N.Y.
column4: rushed to a shelter until the area was safe. It was an experience
column5: Schumer said
column6: that Israelis now have every day as war rages on between Israel and Hamas.

column1: It shows you what Israelis have to go through, Schumer wrote in a post on X
column2: formerly Twitter. "We must provide Israel with the support required to defend itself."

column1: Hamas launched a surprise attack on Israel earlier this month that has led to a conflict with a death toll surpassing 4
column2: 000 people. Israeli defense forces responded
column3: triggering a war between the country and Hamas
column4: a terrorist group that controls the Gaza Strip.

column1: Schumer led the bipartisan delegation to Israel over the weekend with Democratic Sens. Mark Kelly of Arizona and Jacky Rosen of Nevada
column2: as well as Republican Sens. Bill Cassidy of Louisiana and Mitt Romney of Utah.

column1: After a week-long recess last week
column2: the Senate was back in session Monday
column3: with the war in Israel the center of attention. But with the House unable to elect a speaker
column4: Schumer is in the driver's seat steering the upper chamber to pass an aid package for Israel with enough bipartisan support that it will inspire the House to follow suit.

column1: The House cannot consider aid to Israel
column2: or other crucial legislation
column3: until lawmakers pick a speaker.

column1: America will stand with its ally Israel and I, along with my colleagues here, will lead the effort in the United States to provide Israel with the support required to fully defend itself from this monstrous attack, Schumer said during a press conference in Tel Aviv Sunday.
The Israel-Hamas war explained:Understanding the conflict in Gaza amid rush to evacuate
Schumer sent a clear message from Tel Aviv over the weekend: Despite the dysfunction and missing leadership in the House
column2: the Senate would not wait on the lower chamber to pass an aid package to support Israel.

column1: We're not waiting for the House. We believe if the Senate acts in a strong, bipartisan way, it may indeed improve the chances that the House − even with its current dysfunction − will act, he said
column2: adding that waiting on the House to elect a speaker and pass support for Israel would be "foolish."

column1: Schumer said he personally would lead the effort to ensure Israel has the support it needs and anticipated moving a package in the next few weeks that would include military
column2: intelligence
column3: diplomatic and humanitarian assistance. He also called on lawmakers to work together and with the Biden administration to put together a plan.

column1: The bipartisan delegation met with Israeli leaders including President Isaac Herzog and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu
column2: as well as family members of victims of the attacks or of those taken hostage by Hamas.

column1: Sen. Mark Kelly
column2: D-Ariz.
column3: part of the delegation
column4: said the meetings he had with families of the American hostages were some of the toughest meetings he's had as a senator. He revealed that the photos and videos of the brutal attacks against Israelis were like nothing he had seen in his life
column5: including in the 25 years he spent in the Navy flying in combat over Iraq and Kuwait.

column1: I will speak to members of Congress one by one if that's what it takes to get Israel the munitions that you need to defend yourselves, he said in Tel Aviv.
Schumer
column2: the highest ranking Jewish elected official in the United States
column3: said he felt he had an obligation to visit Israel in the midst of the war.

column1: The purpose of trip was threefold
column2: according to the majority leader. First
column3: leaders wanted to send a clear message to the Israeli people that the United States stands with Israel. They also wanted to meet with Israeli leaders to discuss the country's military
column4: intelligence and humanitarian needs to best inform a future aid package. Lastly
column5: leaders said they were seeking to show that Israel's support in the United States is bipartisan.

column1: I'm doing everything in my power to ensure the Senate delivers the support Israel needs to accomplish these military intelligence and humanitarian goals. We will not just talk. We will act. We will work to move this aid through the Senate ASAP, he said.
Sen. Jacky Rosen
column2: D-Nev.
column3: the only Jewish woman in the Senate
column4: joined the delegation and said in Tel Aviv the United States stands with Israel "now and always."

column1: Our support remains unwavering and unconditional, she said.
Sen. Bill Cassidy
column2: R-La.
column3: one of two Republicans in the delegation
column4: said Americans living in Israel he met with during the trip all drew hope from the U.S' relationship with the country. Sen. Mitt Romney
column5: R-Utah
column6: condemned those who feel the U.S. should not get involved in the conflict.

column1: Backing away and saying, 'Hey, we're not going to worry about it' is not going to end their efforts,' Romney said
column2: later adding
column3: "We're involved in the world because it's in America's interest
column4: it's in Israel's interest
column5: it's on all of our allies' interests (and) it's in the world's interest."

column1: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell
column2: R-Ky.
column3: agreed with the need to support Israel in a speech on the Senate floor Monday.

column1: The United States must continue to provide maximum supports to Israel's counterterrorist operation as long as it takes, the minority leader said.

The delegation's visit to Israel comes as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is scheduled to hold a nomination hearing for Jacob Lew to be U.S. Ambassador to Israel. The United States currently does not have a designated ambassador.
But Lew
column2: who served as Treasury Department secretary under former President Barack Obama's administration
column3: doesn't face a path to ambassadorship without some hurdles.

column1: Several Republican senators
column2: including Sen. Tom Cotton
column3: R-Ark.
column4: have said they won't support Lew for the role.

column1: Jack Lew is an Iran sympathizer who has no business being our ambassador, Cotton said on "Fox News Sunday." "It's bad for the U.S. It's bad for Israel."
Cotton
column2: a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee
column3: claimed Lew helped Iran avoid American sanctions and lied to Congress about it.

column1: I know Democrats are saying that we need to confirm Jack Lew quickly to show our support for Israel. I would say it's the exact opposite. We need to defeat Jack Lew's nomination to show we have a new approach to Iran, he added.
Sen. Bill Hagerty
column2: R-Tenn.
column3: a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column4: claimed Lew was a "key point man" in negotiations under the Obama administration related to agreements with Iran.

column1: Lew must answer for the failed Obama-Biden Middle East strategy as he appears before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for his confirmation hearing next week, Hagerty posted last week on X.
Schumer urged his colleagues in the committee to approve Lew as quickly as possible "without any partisan delays" to bring the nominee to the Senate floor for a full vote.

Mr. Lew has proven himself a strong public servant, a ferocious ally of Israel, so delaying him would be egregious at a time like this. We must move him quickly and I hope we will, he said Monday on the Senate floor.
But what's next for lawmakers as the House remains without a speaker?
Schumer explained on the Senate floor Monday afternoon that the upper chamber will meet for an all-senators classified meeting Wednesday to hear from top Biden administration officials
column2: including Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin
column3: Secretary of State Anthony Blinken
column4: Chair of the Joint Chiefs Gen. C.Q. Brown and Director of National Intelligence Avril Haines.

column1: It is essential that we hear what is going on with our top leaders, Schumer said.

column3: revealed in her Glamour UK "Women of the Year" cover story published Monday that she discovered she was a feminist after a psychic told her she was.

column1: After the session

she told the outlet.

Brown, who got engaged to Jon Bon Jovi's son Jake Bongiovi earlier this year, also dished on how her relationship helped her embrace herself.
I think I was so afraid to be a strong woman in a relationship
column3: she said. When I met Jake

Those are things that I love about myself now. He was a really big, huge part of me loving myself and becoming a woman, Brown said. "It was like
column2: 'Wow
column3: I really love this person because he allows me to love myself.'"

WINTER HAVEN
column2: Fla. — Each October
column3: Teresa Scalf’s relatives prepare for the painful anniversary of her murder in 1986.

column1: This year
column2: for the first time
column3: the family members will at least know who committed the vicious killing 37 years ago.

column1: Through an investigation based on retained blood from the killer and public genetic databases
column2: the Polk County (Florida) Sheriff’s Office identified Donald Douglas
column3: a former neighbor of Scalf’s
column4: as the murderer. Douglas
column5: 33 at the time of the killing
column6: died of natural causes at 54 in 2008
column7: PCSO said.

column1: Scalf’s mother
column2: Betty Scalf
column3: and two of Teresa’s sisters joined Polk County Sheriff Grady Judd for a news conference Monday as Judd described how his agency solved the 37-year-old case.

column1: “All I want to say is
column2: I'm 84 years old
column3: ” said Betty Scalf
column4: a petite
column5: white-haired woman who uses a cane. “I lived to see this done. I think that’s why I lived so long.”

column1: Scalf found the mutilated body of her daughter on Oct. 27
column3: in the duplex she shared with her 8-year-old son in an unincorporated area of Lakeland
column4: about 35 miles east of Tampa. Teresa Scalf
column6: worked the night shift as a trauma nurse at what was then Lakeland General Hospital.

column1: Cold case:Victim of 'Happy Face' serial killer who left smiley faces on letters ID'd after 29 years
Betty Scalf received a call saying that her daughter
column2: a single mother
column3: had not shown up for work. Betty went to the duplex
column4: used a credit card to open the locked door
column5: and then discovered her daughter’s body.

column1: Judd
column2: with the family’s permission
column3: disclosed that Teresa had been repeatedly stabbed and nearly decapitated. Douglas lived just behind the duplex
column4: Judd said
column5: and PCSO investigators interviewed him and other neighbors at the time but never considered him a suspect.

column1: Judd speculated that Douglas killed Scalf because he sought a sexual relationship with her and she rebuffed him. Family members said Scalf had mentioned “a creepy neighbor” shortly before her death but didn’t name or describe him.

Judd credited Detective Matthew Newbold with leading the effort to resolve the case after receiving it in 2015. Newbold kept a photo of Teresa Scalf on his desk and vowed to her family that he wouldn’t retire until he had identified her killer
column2: Judd said.

column1: “I hope it gives everybody comfort to know that we now know who did this
column2: ” said Pam Shade
column3: Teresa’s sister. “We also would like to offer encouragement to other homicide victims — don't give up. They (law enforcement) don't give up. And as long as they don't give up
column4: you don't give up.”

column1: Cold case:5 years after pregnant Chicago woman vanished
column2: her family is still searching

column1: Evidence at the scene suggested that Teresa fought back against her attacker
column2: and PCSO investigators collected blood from her murderer. As technology advanced
column3: the agency entered DNA taken from that blood into the FBI’s national database in the early 2000s but found no matches
column4: meaning the killer’s DNA had not been entered.

column1: Judd said Douglas had never been arrested.
“My prayer is that he had been in mental prison
column2: ” Judd said.

column1: Newbold worked with Othram
column2: a Texas company that specializes in developing genetic samples from crime scene evidence. Using publicly available DNA that people submit through such programs as 23andMe
column3: the company helped create a family tree for the murderer
column4: said David Nutting
column5: a company representative who attended the news conference.

column1: It was the 106th publicly announced solution to an unsolved case through Othram’s DNA research
column2: Nutting said. He said there are an estimated 330
column3: 000 unsolved murders in the United States.

column1: After identifying Douglas as the murderer
column2: PCSO investigators contacted his son and asked for a DNA sample. He fully cooperated
column3: Judd said
column4: and was “mortified” to learn that his sample confirmed that Donald Douglas’ blood had been found at the scene of Scalf’s murder.

column1: Judd said that detectives originally investigating the case saw no wounds on Douglas and had no reason to suspect him of the killing. Betty Scalf said that heavy rain on the day of the murder washed away evidence and prevented search dogs from being able to find the killer’s trail from the duplex.
Joining Betty Scalf at the news conference were Teresa’s sisters — Shade
column3: and Lynne Scalf
column4: 57. Teresa’s granddaughter
column5: Teresa Wouters
column7: of Winter Haven
column8: stood beside her great-grandmother
column9: holding an arm around her.

column1: Betty Scalf said that Teresa’s son could not attend because of the overwhelming emotion the anniversary brings on.
'Listen
column2: be responsible'Polk League of Women Voters gives away gun locks to save lives

column1: Family members said they did not know Douglas
column2: who co-owned an electrical company with his brother. Lynne Scalf said she wished Teresa had described the “creepy” neighbor in a way that might have led the investigation to Douglas.

column1: Newbold said investigators found no sign of forced entry at Scalf’s duplex. Betty Scalf said she thinks Douglas entered through a sliding glass door and was waiting for Teresa when she arrived home after finishing her overnight shift and sharing lunch with some co-workers.
Family members praised Judd and Newbold for not giving up on solving the murder. They offered affectionate memories of Teresa Scalf
column2: who rose from an entry role as a phlebotomist to become a respiratory technician and then a registered nurse.

column1: Shade is also a registered nurse and said many family members have gone into medical fields through Teresa’s influence and example.
“The first thing that I would like to say is Teresa was a wonderful person
column2: the most loving person
column3: ” Shade said. “She didn't deserve it. Our family didn't deserve this.”

column1: She added: “She started off at the bottom
column2: nursing assistant. She went to respiratory school. She got her RN and was so proud. I've never seen anyone more proud. She said
column3: ‘I did it. Pam
column4: I did it.’ And she was dead a month later
column5: after we had this conversation.”

column1: Shade said that a brother had died in a diving accident only a year and a half before Teresa’s murder.
Lynne Scalf said that learning the identity of her sister’s killer does not bring an end to their grief but does relieve them of suspecting others who knew Teresa.
Betty Scalf
column2: noting that the murder occurred four days before Halloween
column3: said her daughter had promised to take her son out that day to buy a pumpkin for carving and had put a bike on layaway as his Christmas gift.

column1: Lynne Scalf said her sister had two bumper stickers on her car — one urging the adoption of a 911 emergency call system
column2: an idea that had not gained universal acceptance at the time
column3: and the other saying
column4: “Don’t take your organs to heaven. Heaven knows we need them here.”

column1: The manner of Teresa’s death
column2: and the delay of about 10 hours before her body was found
column3: prevented her from having her organs harvested for donation.

column1: “But she was the kind of person that if you asked her about something
column2: she would engage in dialogue
column3: ” Lynne said. “So hopefully that encouraged some people to consider that pathway.”

column1: “I was a colorful kid in a lot of ways

column3: ” published Tuesday (Penguin Random House). The book begins with her iconic coat of many colors
column4: which her mother stitched together from old fabric scraps. She then recalls her move to Nashville
column5: where she was told she’d never be taken seriously if she didn’t tone down her “trashy” style.

column1: Check out: USA TODAY's weekly Best-selling Booklist
But the singer didn’t back down. In fact
column2: “I just kept getting bigger and bigger and worse and worse with my look
column3: ” she jokes.

column1: Parton
column3: tells USA TODAY about plastic surgery
column4: her classic song "Jolene" at 50
column5: and why it's "scary" being so beloved.

column1: Question: In the book
column2: you revisit some of your most memorable album covers
column3: including "Here You Come Again" (1977). How did you land on that outfit?

column1: Answer: You usually have about four different looks before you do an album cover and you just pick the one that looks the best. We just stayed with the blue jeans and red shirt because that color combo really popped!
Before you released the title track
column2: there was some concern it would be "too pop" for your country fans. (It went on to hit No. 3 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart.)

column1: It’s a good song; that was my first main-selling record. Everybody said I was making a mistake
column2: so I was just praying
column3: “Lord
column4: please don’t let me be a flop. Let me have a hit record.” And the Lord was good! That was really my big start toward a bigger career.

column1: Speaking of incredible album covers
column2: there's also "Backwoods Barbie" (2008). How do you feel now that Barbie is all the rage? Are people just finally catching up to Dolly?

column1: Well
column2: Barbie was around long before I was (famous)! But with “Backwoods Barbie
column3: ” I thought
column4: “Well
column5: I am just a Backwoods Barbie: too much makeup
column6: too much hair.” I was really happy when the “Barbie” movie did so good! I’ve always loved pink and the Barbie Doll
column7: and that was a great little movie. So yeah
column8: I’m still the Backwoods Barbie.

column1: You write in your book that you “wake up with new dreams every day." What are some of your new dreams today?
I’m working on my life story as a musical on Broadway. I've written or chosen all the music that will go into it
column2: and I’ve co-written the script too. So all my spare time
column3: I’m spending on that. That’s been a dream of mine for years and years – at least 20 years I’ve been trying to put that together. I was just about to have it ready when COVID hit and Broadway shut down. Then I thought
column4: “Well
column5: maybe I’ll do it as a biopic
column6: ” and wrote up a script for that. But then I was like
column7: “Nah
column8: everybody’s doing a biopic! I’m going back to Broadway now that it’s open.” So I’m hoping to have my show (there) in spring of 2025. That’s my aim!

column1: You also write
column2: “Not everybody’s supposed to look like a movie star. You should be comfortable in your own skin
column3: no matter how far it stretches.” When did you make that realization for yourself?

column1: I think I’ve always been (confident). That started out as a joke: I was referring to plastic surgery
column2: and how I’ve done those nips and tucks. I always think of myself as a workhorse that looks like a show horse
column3: and I’ve got to keep that show horse up. So I do whatever it takes. The same with clothes: I really do think that fashion is not just what’s fashionable. True fashion is what you’re most comfortable in. If you’re going to be motivated and motivating
column4: you need to feel comfortable in what you wear. If you think you look good
column5: you’re going to do better. You’re going to be more apt to step forward and be assertive.

column1: 'I had the perfect song':Dolly Parton wanted Tina Turner for her new 'Rockstar' album
This week marks 50 years since "Jolene" was first released. Did you ever hear from the flirty bank teller who inspired it?
Yeah
column2: I saw her recently and she was big as a barn! (Laughs.) No
column3: actually
column4: it wasn't as severe as I made the song. I was just a little jealous that she was prettier than me
column5: so you always feel a little threatened when that happens. But it was not a big deal ‒ it was just good for a song
column6: let's put it that way. And I was only joking about seeing her.

column1: You write in your book that "you sometimes see yourself in strange places." Aside from a Tennessee license plate
column2: where's the weirdest place you've seen your likeness?

column1: In a drag show! (Laughs.) I’m big with the drag queens. Every now and then
column2: I’ll get these videos (of Dolly lookalikes). I’ve also seen myself on those Duncan Hines cake boxes in the supermarket. I’ve signed so many of those boxes – I’ve now signed more cake mixes than I have photos through the years.

column1: Well
column2: I don't know a single person who has a bad thing to say about Dolly Parton. How do you feel about your status as an icon?

column1: It’s a little scary sometimes; I hope I can live up to all of that! But I think a lot of it is that I’ve been around for so long. I’m like a favorite aunt
column2: or a favorite godmother
column3: or a favorite sister. I’ve been around so long that people just think of me as part of the family! I’ve just been a fixture in their lives. I like that I’m part of that – I just hope I never let anybody down. I ain’t as important as some of you make me sound!

column1: A financial analyst who was fired by Citibank for allegedly lying about meal expenses lost a wrongful dismissal lawsuit filed in a London court against the large bank.
Former analyst Szabolcs Fekete sued Citibank last year after he was fired for gross misconduct when he claimed he was the only one who consumed two coffees
column2: two sandwiches
column3: and two pasta dishes during a work trip to Amsterdam.

column1: According to court documents
column2: when Fekete was asked about the expenses in an email in July 2022
column3: he said he had "checked the receipt and did not see anything out of order… I was on the business trip by myself and I had 2 coffees as they were very small."

column1: Fekete later admitted his partner
column2: who was not a Citibank employee
column3: was on the trip with him and shared the meals with him.

column1: He added that he was well within the company's 100 euro expense limit and doesn't think he has to "justify" his eating habits to "this extent.”
Learn more: Best current CD rates
The financial analyst claimed he was going through personal issues and was on strong medications when he sent the emails.
More:Former Washington State coach Nick Rolovich files wrongful termination claim over firing
Employment Judge Caroline Illing ruled in favor of Citibank last month. Illing said the dismissal was fair because Fekete was not initially honest about the expenses.
In considering the substantial merits of this case, I have found that this case is not about the sums of money involved, Illing said.
It is significant that the claimant did not make a full and frank disclosure at the first opportunity and that he did not answer questions directly.
More:Fired Northwestern football coach Pat Fitzgerald to sue school for $130M for wrongful termination
Illing said the bank “requires a commitment to honesty from its employees.”
“I have accepted that the expense report may have been submitted in error
column2: ” the judge said. “However
column3: I am satisfied that a dismissal in relation to the misrepresentation allegation alone would fall within the band of a reasonable response by a reasonable employer.”

column1: In a statement to USA TODAY a Citibank spokesperson said the company was "pleased with the decision."
There are moments in a league's history when they are clearly on the wrong side of it. When they make a decision that isn't just foolish but morally wrong. This is where the NHL is right now.

The NHL recently sent a memo to its teams clarifying what players are allowed to do during theme celebrations this season. One of the actions it took was ban the use of rainbow-colored stick tape for Pride Nights. Pride Nights
column2: unbelievably
column3: have become a controversial issue in the league.

column1: The guidance doesn't solely apply to Pride. It also states that on-ice player uniforms and gear for games
column2: warmups and official team practices can't be altered to reflect theme nights
column3: including Pride
column4: Hockey Fights Cancer or military appreciation celebrations. Players can participate in themed celebrations off the ice if they choose.

column1: To be clear
column2: NHL teams will still have Pride Nights
column3: but this represents a chipping away at the advance the NHL has made in recent years in backing the LGBTQ community and players.

column1: So why did the NHL do this? The league
column2: I believe
column3: is trying to satisfy a strong anti-LGBTQ element that exists in professional hockey (and across some other sports) and also among the fans who watch the sport. They could have easily just done nothing. That's what makes this action so reprehensible.

column1: Putting rainbow-colored tape on the blade of a stick is a meaningful gesture and show of support for members of the LGBTQ community both inside and outside of the sport. The fact the NHL won't even allow this small move says a great deal about what the NHL thinks about LGBTQ players.
You don't need to take my word for it about the wrongness of this decision. Listen to the players
column2: former executives and others who say the same.

column1: One of the stars of the league
column2: Edmonton's Connor McDavid
column3: expressed his disappointment in the NHL's decision:

column1: Said former NHL executive Brian Burke: "This is not inclusion or progress. Fans look to teams and the league to show they are welcome
column2: and this directive closes a door that's been open for the last decade. Make no mistake
column3: this is a surprising and serious setback."

column1: Burke
column2: on X
column3: formerly known as Twitter
column4: made one of the more important points about why the NHL did this. It was to appeal to the few people who don't want the league to be inclusive.

column1: This decision has stripped clubs of a powerful community outreach tool and removed meaningful support for special Initiatives, all to protect a select few who do not want to answer any questions about their choices. I hope the NHL reconsiders in order to remain a leader in DEI.
You’ll probably see me with the Pride tape on that night, said Philadelphia's Scott Laughton. "I don’t know
column2: I didn’t read really what it said
column3: if it’s a ban or something
column4: but I’ll probably have it on.

column1: We’ll see what they say, but it’s not gonna affect the way I go about it. If they want to say something, they can.
And while the NHL union
column2: as far as I can tell
column3: has remained silent
column4: the Professional Women's Hockey League Players Association
column5: headed by Burke
column6: has not:

column1: Neither did the Alphabet Sports Collective
column2: which pushes for a safe and inclusive environment in hockey for all people:

column1: The You Can Play Project
column2: which advocates for LGBTQ participation in sports and has worked extensively with the NHL
column3: said in a statement: "If Hockey is for Everyone
column4: this is not the way forward."

column1: It is now clear that the NHL is stepping back from its longstanding commitment to inclusion, and continuing to unravel all of its one-time industry-leading work on 2SLGBTQ+ belonging, the organization said. "We are now at a point where all the progress made
column2: and relationships established with our community
column3: is in jeopardy. Making decisions to eradicate our visibility in hockey — by eliminating symbols like jerseys and now Pride Tape — immediately stunts the impact of bringing in more diverse fans and players into the sport."

column1: Then
column2: there were the actual makers of the tape:

column1: I know what some of you are going to say.
Let the players do what they want. Don't force "their" lifestyle on everyone. This is America. Freedom. Apple pie. Etc.
But the NHL knows better. The league knows it's not about any of that. The league is doing this out of fear with a select few
column2: as Burke said
column3: making these decisions to appeal to anti-LGBTQ forces
column4: and those people making the decisions aren't standing in front of the cameras and answering questions on why. They won't because they're cowards.

column1: This story is about inclusion
column2: of course
column3: but in some ways it's about something simpler: decency. The NHL had a moment to be decent. It could have fought the uglier base instincts that rule us all. They didn't. They caved.

column1: And this is why the NHL is on the wrong side of history.
The Carolina Reaper has been officially dethroned as the world’s hottest chilli pepper.
PuckerButt Pepper Company founder and pepper expert Ed Currie has spent the last ten years working on Pepper X
column2: a chilli pepper that emits an “immediate and brutal heat
column3: ” according to reporting by the Associated Press.

column1: Five of those years were spent proving Pepper X was a different plant with a different fruit and documenting its average heat over different plants and generations.
“We covered the genetics
column2: we covered the chemistry
column3: we covered the botany
column4: ” Currie shared.

column1: Pepper X
column2: which has a rating of 2
column4: 000 Scoville Heat Units was named hottest chili pepper in the world by Guinness World Records on Oct. 9.

column1: The heat of the pepper lingered with Currie hours after he completed his initial taste test.
“I was feeling the heat for three-and-a-half hours. Then the cramps came. Those cramps are horrible. I was laid out flat on a marble wall for approximately an hour in the rain
column2: groaning in pain
column3: ” Currie shared with the AP.

column1: The greenish-yellow Pepper X has an earthy flavor unlike the spicy-sweet taste found in the bright red Carolina Reaper. Pepper X was crossbred with a Carolina Reaper and a pepper from Michigan that is “brutally hot
column2: ” Currie said.

column1: More:'Hot Ones
column2: ' Bobbi Althoff and why we can't look away from awkward celebrity interviews

column1: Currie chose to unveil Pepper X on “Hot Ones
column2: ” a YouTube talk show where celebrities are interviewed over an assortment of spicy chicken wings.

column1: He was joined by the show’s host Sean Evans
column2: Claus Pilgaard “Chili Klaus” and Noah Chaimberg from Heatonist
column3: the hot sauce company that partners with Hot Ones to source their hot cause lineup.

column1: Currie talks all things Pepper X
column2: receives his Guinness World Records plaque and facilitates a Pepper X taste test to end the video.

column1: “There’s an intense burn that happens immediately. Then your head kind of feels like ‘Oh
column2: no. What’s going on?’ Then your body just starts reacting. You get it in your arms. You get it in your chest. It has no real throat burn like the Reaper but that comes on later when you are in pain
column3: ” Currie says in the video.

column1: The Scoville scale measures the spiciness of chilli peppers numerically based on the pepper’s capsaicin concentration
column2: which causes a burning sensation when it comes into contact with human tissue
column3: according to Guinness.

column1: The burning sensation produced by capsaicin also releases endorphins and dopamine into the body
column2: AP reported.

column1: Currie
column2: who began to grow peppers after overcoming substance abuse addictions
column3: says the kick from the peppers is akin to a natural high.

column1: He has shared his inventions with medical professionals in the hopes of helping people who suffer from chronic pain or discomfort.
Currie has hinted at the possibility of pepper hybrids much hotter than Pepper X
column2: but has kept his cards close to the vest.

column1: “Is this the pinnacle?” Currie said of Pepper X
column2: a mischievous smile warming his face. “No
column3: it’s not the pinnacle
column4: ” AP reported.

column1: Winthrop University in South Carolina spent the last four years conducting tests on specimens to determine Pepper X’s Scoville score.
Here’s how Pepper X compares to other chilli peppers:
Contrary to popular belief
column2: the seeds of a pepper don’t make it hot. Capsaicin is held in the placenta
column3: or the tissue that holds the seeds.

column1: Peppers aren’t the only thing that have a Scoville score
column2: pepper spray has a score of 1.6 M SHU while bear spray has a score of 2.2M SHU
column3: respectively
column4: the AP reported.

column1: DENVER — It’s difficult to overstate how good the 2024 Chevrolet Corvette E-Ray is
column2: or what an important step it constitutes for America’s great sports car. Now
column3: maybe the world’s great sports car. Performance
column4: design
column5: technology
column6: value: It’s hard to think of an area where the E-Ray isn't at least among the leaders.

column1: All-wheel drive and hybrid-powered
column2: the E-Ray is the biggest leap of imagination and engineering in the Corvette’s 70-year history. Ferrari 296 GTB
column3: Audi R8
column4: Porsche 911
column5: McLaren Artura
column6: Acura NSX
column7: Nissan GT-R
column8: Corvette. Take your pick. You’ll never get a consensus
column9: but that’s the point: Each car is as good as it gets. The fun is in the debate
column11: lap times and unforgettable road trips.

column1: The ‘Vette’s last evolution
column2: from front engine/rear-wheel drive to mid-engine for the 2020 model year
column3: was child’s play by comparison. Chevy engineers had been kicking around proposals for mid- and rear-engine models for decades. That was a question of when
column4: not if.

column1: Building an electrified — not electric
column2: there’s a difference; the E-Ray is a hybrid that combines a classic small-block V8 driving the rear wheels with an electrically powered front axle — ‘Vette with all-wheel drive was a choice dictated by physics and advances in engineering. Locating the engine's weight over the rear wheels improves traction. Powering the front axle with a small
column3: efficient electric motor provides instant torque and precise control.

column1: The program began before and was separate from the Ultium electric motors and batteries GM developed for 100% electric vehicles like the Cadillac Lyriq
column2: and Chevy Silverado EV pickup. It’s also unrelated to the inexpensive Chevy Bolt.

column1: The E-Ray was part of the plan for the eighth generation C8 model from the start. That’s why its lithium-ion battery fits tidily in the center tunnel
column2: and why the front electric motor and reworked steering and suspension don’t reduce space in the car’s front trunk.

The E-Ray’s bodywork is virtually identical to the Corvette Z06
column2: with the exception of name badges and a logo that adds a pair of openings — opinion varies as to whether they’re eyes or gills — to the stylized stingray’s dorsal surface. The E-Ray is 3 inches wider than a Stingray
column3: with staggered 20- and 21-inch wheels.

column1: Chevy explains the distinction between the two models thus:
The E-Ray is faster 0-60 mph — if the difference between its 2.5 seconds and the Z06’s 2.6
column2: as measured by Chevrolet
column3: is a deal breaker for you. The track-ready Z06 covers a standing quarter-mile in 10.6 seconds and hits 130 mph
column4: while the E-Ray slouches through it in 10.5 and 129 mph. Of such distinctions are buying decisions made
column5: particularly when you’re dealing with some of the most passionate and informed car buyers on Earth.

column1: If you haven’t been keeping up with “Planet Earth” on BBC
column2: the name E-Ray is a riff on ‘Vette’s stingray heritage: There’s also an electric ray
column3: a sleek sea creature that generates up to 220 volts to defend itself or stun prey.

column1: Getting the front axle’s electric motor and the rear wheels’ 6.2L V8 to work together seamlessly at thousands of revolutions per minute — while simultaneously diving into curves and managing inputs from the steering system
column2: eight-speed transmission and Brembo carbon-ceramic brakes — was one of the most daunting challenges GM engineers have tackled. And remember
column3: this is the company that developed Lunar Rovers for the Apollo program.

column1: “It’s the most complicated consumer product you can buy
column2: ” Corvette executive chief engineer Tadge Juechter told me as he pointed out details of the exposed mechanicals in a cutaway E-Ray in an airport hangar outside Denver. “Electrification increases the driver’s feeling of control and composure in all conditions.”

column1: The E-Ray’s sensors also interpret steering angle and pedal inputs to determine the driver’s intent and keep the car on course and at speed. The electric all-wheel drive system dispenses torque for secure traction accelerating out of curves.
The 6.2L V8 engine produces 495 hp that go to the rear wheels
column2: via the same eight-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission that powers all current Corvettes. An electric motor located under the front trunk delivers another 160 hp.

column1: There’s no physical connection between the two drivetrains
column2: which must operate in harmony at all speeds
column3: road surfaces and conditions.

column1: The Acura NSX
column2: which ended production last year
column3: was the only other supercar with independently powered front and rear ends. Its front wheels are driven by two separate electric motors. A turbocharged V6 and electric motor power the rear. The NSX developed 600 hp and accelerated to 60 mph in 2.9 seconds. Prices started at $169

column1: Car recalls:Ford and Mercedes-Benz among nearly 250
column2: 000 vehicles recalled: Check car recalls here

column1: I found the E-Ray remarkably easy to drive over two days that included highways
column2: twisting mountain roads north of Denver and a tight slalom course at Pikes Peak International Raceway
column3: 90 miles south of the city.

column1: The power comes on with smooth precision
column2: the steering is responsive and neutral
column3: the ride surprisingly comfortable over bumps.

column1: An adaptive magnetic ride suspension kept the car level in fast launches and hard braking
column2: and firmly planted in fast maneuvers
column3: including a tire-smoking drifting session the E-Ray could have maintained until the the tread fell off or the tank ran dry.

column1: Speaking of running without gasoline
column2: the electric front axle provides a "stealth mode
column3:
with speeds up to 45 mph when leaving home or driving through the neighborhood.
The electric motor also extends the V8’s four-cylinder operating mode on the highway, reducing fuel consumption and emissions. The 655-hp E-Ray avoided the gas-guzzler tax, scoring the same 19 mpg EPA rating in combined city and highway driving as a 490-hp, gasoline-only Stingray.
The E-Ray’s weight distribution is 42% over the front axle, 58% over the rear, a couple of percentage points more over the nose than the base ‘Vette, but “still in the sweet spot’” for acceleration and handling, Juechter said.
The interior is luxuriously trimmed in leather, suede and carbon fiber. The touch screen includes performance displays.

Interest in bodybuilding has skyrocketed since the pandemic began. Searches for bodybuilding" or "weightlifting" apps have grown by over 190% year over year
column4: according to Google Trends data. Among the most popular bodybuilding gym exercises that people seek out are squats
column5: dumbbells and deadlifts. But one analysis shows that by far the most popular weightlifting exercise – among both men and women – is the bench press.

column1: The bench press is such a sought-after piece of gym equipment because the workout produces the kind of results bodybuilders are after
column2: it's a straightforward exercise that's easy to do and because it offers a host of other health benefits beyond muscle growth alone.

column1: Like many forms of resistance training
column2: the bench press requires the use of some basic gym equipment. These include a workout bench to lay back on
column3: a long barbell that sits atop a secure rack frame on both sides of the bench
column4: and weight plates of varying poundage that are added to each side of the barbell in equal amounts and then secured with clips at each end.

column1: Once the right equipment is in place
column2: getting the most out of the exercise requires good form. Jackie Miller
column3: a certified IRONMAN and USA Triathlon coach who has been advising athletes for 18 years
column4: says the trick to proper bench press form is sticking to the following steps:

column1: Once you feel fatigue such as muscle burn or feeling overly tired, it's time to rack the weight, says Melanie Adams
column2: an American College of Sports Medicine certified exercise physiologist and a professor of exercise science at Keene State College in New Hampshire.

column1: Done properly
column2: the exercise works several muscle groups
column3: but its primary target is the pectoralis major
column4: often called pecs. "This is the large
column5: fan-shaped muscle on top of our ribs and over our chest
column6:
says Adams. She explains that the job of these chest muscles is to help move one's shoulders and control movement of both arms across the front of the body.
The bench press works other muscles, too. The triceps get some good stress as well as the exercise extends the elbow
column7: Adams explains. So do assisting muscles such as deltoids, biceps, forearm muscles, rib muscles, and the latissimus dorsi
column8: which stabilize the wrist and shoulder blades."

column1: The exercise is also unique because it can be adjusted to target each muscle group more extensively.
Lifting from an inclined workout bench will target one's upper chest muscles
column2: while decline bench-pressing movements will target one's lower chest muscles
column3: explains Dr. Matthew Best
column4: director of research in the sports medicine division at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine. At either setting
column5: however
column6: "it's important to avoid trying to lift too much weight or performing the exercise too rapidly
column7: which can predispose to injury
column8:
he adds.
More on squats:Squat challenges are all over social media. What muscles does the exercise work?
Beyond increased upper-body strength in each of these muscle groups, bench pressing has other health benefits as well. These include improved stamina and endurance, increased mobility and some research shows that the exercise can also increase bone density.
Performing the exercise also partly satisfies the physical activity recommendations set forth by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. For optimal health and strength, the agency recommends 75 to 150 minutes of moderate to vigorous aerobic activity each week in addition to muscle strengthening activities at least twice a week. 
Maintaining such levels of physical activity, the CDC notes, can improve one's brain health, help manage weight, reduce the risk of disease and improve one's ability to do everyday activities. Many people are initially interested in weightlifting to increase muscle size
column9: but quickly learn our muscles are involved in all kinds of hormonal interactions like lowering inflammation
column10: stopping stress response and growing brain cells
column11: explains Adams. Building both muscular endurance and muscular strength throughout the body pays off for your health."

column1: WASHINGTON - President Joe Biden plans to travel to Israel on Wednesday in a dramatic display of support for the U.S. ally as his administration seeks to prevent the Israel-Hamas war from expanding into a larger Middle East conflict.
Secretary of State Antony Blinken
column2: who is currently in Tel Aviv
column3: announced Biden's visit following an overnight meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

column1: He's coming here at a critical moment for Israel, for the region and for the world, Blinken said.
The trip will come a week and a half after Hamas' surprise attack on Israel killed at least 1
column2: 300 Israelis
column3: prompting airstrikes on Gaza in retaliation. The death toll on both sides of the war has surpassed 4
column4: 000 − about 2
column5: 800 in Gaza − and more than 10
column6: 000 are wounded. Blinken said at least 30 Americans were killed in Israel.

column1: Blinken said Biden "will again make clear
column2: as he's done unequivocally
column3: that Israel has the right and indeed the duty to defend its people" following the Hamas attack.

column1: Biden will travel to Tel Aviv
column2: where he will hold a bilateral meeting with Netanyahu and meet with other Israeli officials.

column1: Blinken said Biden will hear from Israeli leaders about what it needs from the U.S. to defend itself. The White House is seeking approval from Congress to provide military aid to Israel.
Israel has advised Palestinians in northern Gaza to head south ahead of a ground offensive
column2: prompting concerns that other Middle East adversaries could join the conflict.

column1: President Biden will underscore our crystal-clear message to any actor, state, or non-state trying to take advantage of this crisis to attack Israel. Don't, Blinken said.
Biden has publicly warned other parties hostile to Israel – terrorist groups and other nations - not to use the Israel-Hamas War as a moment to interfere and expand the conflict.
Biden singled out Iran by name last week
column2: saying he “made it clear to the Iranians: Be careful.”

column1: But Iranian leaders warned Monday that an expanded Israel-Hamas War is increasingly becoming unavoidable
column2: a sign that the primary backer of the Palestinian militant group Hamas is preparing for a larger conflict.

column1: “The time for political solutions is running out
column2: Iran’s foreign minister, Hossein Amirabdollahian, wrote on X, formerly known as Twitter, adding that the possibility of expanding the scope of the war on other fronts is approaching the stage that cannot be avoided."

column1: Iran is allies with Hamas but the Biden administration has so far said it found no evidence that Iran either knew about the attack on Israel or helped Hamas carry it out.
Biden canceled a previously scheduled trip Monday to Pueblo
column2: Colorado
column3: where he planned to tout his administration's efforts to expand wind turbines
column4: as the administration scrambled to arrange the Israel visit.

column1: John Kirby
column2: a White House spokesman for national security issues
column3: said Biden will "affirm our solidarity with Israel
column4: and he will look forward to getting an update from Israeli officials about their strategy and the pace of their military operations."

column1: Biden will also talk to Israel about the hostages who are being held by Hamas and will discuss coordinating efforts to get Americans back home
column2: Kirby said.

column1: Asked whether it's safe for Biden to travel to the region
column2: Kirby said
column3: “We wouldn't make a trip
column4: obviously
column5: if we did not believe that proper security measures would be in place.”

column1: Also on Wednesday
column2: Biden will travel to Amman
column3: Jordan
column4: where he will meet with King Abdullah II
column5: Egyptian president Abdel Fattah El-Sisi and Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abba. Biden will reiterate his concern that Hamas does not represent the vast majority of the Palestinian people
column6: and he will discuss the humanitarian needs of all civilians in Gaza
column7: Kirby said.
