column1: Editor's note: Part one of a five-part USA TODAY series revealing why America hasn't solved its long struggle with Type 2 diabetes.
For chef Robin Ray
column2: newly married with young stepchildren
column3: the turning point came when a stabbing chest pain sent her rushing to the emergency room.

column1: For Brian Castrucci
column2: the gravity hit when the ER doc who had treated him for a near-heart attack a few weeks earlier gave him a big bear hug. “I didn’t think you’d make it
column3: ” the doctor said.

column1: The crisis unspooled more slowly for James Haynes but started in 2019 when he stepped on a rusty nail and didn’t notice.
The moments were turning points for all three to get serious about addressing their diabetes.
Type 2 diabetes
column2: in which the body can’t properly regulate blood sugar
column3: has become so common it’s almost considered inconsequential. More than 1 in 10 Americans have the disease (though many don't know) and another nearly 4 in 10 are at risk for it. In total
column4: half of all adults and a quarter of teenagers have diabetes or pre-diabetes.

column1: Its financial costs are astronomical. The country spends more than $300 billion a year to address diabetes
column2: accounting for $1 out of every $4 spent on health care.

column1: And its personal tolls are even worse: heart attacks
column2: amputations
column3: blindness
column4: kidney disease
column5: double the risk of premature death. It also causes what’s known as “diabetes distress
column6: ” the daily burdens and emotional toll of living with and managing a chronic ailment that can lead to regular dips in energy
column7: foggy thinking and depression
column8: and a sense of isolation.

column1: The most frustrating aspect of Type 2 diabetes
column2: experts say
column3: is that it has long been largely preventable and controllable.

column1: “We have made tremendous gains in understanding diabetes
column2: ” said Dr. Donald Berwick
column3: a pediatrician and former administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. “The best diabetes care can make a very big difference. You can’t say we don’t know what to do.”

column1: And yet
column2: diagnosed rates of Type 2 diabetes have soared over the past 25 years
column3: and especially over the past dozen – particularly among working-age adults like Ray
column4: Castrucci and Haynes.

column1: Roughly 40% of people who died early in the coronavirus pandemic had Type 2 diabetes
column2: a rate four times higher than people without the disease. Even when elevated blood sugar levels are below the threshold for type 2 diabetes
column3: the risk for heart disease jumps 30% to 50% compared with people with normal blood sugar levels. (Type 1 diabetes
column4: which accounts for 5% to 10% of diabetes
column5: is caused by the immune system and is unrelated to diet or lifestyle.)

column1: America’s failure to address Type 2 diabetes highlights larger problems with our food and medical systems
column2: Berwick and other experts said.

column1: A soda costs less than a bottle of water
column2: a double cheeseburger and fries less than a carton of blueberries. Patients wait months for medical appointments only to see the back of a white coat for the short time they’re allotted. Treating disease costs society far more than preventing it but typically provides more profit for insurance companies
column3: hospitals and the pharmaceutical industry.

column1: The USA TODAY Health team spoke with scores of health care providers
column2: researchers
column3: community leaders and patients for this five-part series to understand why Type 2 diabetes continues to worsen in America despite known solutions.

column1: The answer isn't simple. It involves systemic problems facing everyone in society
column2: not just those with diabetes: a food system designed to sell products; a medical system in which cutting off a leg is less expensive than saving it; the high cost of healthy living and the fact that breaking habits takes a lot more than just personal willpower.

column1: This first story looks at what it takes for people to cope with or overcome the disease.
Then
column2: we explore one community in a David vs. Goliath battle against a food system that fails to prioritize people's health.

column1: More in series:Diabetes runs deep in rural Mississippi. Locals have taken to growing their own solutions.
We next travel to Colorado
column2: which has the lowest level of diabetes in the nation. Yet even in this state
column3: where hiking trails and gorgeous views abound
column4: economic and other disparities make it easier for some people to avoid diabetes than others.

column1: More in series:A diabetes disparity: Why Colorado's healthy lifestyle brand isn't shared by all
It's tough to manage a chronic illness in the face of high medical costs
column2: scattered care and caregiver frustration and burnout
column3: so we highlight that next.

column1: More in series:The steep cost of Type 2: When diabetes dragged her down
column2: she chose to fight

column1: Finally
column2: we explore solutions
column3: addressing why it will take a combination of education
column4: medication
column5: medical devices and improved food access to solve this national problem.

column1: More in series:Solutions exist to end the Type 2 diabetes dilemma but too few get the help they need
The system is fixable
column2: said Dr. Dariush Mozaffarian
column3: a cardiologist and professor at the Tufts University School of Medicine in Boston.

column1: But it will take "sensible action" from across many sectors
column2: including health care
column3: science
column4: nutrition
column5: business
column6: public health and politics to change the financial and other incentives that drive so many Americans toward sickness instead of health.

column1: If we do it all, we could fix a lot of this in 10 years, said Mozaffarian
column2: who serves on the President’s Council on Sports
column3: Fitness
column4: and Nutrition. "If we do it incrementally or don't do it at all
column5: we're all going to be toast in 50 years from diet-related illnesses and a depleted environment."

column1: There’s no question personal responsibility plays a role in fighting diabetes.
Haynes
column2: Ray and Castrucci radically changed their lifestyles and sought help after their come-to-Jesus experiences. They’ve reduced their dependence on daily medication and hope to have saved themselves the horrors of more amputations
column3: blindness and dialysis. They’ve extended their lives and improved the quality of that time.

column1: But like many medical problems
column2: the challenges of diabetes go well beyond individual responsibility and blame.

column1: “There are structural issues that we have to start paying attention to and addressing
column2: ” said Dr. Shivani Agarwal
column3: an endocrinologist who specializes in research and treating young adults with diabetes at Montefiore Medical Center and Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York. Agarwal recently led a series of studies in the journal The Lancet that looked at diabetes rates around the world.

column1: Poverty
column2: the studies showed
column3: was a major driver of diabetes
column4: along with racism and unequal access to healthy food and high-quality medical care.

column1: Personal stories illustrate how these structural issues play out in the lives of so many Americans.
Ray
column3: director of culinary operations at HOSCO/North Sarah Food Hub in St. Louis
column4: got weight-loss surgery and then put her culinary expertise to good use.

column1: Castrucci
column3: who runs a public health nonprofit outside Washington
column4: D.C.
column5: used his advantages provided by his work
column6: salary and insurance to “buy” himself better health.

column1: “I’m healthy because of privilege – not diet
column2: not exercise
column3: not determination
column4: ” he said.

column1: Haynes
column3: a former truck driver and maintenance technician in Gulfport
column4: Mississippi
column5: has fewer material assets
column6: but his attitude and the advantages he does have explain why he's still around
column7: despite all he has been through.

column1: “It’s going to be all right after a while
column2: as long as I keep this spirit
column3: ” he said.

column1: Ray’s love for food began when she was 8 years old
column2: watching Julia Child on TV. During family gatherings
column3: she would run around taking everyone’s dinner order. Then she’d scurry back to the kitchen with a notepad full of scribbles.

column1: Throughout her life
column2: she made fried chicken
column3: pork chops
column4: baked mac and cheese
column5: collard greens
column6: and even a whole roasted chicken filled with wild rice and two sticks of butter – everything that made her soul sing.

column1: In her world
column2: food was home. Food was family. Food was love.

column1: But that was some pretty tough love.

column2: Ray was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes. Her father
column3: grandmother
column4: aunts and uncles all had diabetes. She knew what it meant.

column1: “For you to tell me I can’t have ice blue raspberry Kool-Aid was like you shut down my world
column2: ” Ray said. “I didn’t want to accept it. So
column3: I ate
column4: because you eat through your emotions.”

column1: She didn't dwell on the diagnosis and continued with life. Her culinary career took her to Italy
column2: where she learned and fell even more in love with food. She returned to St. Louis
column3: got married and became a mom to her husband’s two children ‒ “beautiful bonus babies
column4: ” as she described them. Through the years
column5: she continued to express love through cooking and eating.

column2: a stabbing chest pain sent her to the emergency room. Doctors assured Ray she hadn’t had a heart attack
column3: but they warned that her life was on the line. At 5-foot-2
column4: she weighed 334 pounds and had an A1C
column5: a measure of average blood sugar of 11%
column6: well above the 6.5% cutoff to be considered diabetic. Her diabetes – and her diet – were out of control.

column1: “That scared me. … It was gut-wrenching and terrifying
column2: ” she said. “I’m fighting against something that’s fighting me back and I did not know how to win.”

column1: She and her primary care doctor decided she would pursue weight loss surgery.
But she also decided to use her culinary prowess to transform her diet. She reconfigured favorite foods
column2: substituting healthier ingredients: Collard greens cooked in smoked fats or ham hocks turned into a kale
column3: turnip and rutabaga recipe flavored with natural chicken broth fat
column4: oils and seasonings.

column1: She fostered her feelings into new recipes and brought them to North Sarah Food Hub
column2: which partnered with Barnes-Jewish Hospital to make packaged
column3: pre-made meals for St. Louis residents with diabetes and limited access to fresh food.

column1: “I had to restructure the food that I put in my mouth. I had to think about what I was eating and how I was eating and how it was going to be good for my body
column2: ” she said. “I became excited about food again
column3: and food became a joy.”

column1: It isn’t always easy
column2: of course. Ray admits to an occasional cookie craving. But now she takes the time to think about how her body processes that cookie and whether it’s worthwhile.

column1: She hopes her cooking can help other people make the same transformation she did. Her staff at North Sarah helps her create new recipes for others. She wants to provide nourishment that allows people to avoid illness and medicine.
“Nobody wants to take 55 pills
column2: nobody wants to feel like a patient
column3: but how do you fix that? It’s by our food
column4: ” she said. “That should be what we’re teaching our community and our culture and our children. … It’s not always about the macaroni noodle with a smile
column5: it’s about what’s good for your body.”

column1: Castrucci is a third-generation diabetes patient. The lifetime risk of developing Type 2 diabetes if a parent has it is 40%. If both parents have it
column2: the risk jumps to 70%.

column1: He knew he was at risk
column2: but he pushed his luck
column3: he said
column4: by eating poorly during the pandemic and falling out of his exercise routine. With the luxury of working from home
column5: walking to the kitchen and bathroom was often the extent of his daily activity.

column1: On Feb. 14
column2: 2022 – Valentine’s Day – he went to an urgent care clinic
column3: concerned his breathing trouble meant he had bronchitis. His blood pressure measured 210 over 110
column4: well above normal levels that top out at 120 over 80. A chest X-ray showed fluid filling his lungs
column5: leading to congestive heart failure.

column1: The clinic sent him straight to a local emergency room
column2: where he was diagnosed with a blockage of the left descending artery – a clogged artery made worse by diabetes. If he had waited any longer
column3: he would have had a massive heart attack
column4: his doctor later told him.

column1: After his release from the hospital
column2: he went to the drugstore to fill his new prescriptions. The pharmacist told him she couldn’t fill one because it would cost $1
column3: 000. He’d have to wait until his insurance approved it. “Please fill it
column4: ” he said. She stressed the cost. “Fill it
column5: ” he pleaded
column6: putting the charge on his credit card.

column1: Medication helped him lose 70 pounds in three months. When his local drugstore ran out of the weight-loss drug
column2: he easily drove to another pharmacy and then another to find what he needed.

column1: His 100 hours of high-quality cardiac rehabilitation were fully covered by insurance.
For my midlife crisis, I got healthy, Castrucci said.
He could devote all his energy to getting well because he didn’t have to focus on how to afford his care. “(I) paid almost nothing for the whole episode
column2: ” he said
column3: “and never worried about it because I have really good insurance.”

column1: Even so
column2: Castrucci pays out-of-pocket for a cardiologist and an endocrinologist because the best ones near him don’t accept insurance.

column1: Every time he goes to Walgreens to refill his medications
column2: Castrucci said
column3: he sees someone turned away because they can’t afford their prescriptions. When they finally show up in the emergency room
column4: “because they will
column5: ” they will cost the system far more
column6: he said.

column1: “Health outcomes are dictated by economics. It’s a whole side of privilege that we don’t always talk about.”
On the day Haynes stepped on a rusty nail in 2019
column2: he walked all day as the nail pierced the sole of his sneaker and then his foot. By the time he took off his shoe that night
column3: his foot was infected. He landed in the hospital for two months as doctors and nurses tried
column4: mostly unsuccessfully
column5: to get the infection and Haynes’ blood sugar under control.

column1: By the time he was released
column2: he knew enough about Type 2 diabetes to realize his daily blood sugar levels – typically in the mid-400s – were four times above what he had been told to shoot for.

column1: But nothing he did or ate seemed to make a difference. He had long since traded ribs for salads
column2: beer for water.

column1: His wife
column2: Angela
column3: barely noticed when James started wearing multiple pairs of socks
column4: pouring powder on his feet and buying bigger shoes. His feet tingled a lot
column5: he said
column6: but he was coping with it.

column1: James ended up in the emergency room again
column2: dehydrated and in need of antibiotics. The doctor amputated the baby toe on his right foot
column3: leaving a large open wound.

column1:
We're going to leave this open because we'll probably have to take more,” Angela remembered the doctor saying. “I didn't like that we're not going to try to save anything, we're just going to start cutting.”
James was fading.
His arm muscles shriveled and he lost his Popeye physique. Antibiotics left him looking sickly, his voice so weak Angela could barely hear him. “I felt like I was watching my husband slowly dying,” she said.
Finally, taking her doctor sister’s advice, Angela emailed Dr. Foluso Fakorede’s office to ask for an appointment. She thought it would take months to get James in to see the heart disease specialist, but the office called and asked if they could come the next day. 
The Hayneses would end up going back to see Fakorede many times − sometimes twice in one week, driving more than five hours each way from Gulfport north to Cleveland, Mississippi.
“We started looking forward to these visits because there was always hope,” Angela Haynes said, though she felt guilty they were taking up so much of the important doctor’s time. 
Fakorede, who is on a personal mission to save people with diabetes from amputations, noticed what other doctors had missed. Haynes had blockages in blood vessels on both legs. 
Once he got the blood flowing again, Haynes began to feel better. His flesh returned to its normal color. The wound started healing at last. Walking became easier.
Then disaster struck again. 
On July 2, 2022, Haynes caught COVID-19. Everything went downhill after that
column2:
he said.
During his 13-day illness, the bacteria in his foot raged out of control. He ended up back in the hospital and unable to withstand the long drive to Fakorede’s office.
Every week, a surgeon would come to the door of his hospital room and before even stepping all the way in ask Haynes whether he had decided to get his leg amputated. 
This is my leg. I was born with this. And you're walking in like you're cutting a piece of cake
column3:
Haynes said.
He was worried about how he’d get around, how he’d be able to work to support his family if he had only one leg. No one took the time to explain why they thought the leg needed to come off or how he’d cope without it, Haynes said. 
In late November, he was finally sent home in a wheelchair. But just three weeks later, as he was getting out of the car after wound care, his right leg gave out and he fell to the ground. Back at the hospital, Haynes was told his foot was broken, essentially beyond repair. He agreed to a below-the-knee amputation.
Released right before Christmas, he spent the next three weeks in bed wondering how he’d manage the rest of his life.
Finally, it looked as if his luck might be turning around.
With the leg gone, his diabetes improved. His blood sugar dropped into the 120s or one-teens. His blurry vision cleared up.
During his long hospital stay, he befriended nurses and learned about a program for people who needed prostheses. The man who ran it called early in the year and said he had received a donated leg. If it fit Haynes, he could have it while waiting for insurance to pay for a personalized one. Miraculously, it did. 
Haynes spent the next six months teaching himself to walk again. The donor leg was heavy and uncomfortable. He wasn't mobile enough to hold down a job.
One late spring night, picking up dinner at a nearby restaurant, he headed to the bathroom for a pit stop. A sink had been leaking all day and Haynes slipped in the puddle, falling backward.
He's still recovering from the resulting wrist surgery.
He and Angela are living – barely – off her part-time salary as a secretary and a church organist.
Haynes has tried at least three or four times" to receive government assistance
column4: but they keep losing his paperwork
column5: or not believing he's disabled
column6: though he once checked himself out of the hospital and arrived at an appointment in his wheelchair to prove he didn't have a leg.

column1: Still
column2: he clings to his faith and the positive attitude he has long used to cheer up himself and others. These are his secret weapons against diabetes and everything else life throws his way.

column1: I try to put a smile on other people's faces, he said. "It keeps my day going."

Hoover

The USA TODAY list is a ranking of the top-selling titles each week from a broad range of businesses including major chains

Rabbi Igael Gurin-Malous grew up in an Orthodox home
column2: spending time in Belgium

column1: Most of the people he went to Jewish boys school with are right-wing. This week

column1: His situation resembles many across the U.S. and rest of the world as people grapple with differing opinions among friends
column2: family and colleagues; A college group text devolving because no one can agree. Millennials walking on eggshells for fear of upsetting their Gen Z partners.

column1: There's no one way to approach sensitive issues of this nature. But experts say those aiming to preserve relationships fractured by the war between Israel and Hamas should tread lightly.
Reactions like rage and heartbreak are normal, says Kimberly Vered Shashoua
column2: a licensed clinical social worker. "If you’re feeling too overwhelmed with your own emotions
column3: that’s OK. Just let your partner or loved ones know you need some time or space before you are up for having deep conversations."

column1: Emotions have been running high since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7; 4
column2: 200 have died on both sides
column3: according to the United Nations.

column1: It's creating these distances that people feel unseen, unheard, vilified, Gurin-Malous says.

Many have expressed their fears and frustrations on social media in an effort to empathize and seek personal connections to tragedies in lieu of or in addition to private conversations. Maybe to alleviate guilt
column2: to feel like they're doing something
column3: to "perform" uneducated solidarity.

column1: These posts often go awry when people play the comparison game. "The problem is not the desire to find a personal connection
column2: says Benjamin Goldman, licensed mental health counselor. The problem is when conversations become about comparing degrees of suffering and pain. And during this time that we're in right now
column3: there's a lot of data and a lot of real information." Anyone can throw statistics at a situation to try and justify their points. But many aren't really looking for meaningful conversation

column1: Aziz Abu-Sarah's octogenarian parents live in Jerusalem. He visited them there three weeks ago. Now
column2: he's afraid for their safety. A Palestinian peacemaker
column3: his Israeli and Palestinian friends have been asking him how to broker dialogue.

column1: My advice was this: refrain (from) political discussions, he says. "Don't talk heavy politics right now. You always do
column2: you will eventually
column3: but now
column4: maybe is not the time to start going into what happened 100 years ago and 50 years ago. This is just the wrong time for that."

column1: Before engaging with someone on as sensitive a topic as the Israeli-Palestinian conflict
column2: consider who you are talking to (i.e. where do they fall on the issue) and have a goal in mind. Are you looking to vent? For a dialogue? To change their mind?

column1: Because "if you're looking for a conversation that takes place in a shared experience in pain
column2: and then you go to someone with a conflicting experience from you to have that conversation
column3: you will be hurt
column4: Goldman says. And they will also probably be hurt." That said
column5: "if you must share information that you feel very strongly about
column6: it’s best to adopt a non-confrontational attitude – even if you believe you are right
column7:
says Cecille Ahrens, a licensed clinical social worker.
It may also be worth some introspection. We would be wise to remember that we are each a product of our own lived experience steeped in the culture that surrounds us
column8: says Laura Petiford, a licensed marriage and family therapist. Additionally
column9: we are influenced by the media's synthesis of information and the mediums we trust to deliver it to our screens and inboxes."

column1: Focus less on politics and more on the personal if you're aiming for a productive conversation. "Try and connect from a human perspective on fear and isolation
column2: and not being seen
column3: and all the other emotions that we all feel whenever there is war
column4:
Gurin-Malous says.
Abu-Sarah adds: Being vulnerable for each other and being willing to listen
column5: instead of being quick to fight and argue – this is true in all situations."

column1: He suggests focusing less on your position at the start of a dialogue and more on your story: "Before we start taking positions: 'Here why I stand (for Israel's) right to defend itself; here's why I stand for Palestinians' right to end occupation.' Before you say
column2: your position
column3: tell your story. It's more important."

column1: Consider
column2: too
column3: "is there any common ground from which you can start?" asks Regine Galanti
column4: a clinical psychologist. "Can you agree that all civilian deaths are terrible and tragic? That it's not OK to kidnap women and children? That it's terrible for people not to have access to basic utilities? Again
column5: if you have no common ground
column6: it might not be a conversation worth having right now."

column1: You are also allowed to hit pause if you're not ready to talk just yet. "It's OK to avoid conversations with friends or family if you're not  emotionally in the right place for these disagreements
column2: Galanti adds. I've been muting a lot of my Instagram stories – even of people that I agree with – because I go to Instagram to unwind
column3: and the constant barrage of videos on the Israeli-Gaza conflict make me anxious instead."

column1: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis was able to transport hundreds of people from Israel to Florida just days after announcing an evacuation initiative by tapping into an existing rescue program
column2: Project Dynamo
column3: that likely would have gone forward with the effort regardless of the state’s support.

column1: Florida has paid for five flights to evacuate people out of Israel between Friday and Sunday
column2: including one that landed in Tampa Sunday night with 270 people
column3: but Project Dynamo coordinated everything else
column4: according to the group’s CEO and founder Bryan Stern.

column1: Project Dynamo was founded in 2021 to help rescue people from Afghanistan after American troops withdrew from the country and has conducted missions everywhere from Ukraine to Sudan. The flight to Tampa Sunday was the group’s 602nd evacuation mission.
Stern spoke about the rescue missions during a news conference Monday and said he was raising money to pay for the Tampa flight when the state of Florida stepped in to offer assistance.
“We were fundraising right up until Gov. DeSantis and his office came in… bottom line is we would have figured it out
column2: ” Stern said. “We’ve done it six hundred and one times without government help
column3: six hundred and two was not going to be the one that we failed on. But it makes it so much easier when you have backing by a state entity for sure.”

column1: Many commercial flights out of Israel were canceled following a surprise attack by Hamas and subsequent retaliatory measures by Israel. That has left many Americans struggling to find a way out of Israel.
DeSantis declared a state of emergency last week and directed the Florida Division of Emergency Management to coordinate evacuation efforts. The governor
column2: running what now appears to be a longshot campaign for the Republican presidential nomination
column3: was at the Tampa airport Sunday to welcome the evacuees from Israel
column4: which included 269 Americans – including roughly 70 Floridians – and one native of the Czech Republic.

column1: Stern said he was grateful for Florida's financial support
column2: the first time a government agency has funded one of his evacuation efforts
column3: but also made it clear that he would've done everything to get people home safely
column4: regardless of whether Florida funded the effort.

column1: Would it have been possible? I'll tell you that I wasn't going to leave them behind and I'm not trying to stay in Israel a moment longer than I need to so we would've figured it out, for sure, Stern said.
DeSantis' trip to Tampa on Sunday was “the first time an American politician has ever met us home
column2: ” Stern said.

column1: The evacuation flight to Tampa involved gathering people from more than 12 different areas across Israel
column2: Stern said. On the flight were Ron and Linda Neumann
column3: who are trying to become dual citizens of Israel and the United States
column4: and their dog.

column1: The Neumanns have been living in Israel recently
column2: but also live in Melbourne.

column1: Ron Neumann said after two flights out of Israel were canceled he tried to find a way out of the country by contacting U.S. State Department officials and state officials in Florida. Neither effort was successful
column2: but he heard about Project Dynamo through a friend and they helped him get on the flight to Tampa.

column1: “It was a miracle from God because we had no way to get out
column2:
Neumann said.
Stern didn't know the exact cost of the most recent flight from Israel to Florida, but said the average cost to charter a plane from Tampa to Israel right now is around $2 million. The governor's office and the Florida Division of Emergency Management provided no answers to questions from the USA TODAY Network - Florida on costs of the trips.
The first Florida arrival of what supporters are calling DeSantis Airlines" come at the same time the Biden administration is chartering flights from Israel to European destinations so passengers could book connecting flights home. DeSantis has slammed the White House for "dragging its feet" on the charters and said its flights "dump people in Europe."

column1: “But people don't need to be dumped in Europe
column2: DeSantis said in a video posted on the social media website X by his campaign. They want to get home.”

column1: The flights from Israel occurred the same weekend CBS News' 60 Minutes aired a segment Sunday critical of DeSantis' actions in September 2022
column2: when his administration lured about 50 mostly Venezuelan asylum-seekers from Texas to Martha's Vineyard
column3: off the Massachusetts' coast
column4: with the false promise of jobs and housing.

column1: Money for that trip came from a $12 million fund established within the state's Division of Emergency Management for relocating undocumented migrants from within Florida to other locations. The program has since been expanded and rewritten by the Florida Legislature to authorize DeSantis' action
column2: after its legality was challenged in a handful of lawsuits.

column1: DeSantis while campaigning in Iowa
column2: home of the first Republican presidential nomination contest
column3: has cited the Martha's Vineyard trip as proof of his commitment to combating illegal immigration and to underscore the failures of the Biden administration. DeSantis' White House bid probably lives or dies based on how he performs in Iowa.

column1: Remember how it used to be? Belichick’s team

column5: versatile and looking poised to make a run.

column1: Here are the winners and losers from Sunday of Week 6.
NFL STATS CENTRAL: The latest NFL scores

column4: stats and more.

column1: On the back of an aggressive defense
column2: the Jacksonville Jaguars (4-2) took down the Indianapolis Colts 37-20 for a season sweep against their AFC South rivals. That gives Jacksonville a nice bump in the race for the division title
column3: but if there’s any indication that that Jaguars may stick around
column4: it’s the team’s turnover differential of +7
column5: which ranks second in the NFL. Jacksonville leads the NFL in takeaways with 15. By comparison
column6: the Jaguars had 27 last season
column7: tied for fourth-best.

column1: Their four takeaways against the Colts helped them build an early lead. Jacksonville still allows far too many explosive passing plays (it allowed three completions of 40 or more yards Sunday) and will need to limit those moving forward. Quarterback Trevor Lawrence has been solid and running back Travis Etienne ranks sixth in the league in rushing yards (451)
column2: but it’s Jacksonville’s propensity to create turnovers that gives it the ability to win any given week.

column1: The Lions (5-1)
column2: as the only team in the NFC North with a winning record
column3: are running away with the division. They have a two-and-a-half game lead on the next closest team. They are balanced
column4: with an offense capable of explosive fits and a defense that limits big plays. What makes Detroit so fun to watch is that it is versatile enough to win in different ways. And its players are maximizing effort
column5: too.

column1: In a 20-6 road win against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers
column2: quarterback Jared Goff lit up the box score to the tune of 353 yards and a pair of touchdowns. In previous weeks
column3: it had been David Montgomery and the rushing game posting big numbers. The defense has been steadily productive and limited Tampa Bay to two third-down conversions and no red=zone touchdowns on two tries. For the first time since 1969
column4: the Lions have won four straight games by 14 points or more. More may be coming.

column1: New York was without its two starting cornerbacks
column2: Sauce Garnder — one of the finest in the NFL — and D.J. Reed. It was still missing Aaron Rodgers
column3: yet the Jets defeated the Eagles 20-14 for the first time in franchise history. Philadelphia quarterback Jalen Hurts has been in the MVP conversation. New York
column4: however
column5: intercepted Hurts three times and pressured him on 21 of 50 dropbacks (42%).

column1: The Jets (3-3) are hanging around in the AFC East
column2: though the offense with Zach Wilson (19-of-33 for 186 yards) under center remains anemic. The Jets converted just two-of-11 third-down attempts (18.2%). They went just one-of-four in the red zone. Those numbers alone make it remarkable that New York upset the Eagles
column3: but it also shows the proficiency of the defense. This was a statement victory. But unless the offense eventually shows it can bear some weight
column4: this style will prove unsustainable.

column1: By no means is he a finished product
column2: and he still needs to sustain this production over a longer sample size
column3: but second-year Washington Commanders quarterback Sam Howell is taking steps toward becoming a reliable option. Howell
column5: ranks ninth in the NFL in passing (1
column6: 500 yards) and is posting an above-average completion rate (67.8%).

column1: In a 24-16 win against the Atlanta Falcons
column2: Howell recorded his first three-touchdown game. He also did it against a team that came into Sunday with the eighth-ranked passing defense (190.8 yards per game allowed). Yet
column3: what has made Howell’s performance this year so impressive is that he’s doing it behind a tattered Washington (3-3) offensive line that has yielded more sacks (34) than any other in the NFL. Some of those sacks
column4: of course
column5: are on Howell
column6: but his ability to evade pressure and release the ball quickly should give him some staying power in the league.

column1: San Francisco
column2: the most consistent team in the league thus far
column3: failed to seize opportunities against the Browns in a 19-17 defeat. And while a pair of missed field goals loom large
column4: second-year quarterback Brock Purdy played the worst game of his career. Rookie third-round place kicker Jake Moody pushed a 41-yard field goal that would have won the game
column5: and he also hooked a 54-yarder in the first quarter. The one in the opening frame came after linebacker Fred Warner returned an interception to the Cleveland 26-yard line; with that short of a field
column6: the Niners (5-1) should’ve done far more with that drive
column7: anyway.

column1: This was a game in which P.J. Walker started at quarterback for the Browns
column2: who were also Chubb
column3: their longtime offensive engine. The only score for San Francisco after the second quarter was after Walker’s second interception gifted the Niners the ball on the 8-yard line. Purdy (12-of-27 for 125 yards and one touchdown with one interception) struggled
column4: and now offensive stars Christian McCaffrey and Deebo Samuel are banged up.

column1: This was always going to be a tough ask
column2: upsetting the Buffalo Bills on the road with backup quarterback Tyrod Taylor starting. But New York (1-5) settled for a pair of field goals Sunday night after it had marched the ball down to Buffalo’s 11-yard line and failed miserably in the red zone.

column1: There was the end of the first half
column2: when New York got it down to the Bills’ 1-yard line. But with no timeouts and with the clock at 14 seconds
column3: Taylor appeared to audible into a run play for Saquon Barkley. It was stopped short
column4: the clock bled and the Giants couldn’t come away with any points. Then there was the final play of the game
column5: an untimed down with the Giants again at the Buffalo 1-yard line. This time New York did opt to pass
column6: but the attempt fell incomplete
column7: cementing a 14-9 loss. New York ended the game 0-for-5 in red zone tries and 0-for-3 in goal-to-go spots. Against weaker teams
column8: maybe those missteps aren't fatal. Against the Bills
column9: you’re asking to lose.

column1: The Seattle Seahawks outgained the Cincinnati Bengals by a margin of 381-214. They recorded 24 first downs to Cincinnati’s 15. They held the ball for eight more minutes. Yet in a 17-13 loss
column2: Seattle (3-2) was done by quarterback Geno Smith's interceptions and the offense's inability to punch the ball in the end zone.

column1: Smith did throw for 323 yards
column2: but he also tossed a red zone interception at the start of the second half and another at the start of the fourth
column3: after the Seahawks had whittled the Cincy lead down. But Seattle was just 1-of-5 in red-zone situations
column4: including 1-of-4 in goal-to-go scenarios. The Seahawks had a couple of shots at the end zone inside the four-minute mark in the fourth quarter. The first time
column5: Smith was sacked twice in four plays. The second
column6: he couldn’t connect with receiver DK Metcalf twice for the game-winning touchdown. All in all
column7: it wasted a solid defensive performance.

column1: With Mike Vrabel as their head coach
column2: the Tennessee Titans have been — for the most part — consistent. They’ve had a winning record in four of the last five years. Tennessee has claimed the division twice and has made three trips to the postseason.

column1: Now
column2: as it heads home from London after a 24-16 setback against the Baltimore Ravens and goes into the bye week with a 2-4 record and sitting in last place
column3: Tennessee faces a crossroads. That’s primarily because quarterback Ryan Tannehill
column4: who has been the starter since 2019
column5: is no longer suitable to direct this offense. Tannehill
column7: was carted off with an ankle injury against the Ravens
column8: but he has been ineffective even when healthy. He was never a star in Tennessee
column9: but the offense was at its best when he could play turnover-free
column10: clean football. He has a 2:6 touchdown-to-interception ratio this year and is on pace for a career-low 71.9 QB rating. It might be time to look to the future.

column1: WASHINGTON - Hunter Biden's lawyers are carrying out an aggressive counterattack as Republicans make the president's son the focus of an impeachment inquiry and a special counsel investigation threatens to hang over the 2024 election.
In a two-week span in September
column2: President Joe Biden's son Hunter Biden sued Rudy Giuliani over the release of personal material on Biden's laptop
column3: the Internal Revenue Service for allegedly revealing confidential information about his taxes and former Trump White House aide Garrett Ziegler for allegedly accessing and tampering with computer data that he does not own.

column1: Hunter Biden's legal team also issued third-party subpoenas to Trump allies Roger Stone
column2: Steve Bannon and Giuliani
column3: along with six others
column4: in recent weeks seeking information and documents related to Hunter Biden's external hard drive and laptop - contents of which each have boasted about possessing.

column1: The moves taking aim at Hunter Biden's accusers reflect a more aggressive legal strategy adopted by his attorney
column2: Abbe Lowell
column3: who was hired last December
column4: and long pushed by Kevin Morris
column5: a Hollywood attorney
column6: novelist and close friend of Hunter Biden. Morris advised going on offense after Republicans gained control of the House in the 2022 midterm elections.

column1: The Republicans have had the microphone to themselves for many, many months, said David Brock
column2: a Democratic operative and president of Facts First USA
column3: which he launched to counter Republicans' claims about the president's son.

column1: The thinking is to put some facts out there in the public domain so that the public can have a more accurate picture of Hunter and what went on here rather than the distorted Republican lens that is refracted through most of the media coverage, Brock said.
More:Hunter Biden as a 'foreign agent'? Inquiry comes as DOJ ramps up previously 'rare' enforcement

A counterpunch was also delivered as Hunter Biden pleaded not guilty this month to three gun-related charges in a Delaware federal court after a previous deal with prosecutors to plead guilty collapsed.
Lowell
column2: in a statement
column3: slammed the charges as "the result of political pressure from President Trump and his MAGA allies to force the Justice Department to ignore the law and deviate from its policies in cases like this one."

column1: Hunter Biden pleaded not guilty to three gun-related charges for his purchase of a Colt Cobra 38SPL revolver on Oct. 12
column2: 2018 when he has said he was on drugs.

column1: Hunter Biden's lawyers have argued the charges are unconstitutional under the Second Amendment and barred under the prior plea agreement that fell apart. Lowell has said there’s evidence that will exonerate Hunter Biden “when and if there is a trial."
Hunter Biden could also face tax-evasion charges under an ongoing investigation by U.S. Attorney David Weiss
column2: a Trump-appointed prosecutor who was given special counsel status in August. Like the gun charges
column3: Biden had previously reached a deal with prosecutors to plead guilty to two misdemeanors for not paying taxes in 2017 and 2018 before the agreement collapsed.

column1: In addition
column2: the Justice Department is considering a possible third set of charges over Hunter Biden's decision not to register as a "foreign agent" while working with companies in Ukraine and China.

column1: The recent subpoena letters are part of counter lawsuit Hunter Biden filed in March against John Paul Mac Isaac - the owner of a Delaware computer shop - that fights the dissemination of material from an external hard drive and personal laptop that's long been at the heart of the Hunter Biden controversy.
For years
column2: Republicans have exploited material found on a hard drive on Hunter Biden's personal laptop that he left at Mac Isaac's Delaware store in 2019 but never returned to pick back up. Mac Isaac
column3: an outspoken supporter of former President Donald Trump
column4: claimed ownership of the equipment and passed it along to the FBI and to Giuliani ahead of the 2020 election.

column1: Hunter Biden's lawyers accuse Mac Isaac of invasion of privacy
column2: arguing that Hunter Biden never gave him permission to access
column3: copy and share electronically stored data on the computer. The subpoena letters to others like Stone and Bannon could preview future litigation against others who disseminated the material.

column1: “What you will see as this progresses is simply a vise closing on a group of conspirators set on destroying the first family
column2: ” said a source close to Hunter Biden.

column1: The lawsuit filed last month against Giuliani
column2: which includes Castello as a co-defendant
column3: says both men engaged in a "total annihilation" Hunter's "digital privacy." Garrett Ziegler
column4: who has also claimed to possess a copy of Hunter Biden's hard drive
column5: is accused of similar violations in a separate lawsuit for his role in publishing a trove of emails and images of Hunter Biden on the Internet.

column1: Emails and other material discovered on the laptop provide a bulk of the evidence that House Republicans cite to allege "influence-peddling" by Hunter Biden in his foreign business deals as a board member of the Ukrainian energy company Burisma. House Republicans have been unable to prove their most serious claim: that Joe Biden
column2: as vice president
column3: received bribe payments through his son to steer U.S. policy.

column1: At a initial impeachment inquiry House hearing last month
column2: Republicans' own witnesses said their lacked evidence of bribery or other impeachable offenses by Joe Bide.

column1: The laptop also contained nude photos of Hunter Biden that Republicans have seized on to embarrass the president and his son.
Ankush Khardori
column2: a former federal prosecutor
column3: said Hunter Biden's legal team is trying to "humanize" and show more complexities of a client who has been effectively "disembodied" through relentless attacks by Republicans. But he is skeptical the argument will prove effective with a privileged son of a president.

column1: This isn't someone I think most people are predisposed to feel any real pity for, he said. "I'm pretty dubious it will work."

Khardori also questioned the soundness of Hunter Biden's legal argument that Mac Isaac took unlawful possession of the laptop. Mac Isaac claims Hunter Biden signed a form stating that any equipment left at the repair shop for more than 90 days would be considered abandoned.
The lawsuit against Giuliani alleges he and Costello spent months reviewing and manipulating the data before releasing it - accusing them of violating the federal Computer Fraud and Abuse Act
column2: California’s Computer Data Access and Fraud Act and California’s Unfair Competition Law. Hunter Biden currently resides in California.

column1: Hunter Biden's attorneys also pointed to comments Giuliani made this year on his podcasts bragging about loading data from Hunter Biden's equipment onto his own computer and accessing it during the program.
Meanwhile
column2: Costello stated publicly he “scrolled through” thousands of emails
column3: bank statements and pictures
column4: which made him “feel like a voyeur
column5: ” according to the lawsuit. Costello said publicly he manipulated the data to be “cleaned up
column6: the lawsuit argues, and created new digital folders with titles such as “Salacious Pics” and “The Big Guy.

column1: The lawsuit against the IRS targets two IRS agents
column2: Gary Shapley and Joseph Ziegler
column3: who testified before Congress as federal whistleblowers and claimed they were hindered by the Justice Department during a five year investigation of Hunter Biden's business dealings.

column1: Lowell
column2: in the lawsuit
column3: argues Shapley and Joseph Ziegler revealed confidential information about Hunter Biden's taxes - including during more than 20 nationally televised interview - in an “assault” on his client's privacy that sought to embarrass him.

column1: Mr. Biden has no fewer or lesser rights than any other American citizen, and no government agency or government agent has free reign to violate his rights simply because of who he is, Lowell wrote. "Yet the IRS and its agents have conducted themselves under a presumption that the rights that apply to every other American citizen do not apply to Mr. Biden."
The lawsuit contends Biden is eligible for $1
column2: 000 in statutory damages for each unauthorized disclosure and also unspecified punitive damages.

column1: Whenever someone is attacked publicly and they feel like they've been treated unfairly, they're going to want to fight back. And so I do think part of what happened here, Renato Mariotti
column2: a former federal prosecutor now practicing at Bryan Cave Leighton Paisner LLP
column3: said of Hunter Biden's aggressive legal strategy.

column1: But he said the goal is more than just changing the public narrative about Hunter Biden.
I don't think that a strategy like this is meant primarily for PR purposes, he said
column2: arguing the larger purpose is to gather additional evidence and "put adversaries on the defensive."

column1: That strategy
column2: of course
column3: could have major political ramifications for President Joe Biden.

column1: Rather than dealing with his legal troubles quietly
column2: Hunter Biden's lawsuits and his legal team's public jabs against his Republican foes and the IRS could ensure the controversy remains in the spotlight during Joe Biden's 2024 reelection bid.

column1: I think it's apparent that Hunter Biden is focused on his own rights and his own interests, and not on his father's political career, Mariotti said
column2: "given that he's now engaging in a very aggressive attack on the prosecution and its witnesses."

column1: GOP presidential hopeful Asa Hutchinson might be trailing in 2024 polls
column2: but that hasn’t stopped the former Arkansas governor from making his case on the campaign trail.

column1: At a Republican presidential town hall in Exeter
column2: New Hampshire
column3: hosted by Seacoastonline and the USA TODAY Network last week
column4: Hutchinson outlined his platform focused on sending additional resources to the U.S. southern border
column5: addressing school shootings and quelling the opioid crisis that has ravaged communities across the country.

column1: “We have a nation that has its challenges. I’m running for president because I believe that we need new leadership
column2: ” Hutchinson told the small crowd of New Hampshire voters who gathered last Tuesday at the historic Exeter Town Hall
column3: where party-founder President Abraham Lincoln spoke months before he was elected in 1860.

column1: “We need a course correction in the Republican Party
column2: ” Hutchinson said
column3: arguing that the current frontrunner
column4: former President Donald Trump
column5: “is not the right leader” for the party or country.

column1: While Hutchinson is currently hovering around 1% in polls of Republican voters
column2: he said he hopes to reach 4% by Thanksgiving and doesn’t plan on dropping out of the race before New Hampshire’s first-in-the-nation primary.

column1: It's up to the voters of this state to determine what kind of leadership we want, the former congressman and head of the Drug Enforcement Administration said.
The New England state has a comparatively small number of delegates in the Republican presidential nomination process. But its historic status as the first primary state on the party’s calendar
column2: has made it a testing ground for White House hopefuls. Results of the state's primary can make or break campaigns.

column1: As Hutchinson jockeys for more space in the Republican presidential contest
column2: here’s a look at the issues he talked about in New Hampshire that would impact voters from coast to coast.

column1: Hutchinson described securing the U.S. southern border as “the most fundamental question and responsibility the next president will have.”

Among his first acts as president would be providing additional resources for the U.S. Border Patrol. Hutchinson also vowed to continue construction of the border wall that became a signature conservative policy during the Trump administration.
The former Arkansas governor called on leaders to streamline the processing of asylum seekers
column2: “so we’re not catching and then releasing them and expecting them to show up four years later
column3: ” referring to the practice of releasing
column4: rather than detaining
column5: migrants while they await hearings.

column1: Hutchinson suggested he would forge partnerships with southern allies
column2: particularly Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador
column3: along with governors across the country to design solutions at the border. In particular
column4: he expressed support for the 1
column5: 000-foot water barrier Texas Gov. Greg Abbott constructed in the Rio Grande earlier this year to prevent border crossings.

column1: Nearly 110
column2: 000 people died of an opioid overdose in the U.S. in 2022
column3: according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Tackling the issue is top of mind for millions of Americans
column4: especially voters in New Hampshire
column5: which is among the states with the highest rates of opioid-related deaths.

column1: Addressing voters in the Granite State
column2: Hutchinson said he’d take a three-pronged approach to thwart the epidemic by providing improving education about addiction
column3: boosting treatment options and cracking down on drug trafficking from other countries.

column1: “You’ve got to have treatment facilities that are expanded and available in our communities. That’s a joint federal and state responsibility
column2: ” he said.

column1: Once head of the DEA during former President George W. Bush's administration
column2: Hutchinson criticized candidates in the 2024 race who have called for using force against Mexico in an effort to stop the importation of fentanyl.

column1: “We don’t invade Canada because we got marijuana coming in
column2: and so we don’t invade Mexico” he asserted at the Exeter town hall. “We work with them in partnership
column3: but we have to make sure that they support the rule of law.”

column1: Fielding a question about how he would protect children from school shootings and during active shooter drills
column2: Hutchinson pushed for investing in security measures in schools and increased mental health resources for kids from coast to coast.

column1: “Today
column2: to have active shooter drills is not what we want our children to experience in life
column3: but they are adaptable
column4: ” he said
column5: noting that his generation experienced nuclear attack duck and cover drills. “The most important thing is parents need to know their children are safe when they drop them off for school
column6: so we need to invest in our school security.”

column1: However
column2: Hutchinson's comments weren't an endorsement of gun control measures
column3: and the Arkansas governor vowed that he would not take firearms away from Americans.

column1: Hutchinson also spoke more broadly about the state of schools in the U.S. Responding to a voter's question about how he would slim down the federal bureaucracy
column2: the former Arkansas governor said that
column3: if Congress passed a bill abolishing the Department of Education
column4: he would sign it to give states more authority over their school systems.

column1: He said he also believes school choice is a “matter that should be left up to the states." School choice refers to the process of using taxpayer funds to potentially send a child to a school other than their local public school.

A report published earlier this year by the Social Security Administration found that the estimated 67 million Americans who collect Social Security funds each month could see their benefits cut short by up to 25% by 2034
column2: as the ratio of retirees to workers in the U.S. increases.

column1: When asked about his plans to tackle the problem and keep social security solvent
column2: Hutchinson said he’d employ a strategy used by former President Ronald Reagan
column3: relying on a commission to investigate and make recommendations to Congress on how to finance Medicare and Social Security for the future.

column1: “There are a lot of ideas out there
column2: all of those ideas will be on the table
column3: ” he said.

column1: But Hutchinson didn't suggest shrinking the program. For example
column2: he said
column3: if elected president
column4: he would remove penalties for people ages 62 to 66 who are in the workforce and earn more than $21
column6: but want to take Social Security benefits.

column1: Republican presidential candidate Vivek Ramaswamy emphasized his status as a political outsider in the 2024 race for the White House during a New Hampshire town hall sponsored by the USA TODAY Network and Seacoastonline last week.
“I think we live in a moment where it will take an outsider
column2: someone who comes from the outside
column3: really someone who comes from the next generation to reach the next generation
column4: ” Ramaswamy
column6: said Saturday at the historic Exeter Town Hall in Exeter
column7: New Hampshire.

column1: But the youngest presidential candidate also took the USA TODAY Network behind the scenes
column2: sharing his day-to-day habits on the campaign trail. Here's a closer look at Ramaswamy's favorite books
column3: soundtracks and other picks.

column1: These days
column2: Ramaswamy said he’s mostly reading policy papers and making sure he's caught up on the day's news. But he and his wife
column3: Dr. Apoorva Ramaswamy
column4: have been reading “G-Man: J. Edgar Hoover and the Making of the American Century
column5: ” a book about former FBI director J. Edgar Hoover.

column1: “Very fascinating read
column2: ” Ramaswamy said. “It gives me a perspective on some of the issues we're talking about in the present
column3: but how they date back decades into our country's history. So that's a half decent book that I'd recommend.”

column1: Ramaswamy noted he's traveling with his two kids
column2: a three and a half year old and a one year old
column3: on the campaign trail.

column1: “A lot of the soundtrack from 'Cars 2' and 'Monsters Inc.' Those have been
column2: I would say
column3: all the rage in the family recently
column4: ” Ramaswamy said.

column1: Ramaswamy said watching football on Sundays is the closest he gets to watching a guilty pleasure TV show.
“Late night
column2: if I'm getting home and it's like 9:30 p.m. on a rarity
column3: I'll go to sleep
column4: catch up on some sleep
column5: get up early the next morning
column6: get a workout in
column7: ” Ramaswamy said.

column1: “That's where my focus has been. But a little bit of football season after the end of tennis season has been good for me in decompressing.”
When asked how he would help young Americans across the country
column2: Ramaswamy told USA TODAY that one of the things a president has to do is grow the economy for all.

column1: “Young Americans have not enjoyed economic mobility for a long time
column2: and that's why many young people are disaffected from politics and from the government
column3: ” Ramaswamy said. “I get that.”

column1: Part of addressing these frustrations is to lower inflation and bring down other costs
column2: he said.

column1: “What do we do to accomplish that? Unlock American energy
column2: ” Ramaswamy said. “That's the number one driver of inflation as high energy costs. That's also how we grow our economy. Reforming the Federal Reserve is also key.”

column1: He also said he wants to help provide multiple paths to success for young people.
“The only path to the American Dream can't just be four year college degrees and standard expensive college debt laden paths to get ahead in this country
column2: ” Ramaswamy said. “There have to be multiple paths to success
column3: including even one or two year vocational education
column4: building skills in the trades.”

column1: WASHINGTON — Former President Donald Trump continued to walk back his previous criticism of Israel
column2: telling Iowa voters on Monday that he has always supported the longtime ally now engaged in a war with Hamas.

column1: We stand with Israel, Trump said during a rally encouraging supporters to attend the Jan. 15 Iowa caucuses that kick off the Republican presidential nomination.
Trump was also more a little more reticent about the indictments and four criminal cases against him
column2: hours after a federal judge issued a limited gag order on the former president and 2024 Republican presidential candidate.

column1: Claiming the gag order
column2: which only applies to the federal charges alleging he tried to steal the 2020 election
column3: is unconstitutional
column4: Trump said: "we'll appeal it and we'll see."

column1: In a second speech
column2: ostensibly devoted to national security
column3: Trump vowed to press on with his presidential campaign and added: "I am willing to go to jail if that's what it takes for our country to win and become a democracy again.”

column1: Trump's two appearances in Iowa on Monday were his first speeches since his criticism of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu - and compliments of Hezbollah - drew counterattacks from his Republican primary opponents.
Speaking before supporters last week in West Palm Beach
column2: Fla.
column3: Trump attacked Netanyahu for refusing to participate in the 2020 targeted killing of an Iranian general.

column1: Trump also criticized unnamed Israeli officials for discussing the possibility of attacks from Hezbollah
column2: saying those comments might tip off the militant group to the county's vulnerabilities. He added: "You know
column3: Hezbollah is very smart ... They’re all very smart.”

column1: Trump additionally criticized Netanyahu in an interview with Fox News Radio over the Hamas attack. "He was not prepared
column2: Trump said. He was not prepared and Israel was not prepared."

column1: During his Iowa appearances
column2: Trump did not mention Netanyahu and Hezbollah. He focused instead on Iran and President Joe Biden
column3: blaming both for the outbreak of more violence in the region earlier this month.

column1: Trump first sought to clean up the damage with social media posts and written statements over the weekend. In a Truth Social post
column2: Trump included the hashtags #IStandWithIsrael” and “#IStandWithBibi."

column1: Trump's opponents for the Republican presidential nomination have spent days denouncing his comments on Israel
column2: saying they undermined an ally in the midst of a crisis and could embolden Iran.

column1: “He’s a fool
column2: said former New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie. Only a fool would make those kinds of comments. Only a fool would give comments that could give aid and comfort to Israel’s adversary.”

column1: Former South Carolina governor - and United Nations ambassador - Nikki Haley said Trump's comments underscore that he is out of touch. "It's why I continue to say it is time for a new
column2: generational leader
column3: Haley said on CNN's State of the Union."

column1: Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis
column2: speaking on Fox News
column3: said Trump seems to have a personal beef with Netanyahu because the Israeli prime minister called Biden to congratulate him on winning the 2020 election
column4: despite Trump's protests about the race.

column1: Saying that "attacking Bibi was a huge mistake" from Trump
column2: DeSantis argued that it was "personal for him to come out and take shots at Bibi just days after Israel had suffered the worst terrorist attack in its history."

column1: Trump enjoys big leads in state and national polls
column2: including ones conducted in Iowa and New Hampshire.

column1: In both speeches on Monday
column2: Trump again criticized his criminal prosecutions and civil trials
column3: though he held off on specifying Justice Department prosecutor Jack Smith and U.S. District Judge Tanya Chutkan.

column1: Hours earlier
column2: Chutkan issued a gag order that puts limits on what Trump can say about prosecutors
column3: witnesses
column4: and court personnel. The judge said Trump did not have the right to use his campaign to mount a "smear campaign" against legal officials.

column1: While Trump did not single out individuals
column2: he did claim that "they've weaponized the Justice Department and the FBI
column3:
and he protested the new order. This order does not apply to the charges he faces in Georgia over allegations he tried to steal the election in the Peach State.
I'll be the only politician in history that runs with a gag order where I'm not allowed to criticize people
column4:
Trump said during his first speech in Adel, Iowa.
In his second set of remarks, in Clive, Trump did not mention Chutkan by name, but said: The judge doesn't like me too much."

column1: At a moment when banks are slashing overdraft fees and President Biden is vowing a crackdown on hidden “junk” fees
column2: the dreaded ATM surcharge has never been higher.

column1: Americans who use an “out-of-network” ATM pay $4.73 in fees
column2: on average
column3: according to a study by the personal finance site Bankrate.

column1: As other routine banking charges trend downward
column2: ATM fees are creeping up. The average cash-machine customer paid $1.97 for the service in 1998
column3: Bankrate reports. The average rose to $3.74 in 2010 and $4.52 in 2015.

The annual Bankrate survey draws on data from banks and thrifts in 25 large U.S. markets.

column1: Many large banks voluntarily reduced or eliminated overdraft fees in 2021 and 2022

column1: The average overdraft fee peaked at $33.58 in 2021

column1: Those $30 and $35 fees were hard for banks to justify

column1: The Biden administration also warned banks not to charge fees for basic services

column1: No account holder likes ATM fees. But customers may find it tricky to assign blame.

column1: The second fee comes from your own bank

column1: Customers might not be aware of the second fee
column2: unless they pay close attention to their transaction records. The out-of-network fee isn’t likely to appear on an ATM screen.

column1: Choice Hotels International on Tuesday said it has offered to buy rival chain Wyndham Hotels & Resorts for nearly $8 billion.

column2: a deal valued at roughly $7.8 billion
column3: or $9.8 billion when including debt. The proposal is a 30% premium to Wyndham's latest closing price.

column1:
We have long respected Wyndham's business and are confident that this combination would significantly accelerate both Choice's and Wyndham's long-term organic growth strategy for the benefit of all stakeholders,” Choice President and CEO Patrick Pacious said in a statement.
A statement from Wyndham said it rejected the offer after determining that it was not in the best interest of shareholders."

Choice's offer is underwhelming, highly conditional, and subject to significant business, regulatory and execution risk, Wyndham Board of Directors Chairman Stephen Holmes said. "Choice has been unwilling or unable to address our concerns."

But New Jersey-based Wyndham questioned Choice’s stock value and the timing for obtaining regulatory approvals, and pulled out of discussions, according to Choice’s statement.

column1: A proposed ruling filed from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration could mean bans on some chemical hair-smoothing and straightening products that have been linked to cancer.
The FDA has proposed a rule banning formaldehyde and other formaldehyde-releasing chemicals from being used in hair-smoothing and straightening products sold in the U.S.
The use of such chemicals has been linked to long-term health concerns
column2: including an increased risk of cancer
column3: according to the FDA. They can also cause short-term health risks
column4: including sensitization reactions and breathing problems
column5: the agency says.

column1: Before an FDA proposal can become an official rule
column2: the agency takes comments from the public and then may "decide to end the rulemaking process
column3: to issue a new proposed rule
column4: or to issue a final rule
column5:
the agency's site says.
Maternity units closing in Alabama:Pregnant women have to travel further for care
A 2019 study published in the International Journal of Cancer linked hair dye and chemical straightener use to a risk of breast cancer in women in the U.S.
The link was further solidified in 2022, when the National Institutes of Health published a study that found women who used hair-straightening chemicals were associated with a higher uterine cancer risk, and that Black women may be more affected due to a higher use.
There has also been Congressional pressure to look into the link between chemical straighteners and cancer. In March 2023, Rep. Ayanna Pressley (D-Massachusetts) and Rep. Shontel Brown (D-Ohio) wrote a letter to FDA Commissioner Robert Califf asking the agency conduct an investigation into the matter.
We urge the FDA to investigate the potential health threat posed by chemical hair straightening products
column6: the letter reads. Consumers need to be reassured that the cosmetic products they use do not threaten their health. It is critical that the agency act quickly to address these legitimate concerns."

column1: In a news release following the FDA's proposed new rule
column2: Pressley called it "a win for public health — especially the health of Black women who are disproportionately put at risk by these products as a result of systemic racism and anti-Black hair sentiment

column1: The power comes on with smooth precision

with speeds up to 45 mph when leaving home or driving through the neighborhood.
The electric motor also extends the V8’s four-cylinder operating mode on the highway, reducing fuel consumption and emissions. The 655-hp E-Ray avoided the gas-guzzler tax, scoring the same 19 mpg EPA rating in combined city and highway driving as a 490-hp, gasoline-only Stingray.
The E-Ray’s weight distribution is 42% over the front axle, 58% over the rear, a couple of percentage points more over the nose than the base ‘Vette, but “still in the sweet spot’” for acceleration and handling, Juechter said.
The interior is luxuriously trimmed in leather, suede and carbon fiber. The touch screen includes performance displays.

For a lot of amateur or busy family chefs, chicken is an easy go-to dinner option. Tacos, enchiladas, chicken noodle soup, or even a salad, chicken is a classic centerpiece to a quality meal. 
Once you have decided on your choice of meal (which is the hardest part), it is time to prepare your chicken. Not only is boiling chicken faster and easier than roasting or grilling it, but it is also a safer way to ensure your chicken will be juicy without drying out, according to Better Homes & Garden. 
Regardless if you have boned or boneless chicken, here is how long it takes to boil it to perfection.
Ideally, the chicken will be done once it has reached 165 degrees Fahrenheit, according to the U.S. Food Safety and Inspection Service. However, here are a few timing guidelines you can follow if you are unsure, based on chicken type.
Need a side dish?:Add this 'healthiest' vegetable into your diet
It is advised that you thaw the chicken first before boiling it frozen. If able, leave the chicken in a fridge for at least nine hours. 
If unable, the U.S. Food Safety and Inspection Service recommends boiling frozen chicken 50% longer in time than already thawed chicken. 
Cook for about 30 minutes, or 45 minutes if frozen, according to Better Homes & Garden.
Cook for about 12 to 15 minutes, or 18 to 22 minutes if frozen, according to Better Homes & Garden.
Step 1: Select a liquid
Based on your overall meal, you can boil your chicken in a variety of ways. Whether you want to boil in water or something more flavorful like chicken broth, there is no wrong answer as long as you have a liquid in the pot.
Step 2: Season up
Place your chicken in a large pot with a tight-fitting lid that has enough liquid to cover the chicken. Add any additional seasonings, such as salt and pepper. This is a good time to add any vegetables or fresh herbs that you want to be included because the boiling water can really bring those savory flavors out, Delish reports. 
Step 3: Begin to boil
After the chicken is covered up in your chosen liquid and additional flavors, bring your water to a boil. Cover the pot with your tight-fitting lid, slightly lowering the heat once the water is boiling.
Leave your chicken to simmer in the pot until the internal temperature is 165 degrees Fahrenheit (this can be checked with a meat thermometer). If your chicken seems to need more time, check every 5 minutes and avoid overcooking so the chicken doesn’t become rubbery, according to Delish. 
Hungry for more?:How to grill chicken breast safely
