column2: anger and
column3: most of all
column4: a profound sense of helplessness after an act so horrific and brutal that we never could have imagined it.

column1: Hell began for us when my wife and I called my brother
column2: Yair Yaakov
column3: during the first round of missile attacks the morning of Oct. 7
column4: to check in on him; his girlfriend
column5: Meirav Tal; and my two nephews
column6: who are 16 and 12. They live in Nir Oz
column7: a kibbutz in southern Israel
column8: near the Gaza border.

column1: My brother reassured my wife that they were in their shelter/safe room. His two sons were staying at their mother’s house
column2: and my brother
column3: no matter how much he may have wished he could race to the rest of his family and bring them all together to protect them
column4: couldn’t leave the safe room in his house at the kibbutz.

column1: We survived the Hamas attack on Israel.What haunts us now is the blockade of Gaza.
They were strictly instructed to stay in place
column2: and they heard gunshots outside the house. Everyone was frozen as they faced the approaching fear and horror of Hamas terrorists closing in.

column1: About a half hour later
column2: Meirav sent us an audio message on WhatsApp. Her voice was shaking as she told us that terrorists had entered their home. Yair held the shelter’s door to keep the attackers out. But in the end
column3: he did not prevail. This was the last time we had contact with them.

column1: Our family was thrown into darkness. We searched every minute of that day for any sign of them. We tried using Apple’s “Find my iPhone” feature to no avail. We fought fear and panic all day to remain focused on locating our family.
Later that afternoon
column2: the mother of my nephews shared with us through tears that she had confirmation that her two sons had been kidnapped. Our world collapsed around us.

column1: For nearly 30 agonizing hours
column2: we had no idea where any of them were. We reached out to every level of every authority we could
column3: asking for help in finding Yair
column4: Meirav and my nephews. The silence that returned became overwhelming as we learned that we were going to face this nightmare primarily on our own. We turned to social media
column5: sharing pictures and heartfelt pleas
column6: hoping someone in our connected web would come forward with information.

column1: Then we learned the fate of my family when a friend of Yair shared a video showing that Hamas had taken them hostage. It showed the terrifying moments of Yair and Meirav's abduction after Hamas terrorists threw grenades to break the safe room’s door.
This wasn't just a crime; it was an inversion of humanity. Innocent people
column2: including children and women
column3: were forcibly taken from their homes where they should feel safe and torn away from their lives
column4: their families and their communities. They are now pawns in a war.

column1: 'Take a lesson from the dead':Fatal stabbing of 6-year-old in Illinois serves as warning to divided US
The days since have been dark with just one glimmer of light. Yair's oldest daughter and her boyfriend
column2: who were staying in yet another house in the kibbutz
column3: managed to keep their shelter secure and were eventually rescued by the Israel Defense Forces.

column1: As a family
column2: we appeal to the world for one thing: the safe return of our loved ones. We were brought up to believe that everyone has a family and deserves to be treated humanely. Hamas operates in stark contrast to these principles.

column1: Our only plea is to bring our kidnapped family members back home safely. We don’t know if they are being fed. We don’t know the state of their health. We don’t know where they are. The uncertainty about their fate is what our lives are defined by now
column2: and we are desperate for the day that we can receive good news about their well-being.

column1: Until then
column2: I am a brother and an uncle who refuses to give up.

column1: Yaniv Yaakov works in information technology in Israel.
This time
column2: I almost gave up the hope that one day
column3: people will see the humanity in Palestinians
column4: my people. See the humanity in me.

column1: As if the number of innocent civilians killed in the latest war between Israel and Hamas hasn’t been horrifying enough
column2: the count continues to rise.

column1: The sheer number of bombs Israel dropped in five days is more than the United States dropped in Afghanistan in a year after 9/11
column2: The Washington Post reported.

column1: Condemnation of the killing of innocent Palestinian and Israeli civilians should be easy to come by
column2: yet I watch in frustration as Palestinians are dehumanized
column3: as if their lives are less valuable.

column1: I’ve felt this frustration before – too many times. The pain of feeling less than human is never less gut-wrenching. I feel this rage and sadness
column2: but I harness that. It drives what I do
column3: who I am.

column1: And instead of waiting for people to see Palestinians as humans
column2: I have the power to show them. As journalists
column3: we have a duty to expose injustice
column4: to think critically. To show humanity.

column1: As a woman living in diaspora
column2: I watch events in the Palestinian territories from afar while my family there lives through it.

column1: March 30
column3: marked the beginning of the monthslong Great March of Return
column4: when tens of thousands of Palestinians came together to protest across Gaza
column5: the West Bank and within Israel’s borders.

column1: They demanded the end of Israel’s blockade of the Gaza Strip
column2: the end of its now 75-year brutal military occupation that human rights groups have described as apartheid
column3: and the return of the 750
column4: 000 Palestinians expelled from their homes to make way for the creation of Israel in 1948.

column1: Today
column2: there are an estimated 6 million Palestinian refugees.

column1: I did what I always do when Palestinians dare demand their right to live freely: I checked on my family in the West Bank to make sure they were safe.
And then
column2: my stomach already in knots
column3: I braced myself for what was to come.

column1: Israel responded to these protests in 2018 by using live ammunition on peaceful protesters
column2: the United Nations reported
column3: sniping down women
column4: children
column5: journalists and medics
column6: along with tear gas
column7: rubber bullets
column8: drones; 214 Palestinians were killed
column9: 46 of them children. More than 36
column12: 800 children. One in 5 were injured by live ammunition.

column1: Watching these events unfold in horror and devastation
column2: I remember thinking to myself
column3: maybe this time the world will get it. Palestinians just want to live. We want to be regarded as human. And even when protesting peacefully
column4: Palestinians still pay the price in blood.

column1: Looking back
column2: I realize I was naive.

column1: Overwhelmed by the war in Israel?Here's how to protect your mental health.
Just a few months earlier
column2: 17-year-old Ahed Tamimi was sentenced to eight months in Israeli prison for slapping Israeli soldiers. She was protesting the expansion of Israeli settlements – illegal under international law – near her village
column3: Nabi Saleh. Her cousin
column4: 15 at the time
column5: was injured after an Israeli soldier shot him in the head with a rubber bullet at close range.

column1: I feel such frustration that a child was imprisoned for eight months
column2: in a country the United States supports and in which there is little challenge to these practices and policies by the news media
column3: the Israeli government or our own government.

column2: thousands of Palestinians across the region again erupted in peaceful protest against the expulsion of eight Palestinian families from Sheikh Jarrah
column3: a neighborhood in East Jerusalem. Tensions were already high following an Israeli police raid on worshippers praying during the holy Muslim month of Ramadan at Al-Aqsa Mosque
column4: one of Islam’s holiest sites. (The image of Palestinians beaten by Israeli forces has been juxtaposed with images of the soldiers protecting Israelis as they marched chanting “death to Arabs” during that same time.)

column1: More than 2 million Palestinians are trapped in Gaza under a 16-year Israeli siege
column2: now subjected to repeated bombings described by the U.N. as collective punishment.

column1: After the Sheikh Jarrah protests two years ago
column2: I remember thinking to myself
column3: in deep pain and frustration: Maybe people will see the daily realities that Palestinians live through – like forced expulsions
column4: even Israeli settlers taking over Palestinian homes while Palestinians still live in them
column5: and boasting about it in the media.

column1: Last year
column2: when prominent veteran Palestinian American journalist Shireen Abu Akleh was shot and killed – likely by an Israeli sniper while covering the near-daily raids and killings of Palestinians – maybe
column3: I thought
column4: the image of those carrying Abu Akleh in a casket
column5: almost dropping it as Israeli police beat them
column6: would be enough for people to understand what Palestinians live through.

column1: Or even now
column2: maybe the news of entire neighborhoods
column3: entire families
column4: obliterated by Israel’s bombs in the latest war between Israel and Hamas – and now Israel’s order for the forced evacuation of more than a million people from northern Gaza
column5: which the U.N. calls an impending humanitarian crisis – would be enough to show people just how unequal this war really is.

column1: Maybe the 6
column2: 000 Israeli bombs that have hit Gaza since Oct. 7 would be enough to remind people that Israel occupies Palestinian territories
column3: subjecting them to violent oppression for the last 75 years.

column1: Or maybe the Israeli minster of defense calling Palestinians “human animals” when he ordered “complete siege” on the 2 million people of Gaza – cutting off water
column2: electricity
column3: fuel and food as hospitals are bombed and on the verge of collapse – would spark some sympathy.

column1: 'Take a lesson from the dead':Fatal stabbing of 6-year-old serves warning to divided US
It can feel lonely and empty to see others disregard your humanity. To paint your people with the broad brush of terrorism.
I’ve witnessed my mother strip-searched and thrown in an Israeli detention cell for trying to visit the country she was born in
column2: told never to fly through Ben Gurion airport again
column3: simply because she is Palestinian.

column1: I’ve seen the separation wall. I’ve heard the gunfire. I’ve driven segregated roads.
I’ve seen Palestinian homes bulldozed in East Jerusalem
column2: settlements built right in the middle of Palestinian neighborhoods
column3: settlements that continue to expand
column4: surrounding my family’s villages in the West Bank.

column1: It’s injustice that I cannot unsee
column2: I cannot unlive.

column1: But Palestinians are strong
column2: they are resilient. Both our strength and our suffering reminds me of why I’m a journalist. Because I’ve seen firsthand the oppression that Palestinians face
column3: and I’ve lived it during every visit home. Interrogation by Israeli soldiers
column4: and at military checkpoints
column5: guns pointed at me by Israeli soldiers.

column1: Palestinians protest even though they know that they can die
column2: and they do it because they have no other choice. It's their freedom they're protesting for.

column1: I have faith that journalists will find the bravery
column2: as Palestinian journalists have
column3: leading the way for humanity to be acknowledged – to ask these questions and think critically and demand that Palestinians be seen as worthy.

column1: To see our humanity
column2: our right to self-determination.

column1: Our right to simply live.
Andrea May Sahouri is a staff writer at the Detroit Free Press
column2: where this column was originally published.

column1: I realize this may be asking a lot
column2: but wouldn’t it be great if so many of our politicians weren’t unscrupulous creeps?

column1: These days
column2: after scanning the headlines about the folks “running” the government
column3: I often feel like I need a shower.

column1: It seems like an almost daily occurrence that a current or former elected official lands in court for one shady misdeed or another. Government corruption almost seems normal.
It shouldn’t be.
Between the alarming attack on Israel this month and the Republicans bungling their House leadership
column2: some of the latest scandals have gotten the amount of attention they deserve.

column1: Republicans fiddle while world burns:Listen up
column2: Republicans. The world is in chaos
column3: so why are you playing stupid games?

column1: Let me refresh you on what’s been happening.
The charges keep coming for Sen. Bob Menendez
column2: a Democrat from New Jersey. A career politician to his core
column3: Menendez has spent decades in Congress
column4: between his time in the House and now the Senate.

column1: His seniority earned him the powerful position of chair of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column2: which he is now charged with abusing for his personal gain. Menendez had to step down from that role while his case plays out
column3: but he doesn’t appear to be leaving office anytime soon – at least of his own accord.

column1: Last week
column2: Menendez was slapped with additional charges of conspiracy to act as a foreign agent. That is on top of last month's indictment on bribery charges.

column1: Stop and think about that: The (now former) chair of Foreign Relations
column2: a committee that reviews treaties with other nations and votes on all diplomatic nominations
column3: is accused of acting as a foreign agent for hire.

column1: Harvard for Hamas?Something is very twisted on America's university campuses.

What he’s accused of is extremely serious. Menendez – along with his wife – is charged in part with benefiting the Egyptian government as well as several businessmen in exchange for hundreds of thousands in gold bars and cash. Some of the loot was found at his home – hidden in closets and clothes
column2: which doesn’t seem suspicious at all.

column1: And for good measure
column2: throw in a Mercedes convertible worth more than $60
column4: which prosecutors say business executives purchased for the senator and his wife in exchange for Menendez interfering in an insurance fraud case.

column1: It's not the first time Menendez has had a run-in with the law involving bribery charges. In 2017
column2: a federal jury deadlocked on whether to convict the senator
column3: which led to a mistrial.

column1: See a pattern here?
Menendez
column2: according to historians
column3: may be the first sitting senator in U.S. history to have been indicted in two different criminal cases
column4: a distinction no one should strive for.

column1: Now
column2: if you’re a liberal
column3: I can bet what you’re thinking: “Well
column4: look at former President Donald Trump!” or “How about Rep. George Santos?”

column1: Trump has been indicted in four criminal cases
column2: as well as a civil fraud case
column3: all of which are unprecedented for a former president (who also is
column4: of course
column5: the leading Republican candidate for president in 2024).

column1: Time for change:Sure
column2: Trump is awful. But that doesn't mean Biden is a good choice for president.

column1: Then there's curious George. Last week
column2: a new indictment alleges Santos stole the identities of campaign donors and used donors’ credit cards as his own personal piggy bank. That comes five months after he was charged with other financial crimes.

column1: It’s really no wonder that his campaign coffers are in arrears.
There’s also the fact that Santos made up his entire résumé. He’s a first-class sleazebag.
Yet
column2: unlike Menendez
column3: Santos is a freshman congressman
column4: one who is unlikely to make it to his sophomore term (assuming voters are paying attention).

column1: Menendez had a position of leadership and real power
column2: and Democrats kept promoting him despite earlier warning signs. What Menendez is accused of doing deserves to be scrutinized on its own accord.

column1: Bribing for access:Menendez indictment raises questions about Hunter Biden case – and DOJ
The question remains: What to do with these bad actors?
It’s easy for Democrats to scream and yell that Santos is a disgrace and must go. And Republicans like to do the same to Democrats. For instance
column2: Republicans have called for Rep. Jamaal Bowman
column3: a Democrat from New York
column4: to be expelled from the House after he pulled a fire alarm before a key vote to keep the government open. Bowman says it was a "mistake
column5: and his office released a memo in his defense that labeled Republicans as Nazis."

column1: Regardless
column2: it’s an odd “mistake” for a former school principal to make and a bizarre incident
column3: even if it doesn’t rise to the level of expulsion. But I digress.

column1: The bar for expelling a House member is high
column2: and it has only happened a few times in our country’s history. Of the 15 times the Senate has expelled a member
column3: 14 occurred during the Civil War for supporting the Confederacy.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: partisanship often comes before principle. The fact remains that with thin margins of control in the House and Senate
column3: both sides need as many warm bodies as they can get
column4: regardless of how repugnant.

column1: Some New York Republicans have called for the House to expel Santos
column2: although that’s not likely to happen. The same goes for the Senate. Quite a few Democrats have called on Menendez to resign
column3: but they’re not likely to take the matter further.

column1: At the least
column2: Menendez and Santos could be censured by their colleagues and face that embarrassment.

column1: These men deserve their day in court
column2: but I'm less certain they should be roaming the halls of Congress.

column1: The surest way to rid the government of (alleged) weasels is for voters to make sure they don’t get the chance again.
Ingrid Jacques is a columnist at USA TODAY. You can contact her at ijacques@usatoday.com or on X
column2: formerly Twitter: @Ingrid_Jacques

column1: Great news
column2: America. Criminal defendant and leading GOP presidential primary candidate Donald Trump has something new to whine about – a partial gag order placed on him by the federal judge in his election interference case.

column1: If you thought Trump’s yearslong journey to become the sorest of sore losers by ceaselessly braying about the 2020 presidential election he lost was growing tiresome
column2: just you wait. Monday’s order provides fresh fodder for his persecution cannon
column3: which I’m sure will be red hot from firing as the former president processes the fact that he
column4: like anyone facing criminal charges
column5: can’t freely intimidate witnesses
column6: prosecutors or court personnel.

column1: In issuing the order
column2: U.S. District Judge Tanya Chutkan said: “Mr. Trump can certainly claim he’s being unfairly prosecuted
column3: but I cannot imagine any other case where a defendant is allowed to call the prosecution ‘deranged
column4: ’ a ‘thug’ or anything else.”

column1: She added: “His political campaign does not give him carte blanche to vilify public servants for simply doing their job.”

Setting aside the remarkable fact that a federal judge sees credible concerns that the far-and-away front-runner for the Republican Party’s presidential nomination is attempting to intimidate witnesses and prosecutors in his own criminal case
column2: consider the way we’d expect Trump to respond to Chutkan’s decision.

column1: Something along the lines of: “A CRAZY RADICAL LEFTIST MARXIST TRUMP-HATING ‘JUDGE’ has now totally violated my CONSTITUTIONAL rights by issuing a ‘gag order’ on me in what everyone knows is ELECTION INTERFERENCE led by Crazy Joe Biden and his boss
column2: Barack HUSSEIN Obama. FIGHT BACK!”

column1: I made that all up
column2: but would you be surprised if Trump wrote something similar? And if you wouldn't be surprised
column3: doesn't that suggest we're facing a serious problem?

column1: Immediately after the ruling
column2: Trump posted on Truth Social: "A TERRIBLE THING HAPPENED TO DEMOCRACY TODAY – GAG ORDER!" and "WILL APPEAL THE GAG ORDER RULING. WITCH HUNT!"

column1: There's little doubt the angry rants will get worse.
Be honest Republican voters.Is Trump really what you want?
Prior to the gag order
column2: Trump had labeled special counsel Jack Smith “a crackhead” and called him “psycho.”

column1: In August
column2: Trump posted what prosecutors viewed as a threat against witnesses
column3: writing: “IF YOU GO AFTER ME
column4: I’M COMING AFTER YOU!”

column1: And in a Sept. 22 post on Truth Social
column2: Trump accused retired Gen. Mark Milley
column3: a former chair of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and now a witness in the election interference case
column4: of treason and suggested that he should be executed.

column1: Prosecutors
column2: in their filing requesting a gag order
column3: wrote that “no other criminal defendant would be permitted to issue public statements insinuating that a known witness in his case should be executed; this defendant should not be
column4: either.”

column1: Judge muzzles Trump:McCarthy booted from House speaker
column2: Trump gagged. The Republican Party is an unserious mess.

column1: Trump will squeal desperately and claim his free-speech rights are being trampled
column2: but even a low-functioning mollusk would know that’s nonsense.

column1: Trump was president
column2: true. He isn’t anymore.

column1: Trump is running for president
column2: true. But that doesn’t give him the freedom to say whatever the hell he wants about people involved in the multiple criminal cases in which he faces 91 state and federal felony charges.

column1: I’m not above the law
column2: you’re not above the law and Trump
column3: sad as it may be for him to learn
column4: is not above the law.

column1: But at least now he has some new material to work with. When your very essence is defined by aggrievement
column2: a legal setback provides fresh paint for your victimhood self-portrait.

column1: Let’s see how long it takes the whiner in chief to violate the judge’s gag order. I’m guessing it comes in 3
Follow USA TODAY columnist Rex Huppke on X
column2: formerly Twitter
column3: @RexHuppke and Facebook facebook.com/RexIsAJerk

column1: Rabbi Igael Gurin-Malous grew up in an Orthodox home
column2: spending time in Belgium
column3: Israel and the United States. Today
column4: he's a gay
column5: tattooed
column6: non-denominational rabbi living in New York.

column1: Most of the people he went to Jewish boys school with are right-wing. This week
column2: those same peers bullied him in group chats. They called him a Hebrew word meaning a traitor to the other side. Because he "dared to" suggest that Israel's current military response in Gaza "is not the only way to to address the (Israeli-Palestinian conflict)."

column1: His situation resembles many across the U.S. and rest of the world as people grapple with differing opinions among friends
column2: family and colleagues; A college group text devolving because no one can agree. Millennials walking on eggshells for fear of upsetting their Gen Z partners.

column1: There's no one way to approach sensitive issues of this nature. But experts say those aiming to preserve relationships fractured by the war between Israel and Hamas should tread lightly.
Reactions like rage and heartbreak are normal, says Kimberly Vered Shashoua
column2: a licensed clinical social worker. "If you’re feeling too overwhelmed with your own emotions
column3: that’s OK. Just let your partner or loved ones know you need some time or space before you are up for having deep conversations."

column1: Emotions have been running high since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7; 4
column2: 200 have died on both sides
column3: according to the United Nations.

column1: It's creating these distances that people feel unseen, unheard, vilified, Gurin-Malous says.

Many have expressed their fears and frustrations on social media in an effort to empathize and seek personal connections to tragedies in lieu of or in addition to private conversations. Maybe to alleviate guilt
column2: to feel like they're doing something
column3: to "perform" uneducated solidarity.

column1: These posts often go awry when people play the comparison game. "The problem is not the desire to find a personal connection
column2: says Benjamin Goldman, licensed mental health counselor. The problem is when conversations become about comparing degrees of suffering and pain. And during this time that we're in right now
column3: there's a lot of data and a lot of real information." Anyone can throw statistics at a situation to try and justify their points. But many aren't really looking for meaningful conversation

column1: Aziz Abu-Sarah's octogenarian parents live in Jerusalem. He visited them there three weeks ago. Now
column2: he's afraid for their safety. A Palestinian peacemaker
column3: his Israeli and Palestinian friends have been asking him how to broker dialogue.

column1: My advice was this: refrain (from) political discussions, he says. "Don't talk heavy politics right now. You always do
column2: you will eventually
column3: but now
column4: maybe is not the time to start going into what happened 100 years ago and 50 years ago. This is just the wrong time for that."

column1: Before engaging with someone on as sensitive a topic as the Israeli-Palestinian conflict
column2: consider who you are talking to (i.e. where do they fall on the issue) and have a goal in mind. Are you looking to vent? For a dialogue? To change their mind?

column1: Because "if you're looking for a conversation that takes place in a shared experience in pain
column2: and then you go to someone with a conflicting experience from you to have that conversation
column3: you will be hurt
column4: Goldman says. And they will also probably be hurt." That said
column5: "if you must share information that you feel very strongly about
column6: it’s best to adopt a non-confrontational attitude – even if you believe you are right
column7:
says Cecille Ahrens, a licensed clinical social worker.
It may also be worth some introspection. We would be wise to remember that we are each a product of our own lived experience steeped in the culture that surrounds us
column8: says Laura Petiford, a licensed marriage and family therapist. Additionally
column9: we are influenced by the media's synthesis of information and the mediums we trust to deliver it to our screens and inboxes."

column1: Focus less on politics and more on the personal if you're aiming for a productive conversation. "Try and connect from a human perspective on fear and isolation
column2: and not being seen
column3: and all the other emotions that we all feel whenever there is war
column4:
Gurin-Malous says.
Abu-Sarah adds: Being vulnerable for each other and being willing to listen
column5: instead of being quick to fight and argue – this is true in all situations."

column1: He suggests focusing less on your position at the start of a dialogue and more on your story: "Before we start taking positions: 'Here why I stand (for Israel's) right to defend itself; here's why I stand for Palestinians' right to end occupation.' Before you say
column2: your position
column3: tell your story. It's more important."

column1: Consider
column2: too
column3: "is there any common ground from which you can start?" asks Regine Galanti
column4: a clinical psychologist. "Can you agree that all civilian deaths are terrible and tragic? That it's not OK to kidnap women and children? That it's terrible for people not to have access to basic utilities? Again
column5: if you have no common ground
column6: it might not be a conversation worth having right now."

column1: You are also allowed to hit pause if you're not ready to talk just yet. "It's OK to avoid conversations with friends or family if you're not  emotionally in the right place for these disagreements
column2: Galanti adds. I've been muting a lot of my Instagram stories – even of people that I agree with – because I go to Instagram to unwind
column3: and the constant barrage of videos on the Israeli-Gaza conflict make me anxious instead."

column1: Watch out:Israel
column2: Gaza and when your social media posts hurt more than help

column1: Some relationships may not survive disagreements of this nature. And that is OK
column2: too.

column1: For Gurin-Malous
column2: some wounds won't scar. They'll sit as open wounds.

column1: Some of the damage that has been done to me, and some of the relationships that I have around this, I think are irreparable, he says. "You can't unsay things you've said. And with that
column2: I also want to allow for the fact that this is a very hot button (issue) for everybody involved." Still
column3: "I want to also bring some compassion to the fact that sometimes we say things that we don't mean. And sometimes we out of fear lash out. And it is unfortunate
column4: I think that many
column5: many times
column6: we reserve our worst behavior for the people we love the most."

column1: Remember
column2: as Abu-Sarah says: "Behind every angry statement
column3: behind every talking point we throw at each other
column4: there's a hurt person."

column1: In case you missed:The videos out of Israel
column2: Gaza are graphic
column3: but some can't look away: How to cope

column1: We always want what we don’t have
column2: whether it’s a different hair color or longer lashes. Now
column3: in what appears to be the rebirth of a beauty trend with a storied history
column4: people are giving themselves pseudo dimples — and not the surgical kind
column5: which yes
column6: is a thing.

column1: Behold the “dimple maker”: a cherry-shaped device with a curved wire sporting marble-like balls on each end. All you have to do
column2: according to people on TikTok
column3: is pry the device open and slip it onto your cheek as the balls clamp the inner and outer sides together.

column1: Over time
column2: the device may leave impressions on the muscles and fat pads in your cheek
column3: although plastic surgeons who spoke to USA TODAY aren’t convinced they’ll last long. Doctors came to the same conclusion nearly 90 years ago after a woman named Isabelle Gilbert invented a similar product.

column1: Today
column2: interest persists and is growing. The hashtag #dimplemaker has over 60 million views on TikTok
column3: with the devices springing up on Etsy and other shops for about $15.

column1: Dimple makers are relatively safe
column2: and are a less invasive alternative to a dimpleplasty — the surgical removal of muscle inside the cheek to create dimples — but experts say that they may still pose risks
column3: such as permanent nerve damage and scarring.

column1: “You want to be careful with home remedies and fads because nobody's counseling you about complications
column2: ” said Dr. Alan Matarasso
column3: board vice president of development for the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. “You especially have to be careful with anything on the face that's not reversible.”

column1: Dimple makers compress the skin and underlying fat in the cheek
column2: squeezing fluid out of surrounding tissue and creating a temporary inward dent
column3: according to Dr. Jonathan Kaplan
column4: a plastic surgeon with Pacific Heights Plastic Surgery in San Francisco
column5: California
column6: who likens the device to a waist trainer.

column1: It’s unclear how long it takes to work
column2: but results will vary depending on how tight the clamp is
column3: how long it’s worn and the amount of fat in the cheek
column4: experts say.

column1: Dimple makers can be helpful if you’re interested in getting a dimpleplasty
column2: Kaplan said
column3: because you can see how you’ll look with dimples and what placement best suits your face.

column1: Dimple makers that are too tight and worn for too long could potentially restrict blood flow to the spot on the cheek that’s being compressed
column2: leading to the death of fat tissue (necrosis)
column3: Kaplan said.

column1: A hard lump could develop in your cheek as a result
column2: but it’s unlikely to be noticeable from the outside and can go away with time
column3: Kaplan said. If enough blood supply is cut off
column4: your skin cells in the area could die
column5: which can leave a scab and scar.

column1: A more unlikely yet still plausible risk of wearing dimple makers is nerve damage in the face
column2: which could theoretically lead to paralysis in the upper and lower lip
column3: Matarasso  said
column4: giving you a "I just had a cavity filled at the dentist"-type of smile.

column1: “When you put pressure on a nerve
column2: you have a certain amount of time until the nerve dies and then it's not reversible
column3: ” Matarasso said. “Think of it as a wet match — sometimes it'll dry off
column4: but if you soak that match enough
column5: it's never going to strike a fire.”

column1: Dimplepasties carry similar risks because a surgical knife could pierce a nerve
column2: but the likelihood of that happening is “extraordinarily low
column3: ” Matarasso said. Dimple makers
column4: on the other hand
column5: may pose greater risks of nerve damage because you’re compressing a larger surface area of the cheek
column6: he added.

column1: However
column2: Kaplan speculates that most people wouldn’t be able to tolerate the pain associated with these kinds of injuries for long enough to sustain any kind of permanent damage.

column1: As dimple makers become more popular
column2: it's far from uncommon for 26-year-old Miya Ulatowski
column3: who was born with dimples
column4: to be accused of faking hers: “When I first started seeing those comments
column5: it threw me off because I didn’t even know dimple surgery was a thing.”

column1: While Ulatowski doesn’t understand dimples’ appeal
column2: the Ohio resident said that she’s “a big supporter of people doing whatever they need to feel happy and confident in how they look.”

column1: Meanwhile
column2: people who opt for a dimpleplasty are frequently bombarded with hate about their decision to pursue the procedure. Merissa Fernandes
column4: of Massachusetts
column5: said she has received pushback online since undergoing surgery in June
column6: but acknowledges that it’s a consequence of being open about body modifications.

column1: “I’ve always adored people who had dimples
column2: so I got the surgery because I wanted to
column3: ” Fernandes said. “I’m not doing anything for the opinions of others
column4: I just think it’s valuable to be as transparent as possible.”

column1: Interest in bodybuilding has skyrocketed since the pandemic began. Searches for "bodybuilding" or "weightlifting" apps have grown by over 190% year over year
column2: according to Google Trends data. Among the most popular bodybuilding gym exercises that people seek out are squats
column3: dumbbells and deadlifts. But one analysis shows that by far the most popular weightlifting exercise – among both men and women – is the bench press.

column1: The bench press is such a sought-after piece of gym equipment because the workout produces the kind of results bodybuilders are after
column2: it's a straightforward exercise that's easy to do and because it offers a host of other health benefits beyond muscle growth alone.

column1: Like many forms of resistance training
column2: the bench press requires the use of some basic gym equipment. These include a workout bench to lay back on
column3: a long barbell that sits atop a secure rack frame on both sides of the bench
column4: and weight plates of varying poundage that are added to each side of the barbell in equal amounts and then secured with clips at each end.

column1: Once the right equipment is in place
column2: getting the most out of the exercise requires good form. Jackie Miller
column3: a certified IRONMAN and USA Triathlon coach who has been advising athletes for 18 years
column4: says the trick to proper bench press form is sticking to the following steps:

column1: Once you feel fatigue such as muscle burn or feeling overly tired, it's time to rack the weight, says Melanie Adams
column2: an American College of Sports Medicine certified exercise physiologist and a professor of exercise science at Keene State College in New Hampshire.

column1: Done properly
column2: the exercise works several muscle groups
column3: but its primary target is the pectoralis major
column4: often called pecs. "This is the large
column5: fan-shaped muscle on top of our ribs and over our chest
column6:
says Adams. She explains that the job of these chest muscles is to help move one's shoulders and control movement of both arms across the front of the body.
The bench press works other muscles, too. The triceps get some good stress as well as the exercise extends the elbow
column7: Adams explains. So do assisting muscles such as deltoids, biceps, forearm muscles, rib muscles, and the latissimus dorsi
column8: which stabilize the wrist and shoulder blades."

column1: The exercise is also unique because it can be adjusted to target each muscle group more extensively.
Lifting from an inclined workout bench will target one's upper chest muscles
column2: while decline bench-pressing movements will target one's lower chest muscles
column3: explains Dr. Matthew Best
column4: director of research in the sports medicine division at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine. At either setting
column5: however
column6: "it's important to avoid trying to lift too much weight or performing the exercise too rapidly
column7: which can predispose to injury
column8:
he adds.
More on squats:Squat challenges are all over social media. What muscles does the exercise work?
Beyond increased upper-body strength in each of these muscle groups, bench pressing has other health benefits as well. These include improved stamina and endurance, increased mobility and some research shows that the exercise can also increase bone density.
Performing the exercise also partly satisfies the physical activity recommendations set forth by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. For optimal health and strength, the agency recommends 75 to 150 minutes of moderate to vigorous aerobic activity each week in addition to muscle strengthening activities at least twice a week. 
Maintaining such levels of physical activity, the CDC notes, can improve one's brain health, help manage weight, reduce the risk of disease and improve one's ability to do everyday activities. Many people are initially interested in weightlifting to increase muscle size
column9: but quickly learn our muscles are involved in all kinds of hormonal interactions like lowering inflammation
column10: stopping stress response and growing brain cells
column11: explains Adams. Building both muscular endurance and muscular strength throughout the body pays off for your health."

Suzanne Somers has died at the age of 76
column2: and the loss has been felt among fans around the world.

column1: Devastated to hear about the passing of Suzanne Somers, @marc_k011 wrote on X
column2: formerly known as Twitter. "A true icon and overall amazing human being."

column1: I'm truthfully devastated with the death of Suzanne Somers. She was a great actress, but had a deeper heart in life, @MichaelKerner20 wrote. "She was a sweetheart!!!"
Grief is different for everyone
column2: and experts say mourning someone you didn't personally know − a phenomenon called collective or public grief − is a complicated
column3: yet valid
column4: experience.

column1: Collective and public grief, as I call it, is always unique in how we attach, David Kessler
column2: grief expert and founder of Grief.com
column3: previously told USA TODAY.

column1: This form of grief can be further compounded when the death of a beloved public figure is read about unexpectedly in the news.
When people experience sudden loss, they may feel shocked, disbelief, confused, and even in denial, Shavonne Moore-Lobban
column2: licensed psychologist
column3: previously told USA TODAY. "The suddenness of the loss may be too much to process and feel too unreal for a person to immediately grasp."

column1: More:Suzanne Somers
column2: star of 'Three's Company' and 'Step by Step
column3: ' dead at 76

column1: Somers' longtime publicist
column2: R. Couri Hay
column3: shared a statement on behalf of the actress' family with the news Sunday. The actress
column4: who "survived an aggressive form" of breast cancer for over 23 years
column5: "passed away peacefully at home in the early morning hours" on Sunday
column6:
the statement read.
Sudden loss can be more shocking and people can feel less 'prepared' than they might with expected loss
column7: Moore-Lobban added. However
column8: it is still hard to prepare for anything that is life-altering
column9: whether a person knew it was coming."

column1: More:The Titanic submersible passengers have died. It's OK to grieve.
Many have parasocial relationships with those in the public eye
column2: be it celebrities
column3: politicians
column4: news anchors. You feel close to them like they're your friend or relative.

column1: Just because collective or public grief doesn't match how one might grieve someone close to them
column2: that doesn't make the experience any less real.

column1: It's a fascinating thing that people don't realize we really can grieve people we didn't know, Kessler added. "And it doesn't mean we're going to grieve them like our spouse or mother
column2: father
column3: or sister or child
column4: but we will grieve them."

column1: More:Lisa Marie Presley
column2: Grant Wahl
column3: Stephen 'tWitch' Boss and the trauma of a sudden death

column1: If you're trying to comfort someone going through loss
column2: don't try to minimize it or put a timetable to the grieving process.

column1: There is no limit to grief and because it is a cycle or process, it will continue as long as it needs to for the person who is experiencing it, Moore-Lobban said.
If you're going through loss yourself
column2: talk about it. This "might mean acknowledging it and being open with someone you trust
column3: about how you are feeling
column4: Moore-Lobban said. It might also include engaging in therapy with a mental health provider
column5: which can be individual or group therapy. Talking about it can also occur by writing
column6: meaning a person can journal about how they feel and what they are thinking."

column1: The deaths of public figures may also serve as opportunities to widen discussions on grief.
We have a relationship with death that we don't quite know how to explore as a society, Kessler said. "I always tell people the death rate is 100%. So we know we're all going to die someday
column2: intellectually
column3: but we don't know
column4: is death the great enemy? Is it the great comforter
column5: when we're in pain? We sort of don't know how to hold it."

column1: The conservatorship stripped me of my womanhood, made me into a child, the "Womanizer" singer writes in the excerpt of the memoir shared with People. "I became more of an entity than a person onstage. I had always felt music in my bones and my blood; they stole that from me."

I ended up walking differently, carrying myself differently, talking differently. I was someone else for months while I filmed 'Crossroads,' the "Oops!…I Did It Again" singer writes.
Getting too deep into a character made her "glad" she didn't get the role of Allie Hamilton in "The Notebook" opposite Gosling
column2: which ended up going to Rachel McAdams.

column1: That was pretty much the beginning and end of my acting career, and I was relieved, she continued. "'The Notebook' casting came down to me and Rachel McAdams

column1: Baby

column4: and her infamous 2001 VMA performance of "I'm a Slave 4 U."

column1: The "snake's tongue is flicking out at me. Right. Now

column3: I got to the part where I handed it back
column4: thank God."

column1: The excerpts also include her thoughts on becoming a tabloid fixture in the early 2000s
column2: the harm it caused
column3: the termination of her conservatorship
column4: and how she hopes telling her story inspires others.

column1: Shaving my head and acting out were my ways of pushing back, Spears writes.

The woman in me was pushed down for a long time. They wanted me to be wild onstage, the way they told me to be, and to be a robot the rest of the time, she said. "I felt like I was being deprived of those good secrets of life — those fundamental supposed sins of indulgence and adventure that make us human.
It took a long time and a lot of work for me to feel ready to tell my story, she said. "I hope it inspires people on some level and can touch hearts."

A Royal Caribbean International cruise ship helped evacuate U.S. nationals from Israel on Monday.
The line’s Rhapsody of the Seas vessel had been sailing in the region but canceled its itineraries in the wake of the Israel-Hamas war.
“Now
column2: with enhanced safety precautions in place
column3: our ship is providing free passage
column4: including accommodation and food
column5: for Americans in the region wishing to leave and find safer ground
column6: ” Jason Liberty
column7: president and CEO of the line’s parent company Royal Caribbean Group
column8: said in an email to employees that was shared with USA TODAY.

column1: The evacuation was conducted in partnership with the U.S. State Department
column2: Liberty said. The U.S. Embassy in Israel said in a security alert Sunday that boarding would begin in order of arrival on Monday at 8:00 a.m. local time
column3: and the ship would sail from Haifa to Limassol
column4: Cyprus.

column1: The Rhapsody of the Seas ship can accommodate more than 2
column2: 400 passengers
column3: according to Royal Caribbean’s website.

column1: “Each traveler must be a U.S. national or the immediate family member (spouse/partner
column2: children under age 21) of a U.S. national and have a valid passport
column3: ” the alert said. The embassy said travelers would be responsible for arranging their own accommodations and travel from Cyprus
column4: but that chartered flights were also being arranged.

column1: “This has truly been an incredible effort as our teams worked tirelessly over the past week to make this mission possible
column2: ” Liberty added in the email. “My heartfelt gratitude goes out to all involved and especially to the ship’s officers and crew for their unwavering support of this call to serve others in the midst of unimaginable tragedy.”

column1: Escaping from Israel:U.S. families take tumultuous flights home after Hamas attacks
Many cruise lines changed itineraries following the conflict
column2: in some cases suspending stops in Israel altogether. The State Department has an advisory in place for the region
column3: warning against travel to Gaza and urging travelers to reconsider going to Israel and the West Bank.

column1: Southwest Airlines wants to make it easier for you to get status in its Rapid Rewards program.
Beginning Jan. 1
column2: it’s lowering the threshold to qualify for A-List and A-List preferred status.

column1: According to the airline
column2: the new requirements will be 20 qualifying one-way flights for A-List status
column3: down from 25
column4: and 40 qualifying one-way flights for A-List Preferred status
column5: down from 50. The thresholds to earn those statuses through tier qualifying points (TQPs) will remain at 35
column7: 000 respectively.

column1: Jonathan Clarkson
column2: Southwest’s vice president of marketing
column3: acknowledged that these changes are going against the grain of other updates in the airline rewards realm.

column1: “While I’d love to say that we’re so nimble we did an immediate response
column2: it just isn’t the case. We’ve been working on this for a while
column3: ” he told USA TODAY
column4: referencing Delta Air Lines’ recent changes. “At a time when other programs
column5: plural
column6: are making it harder to achieve tier status
column7: we’re making it easier.”

column1: Southwest is also lowering the spend-to-earn threshold on its co-branded credit cards. Rapid Rewards Premier
column2: Priority
column3: Premier Business
column4: or Performance Business cardholders will now receive 1
column5: 500 TQPs for every $5
column6: 000 in spending
column7: down from the current $10

column1: Other frequent flyer programs have seen a swelling of their elite ranks in recent years

column1: “That was one of the criteria we used when we talked about how we arrived at these benefits. Foremost was ensuring that whatever changes we make didn’t result in bloating the program
column2: ” he said. “It will result in a larger program we anticipate
column3: but not to the point where it erodes the benefit of the people who get to take advantage of it.”

column1: Cruising Altitude:Don't bother with an airline loyalty program if you're this traveler
The airline announced other changes to Rapid Rewards benefits as well

column1: Clarkson said A-List Preferred members will also be entitled to up to two free alcoholic drinks per flight. He added that vouchers for those drinks will be embedded in the passenger’s boarding pass scanner code
column2: rather than travelers needing to present physical certificates onboard.

column1: Customer feedback has been positive about the changes so far

column1: “This is another example of Southwest deciding to zig when everybody else zags

UPDATE: This story has been updated with news that within hours of publication of USA TODAY's investigation
column2: MSU suspended Coach Mel Tucker without pay.

column1: Two years ago
column2: one of the nation’s star college football coaches and a prominent rape survivor teamed up to fight the culture of sexual violence in sports.

column1: Their partnership should have been a force for good. Instead
column2: it has devolved into scandal
column3: with the activist accusing the coach of the same misconduct that both of them preached against.

column1: The accused is Mel Tucker
column2: the head football coach at Michigan State University and one of the highest paid coaches in all of sports. Accusing him is Brenda Tracy
column3: a rape survivor who has made educating athletes about sexual violence her life’s work.

column1: Over eight months
column2: they developed a professional relationship centered on her advocacy work. Tucker invited Tracy to campus three times – twice to speak to his players and staff and once to be recognized as an honorary captain at the team's spring football game.

column1: But their relationship was upended during a phone call on April 28
column3: Tracy says in a complaint she filed with the university’s Title IX office in December that remains under investigation.

column1: According to her complaint
column2: Tracy sat frozen for several minutes while Tucker made sexual comments about her and masturbated. His violation
column3: she said
column4: reopened 25-year-old wounds from her rape by four men – two Oregon State University football players
column5: a junior college player and a high school recruit.

column1: “The idea that someone could know me and say they understand my trauma but then re-inflict that trauma on me is so disgusting to me
column2: it’s hard for me to even wrap my mind around it
column3: ” she told USA TODAY. “It’s like he sought me out just to betray me.”

column1: In his statements to the Title IX investigator
column2: Tucker acknowledged masturbating on the call but said Tracy grossly mischaracterized the episode. According to him
column3: they had consensual “phone sex.”

column1: “Ms. Tracy’s distortion of our mutually consensual and intimate relationship into allegations of sexual exploitation has really affected me
column2: ” Tucker wrote in a March 22 letter to the investigator. “I am not proud of my judgment and I am having difficulty forgiving myself for getting into this situation
column3: but I did not engage in misconduct by any definition.”

column1: Michigan State hired an outside Title IX attorney to investigate the complaint. She finished her investigation in July. A formal hearing to determine whether Tucker violated the school’s policy banning sexual harassment and exploitation is scheduled for Oct. 5 and 6
column2: during the Spartans’ bye week.

column1: The stakes are high for everyone.

Tracy says Tucker is following through on a threat to ruin her career and reputation by painting her as a woman who mixes professional and personal relationships and files false reports. She fears he will undo her legacy.
Tucker
column2: who signed one of the most lucrative contracts in college sports history two years ago
column3: could lose out on the roughly $80 million he is owed if Michigan State fires him for cause
column4: which would be a stunning fall from the elite ranks of college coaches.

column1: Reached by USA TODAY on his cellphone Saturday night
column2: Tucker hung up after a reporter mentioned the case.

column1: Hours after USA TODAY published its investigation
column2: the university suspended Tucker without pay
column3: pending a resolution of the Title IX case.

column1: “This step
column2: suspending Mel Tucker without pay
column3: is … necessary and appropriate for today's circumstances
column4: ” Interim President Teresa Woodruff said at a Sunday evening press conference. “These actions are not taken lightly.”

column1: USA TODAY typically does not identify people who allege sexual harassment. Tracy agreed to be identified and shared more than 1
column2: 200 pages of case documents.

column1: Title IX
column2: the federal law banning sex discrimination in education
column3: requires schools to investigate allegations of sexual harassment that took place in the context of a school program or activity. Such claims are inherently difficult to adjudicate because of many of the factors at issue in this case: a lack of eyewitnesses and recordings
column4: the passage of time and the thorniness of litigating consent.

column1: Adding to the uncertainty
column2: the institution tasked with sorting out the facts is perhaps best known for missing repeated opportunities to stop one of the most prolific sexual abusers in American history.

column1: For nearly two decades
column2: Michigan State leaders failed to act on complaints against Larry Nassar
column3: the disgraced former U.S.A. Gymnastics and campus physician accused of sexually assaulting more than 300 female athletes under the guise of medical treatments. He has been sentenced to a minimum of 100 years in prison.

column1: Amid its efforts to rebuild trust among students
column2: employees
column3: alumni and the East Lansing community
column4: Michigan State's leaders must now decide whether the face of its prestigious football program is guilty of sexually harassing one of the country’s most influential advocates against gender-based violence.

column1: For some
column2: how the university navigates the crisis will send a clear message about its commitment to progress.

column1: “This goes beyond coach Tucker and Brenda Tracy
column2: ” said Jennifer Gomez
column3: a Boston University professor who researches the effects of interpersonal trauma and violence. “What happens here has the potential to be very healing or very harmful for lots and lots and lots of other people.”

column1: Tracy and Tucker met in August 2021 during her first visit to Michigan State
column2: after a mutual acquaintance introduced them.

column1: Standing before a packed auditorium in the Spartans’ football operations building
column2: Tracy told a gut-wrenching story of turning her pain into purpose two decades after filing a police report saying she had been gang-raped as a 24-year-old mother of two.

column1: At the end
column2: she challenged the “good men” in the room to use their privilege and influence to educate themselves and call out bad behavior.

column1: By then she had delivered versions of the speech more than 100 times to at least 40
column2: 000 athletes and coaches. Michigan State paid her a $10
column3: 000 speaking fee.

column1: Tucker was in his second season as head coach. A former University of Wisconsin-Madison defensive back
column2: he had spent two decades coaching defenses for 10 college and NFL teams before landing the top job at the University of Colorado in late 2018. Michigan State lured him away a year later by doubling his salary.

column1: Mel Tucker's career at Michigan State: A timeline
Tucker and Tracy “hit it off” immediately
column2: they would both later tell the Title IX investigator. They bonded over their love of Jordan sneakers
column3: shelves of which lined Tucker’s office walls.

column1: Tucker had been moved by her speech
column2: and she had been a big hit with players
column3: he told the investigator. They discussed her coming back to campus in the future.

column2: she told the investigator. He seemed engaged with her cause
column3: leading his players in signing her pledge to
column4: among other things

column1: During that time

column4: they said. They chatted about their jobs and eventually more personal matters
column5: such as their families
column6: mental health and daily lives.

column1: They spoke most frequently in fall 2021
column2: while Tucker was leading Michigan State to a 11-2 record – its best season in six years – and negotiating one of the richest coaching contracts of all time.

column1: In November
column2: Michigan State signed him to an unprecedented 10-year
column3: $95 million deal that came fully guaranteed
column4: even if it fired him for poor performance. The only way he could lose out on the money
column5: the contract said
column6: was if he materially breached it
column7: was convicted of a crime or engaged in “conduct which
column8: in the University’s reasonable judgment
column9: would tend to bring public disrespect
column10: contempt or ridicule on the University.”

column1: It was around then that Tucker
column2: who had been married for more than two decades
column3: started becoming interested in Tracy romantically
column4: they both told the investigator.

column1: Whether Tracy reciprocated is where their accounts diverge.
Tucker told the investigator that he and Tracy developed a romantic connection and talked openly about it.
They frequently made flirtatious comments about each other’s looks and bodies
column2: Tucker said. Tracy told him she wanted a “sugar daddy” who would pay her a monthly amount to be his girlfriend
column3: he said
column4: and that she would be “all over” him if he wasn’t married.

column1: Tucker said they had acknowledged their mutual desire for a romance but agreed it would be “too messy” because of his marriage and the physical distance between them.
By contrast
column2: Tracy told the investigator that Tucker’s romantic interest in her was entirely one-sided. She said she came to feel he was less interested in her cause than in her.

column1: Tucker messaged her photos of herself that he had found on her Instagram page
column2: making comments such as
column3: “This is the one
column4: ” or complimenting her eyes

column6: 500 to her nonprofit.

column2: Tucker called Tracy via FaceTime. He was in bed

column5: during a Nov. 9
column7: call

column1: Tracy said she responded that she would not because they worked together – one of several times she recalled trying to set boundaries. She said she made clear to Tucker on a Dec. 1 call that they would only be friends

column1: Then
column2: after the spring game
column3: Tucker called her four times
column4: phone records show. Tracy said he repeatedly asked her to meet him alone
column5: without her assistant
column6: and even suggested slipping into her hotel through a back door so no one would see him. She said no.

column1: Twelve days later came the call.
Tracy was in her home office in Oregon. Tucker
column2: who was in a hotel in Florida
column3: called her at 12:39 a.m. EST
column4: phone records show. The call lasted 36 minutes.

column4: case documents show. “She was the one who said we’ll do it.”

column2: she said. But when she sent Tucker a photo of them together from the spring game

column1: She remembered Tucker’s voice getting deeper and weirder as he continued talking about her buttocks. She asked him what he was doing

column2: "Oh my god

column5: she said

column7: “If you do this

column9: we are only friends
