Lake Erie is now a world record holder!
The lake broke a world record over the weekend for the most waterspouts in a 24-hour period.
The International Centre for Waterspout Research announced that there were 181 waterspouts and funnel clouds observed over Lake Erie on Oct. 7, breaking the world waterspout record. According to the research center, one observer saw 72 waterspouts.
Users on X, formerly Twitter, shared photos and videos of the record-breaking waterspouts spotted over Lake Erie on Oct. 7.
Under busy Florida street:a 19th-century boat discovered where once was water
Yes, cruise prices are up:Here's why cheap sailings may be harder to find
A waterspout is a whirling column of air and water mist, according to the National Ocean Service. They fall into two categories: Fair weather waterspouts, which usually form along the dark flat base of a line of developing cumulus clouds, or tornadic waterspouts, which are tornadoes that form over water, or move from land to water.
The National Weather Service issues a tornado warning if a waterspout moves on shore, as they could cause significant damage and injuries. Fair weather waterspouts typically dissipate rapidly once they reach land, rarely moving far inland.
The National Weather Service office in Buffalo, New York issued a special marine warning Oct. 7, warning of favorable conditions for waterspouts to form and later posted that waterspouts had been observed.
The U.S. ranks first for the most waterspout sightings, according to the International Centre for Waterspout Research, accounting for 41.7% of all waterspouts sighted. Italy ranks second, at 10.2%. As of Monday, the research center reported have been 1,615 waterspouts observed around the world this year.
For Anne Patterson, who is studying to become a psychotherapist at age 55, the several thousand dollars in stimulus checks the government doled out to most Americans during the depths of the pandemic was a godsend.
Patterson, of East Bay, California,  has amassed $100,000 in student loan and other debt, allowing her to just barely pay the bills and forcing her to forgo frills such as dining out and going to the theater.
The government aid in 2020 and 2021 “was extremely helpful,” she says. “I could cover some of the basics like food and medicine.”
But the stimulus money is long gone and the resumption of student loan repayments this fall will saddle her with another $500 monthly expense, she estimates.
“I will certainly have to find places to cut back my spending,” she says, noting that she won’t be able to afford the final stage of a dental crown.
Learn more: Best personal loans
The pandemic-related savings and government aid that have helped prop up the U.S. economy over the past three years are dwindling, posing new strains for low- and moderate-income households and hazards for a nation at risk of slipping into recession by early 2024.
In interviews and a Harris Poll survey for USA TODAY, Americans whose COVID cash reserves are running low say they’re putting off home projects, eating out less, canceling subscriptions and taking out loans to make ends meet. Those kinds of strategies are likely to toss some cold water on U.S. consumer spending, which makes up 70% of economic activity.
“People have drawn down their savings and have less capital to spend
column3: says Gregory Daco
column4: chief economist of EY-Parthenon
column5: a consulting firm.

column1: Other households say they still have a good chunk of their COVID savings or never relied on it to pay expenses. Overall
column2: though
column3: the shrinking trove – along with rising credit card interest rates
column4: high inflation and a cooling job market -- could tip the nation into a recession by next year
column5: some forecasters say.

column1: “We are always unwilling to bet against the U.S. consumer
column2: but we’re struggling here to see a plausible path to avoid a meaningful slowdown in their spending
column3: ” Ian Shepherdson
column4: chief economist of Pantheon Macroeconomics
column5: recently wrote in a note to clients.

column1: Early in the pandemic
column2: Americans socked away $2.7 trillion in excess cash from three rounds of stimulus checks
column3: enhanced unemployment benefits
column4: the pause in student loan repayments and laying low during the health crisis
column5: among other assistance
column6: Moody’s Analytics estimates.

column1: For most people
column2: the stimulus checks alone amounted to $3
column3: 200 per individual. All told the $2.7 trillion cash hoard represents an average $21
column4: 000 average per household. The stash helped people cushion the blow from high inflation and interest rates
column5: or stay afloat while they took a hiatus from work due to health concerns or childcare duties. It gave others the financial leeway to hunt for a new job after getting laid off during the pandemic.

column1: More than one-third of Americans say the money was “very important” to their financial stability during COVID and about one-quarter say it was “somewhat important
column2: ” according to a survey by Suffolk University Sawyer Business School and USA TODAY
column3: conducted in September.

column1: Now
column2: that cache is running dry
column3: by some estimates
column4: at least for the most vulnerable.

column1: Seventy-one percent of Americans built excess reserves during the pandemic and six in 10 of those savers say they’ve depleted most or all of that money
column2: according to the USA TODAY/Harris Poll survey
column3: conducted last month. Among that group
column4: 90% have pared back their spending or plan to do so
column5: compared with 62% who haven’t depleted their COVID funds.

column1: Of those slashing spending
column2: 65% are dining out less
column3: 61% are cutting back experiences and 56% are buying fewer discretionary goods
column4: the Harris Poll survey shows.

column1: Patterson
column2: the clinical psychology student
column3: majored in cultural anthropology in college but couldn’t find a position in her field and spent decades in administrative jobs in industries such as mortgage servicing and title insurance. She decided to seek a more fulfilling career a few years ago and looks forward to a six-figure salary in 2024 but is still earning just $50
column4: 000 as part of an internship.

column1: Besides putting off the dental crown
column2: she says she’ll offset the student loan payments by shelving veterinary appointments for her three dogs
column3: turning down the air conditioning in the summer and cutting back on twice-weekly DoorDash restaurant deliveries for her and her partner
column4: who is disabled.

column1: Fortunately
column2: she says
column3: she inherited her three-bedroom house from her mother and so doesn’t have a mortgage.

column1: “It’s scary but I feel like I’m going to be okay
column2: ” she says.

column1: Across the U.S.
column2: exactly how much of the pandemic savings remains is something of an open question

column1: Daco reckons $1.3 trillion is still left while Mark Zandi
column2: chief economist of Moody’s Analytics
column3: puts the figure at $1.8 trillion. Those estimates are based on recent government revisions that added $500 billion to $800 billion to estimated COVID savings totals.

column1: By contrast
column2: the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco recently figured that a paltry $190 billion or so was left as of June and that sum likely would be exhausted by the July-September quarter. Agency officials are reworking the number based on the government revisions and wouldn’t comment. Even so
column3: the cash buffer could run out in a few months
column4: according to their most recent analysis.

column1: Even if $1.3 trillion remains
column2: as Shepherdson reckons
column3: his analysis of Federal Reserve data suggests that it’s mostly in the hands of the top 20% of income earners who are less likely to spend it. Low- and middle-income people “have spent nearly all of their excess pandemic savings
column4: ” he says.

column1: Zandi disagrees
column2: saying lower and middle-income groups still have about 60% of their COVID stockpile.

column1: Yet that doesn’t mean they’ll spend it.
Christine Perron of Villa Rica
column2: Georgia
column3: says she saved several thousand dollars from stimulus checks and dining out about once a week during COVID
column4: down from as many as four times a week before the pandemic.

column1: Perron
column3: was a baker for a large grocery chain but retired a couple of years ago after receiving a legal settlement for a leg injury she sustained while fixing the roof of her house.

column1: She used her COVID savings to cope with high inflation
column2: including a $500 surge in the price of propane to heat her house for the winter. She also stocked up on toilet paper and other items that were in short supply early in the health crisis.

column1: “It did take a lot of the pressure off
column2: ” she says of the government aid.

column1: Perrone also renovated her deck at a cost of $4
column2: 800 and bought new carpet for a sitting room.

column1: About half the money is left
column2: Perron says
column3: and she’d like to replace her kitchen floor. But prices have doubled or tripled since COVID amid high material and labor costs and she worries that she won’t recoup her investment when she sells her three-bedroom house.

column1: “If I do it now
column2: I’ll get ripped off
column3: ” she says.

column1: Instead
column2: Perron is biding her time and waiting to use the cash to buy a similar-sized house on a smaller parcel that requires less upkeep.

column1: Others burned through their COVID savings long ago.
Michael and Colleen Barineau
column2: of Lehigh Acres
column3: Florida
column4: were scrambling to pay bills before the pandemic. Michael
column6: a former construction worker
column7: is on disability because of a work-related accident. Colleen
column8: an administrative assistant for the medical department of a jail
column9: couldn’t work for three weeks due to pandemic restrictions.

column2: the couple used the stimulus checks to pay the mortgage on their two-bedroom house
column3: the electric bill and other monthly expenses.

column1: “They kept us afloat
column2: ” Michael says. “As soon as they came in the house they were gone.”

column1: Since the money has run out
column2: the Barineaus
column3: who have a combined income of $45
column5: have had to take out loans to make ends meet and sometimes fall behind
column6: prompting calls from the mortgage company.

column1: “It’s not fun
column2: ” Michael says. “You don’t know how you’re going to get the money.”

column1: Some Americans are plagued by second thoughts about how they spent their windfall.
Terrie Wood
column2: of Riner
column3: Virginia
column4: figures she and her husband
column5: Alan
column6: squirreled away about $5
column7: 000 from stimulus checks and hunkering down during COVID.

column1: They needed the cash.
Terrie
column3: had to shut down her horse training and riding lessons business when sales plunged because of COVID. And while Alan earns a healthy six-figure salary as a mechanical engineer
column4: she says the couple has struggled with large tax
column5: insurance and debt payments for their 30-acre farm
column6: tractor and pickup truck.

column1: They used their COVID savings to whittle down credit card bills and pay off a $3
column2: 000 loan for the tractor
column3: wiping out a $580 monthly payment.

column1: “It helped
column2: ” she says
column3: “but it wasn’t significant enough.”

column1: Now
column2: she says she wishes they hadn’t paid off the tractor loan because the cash would be providing more breathing room.

column1: “If we had that money it would be amazing
column2: ” she says
column3: “so we’re not living paycheck to paycheck.” Plus
column4: “There would be play money that we don’t have.”

column1: The value of remote work:Americans will part with pay to work from home
Others welcomed the pandemic cash bonanza but didn’t depend on it.
Jimothy Locklear
column2: of Charlotte
column3: North Carolina
column4: said he
column5: his wife
column6: and two teenaged children have sharply cut back on dining out and traveling since the crisis
column7: saving thousands of dollars. They also received the stimulus checks.

column1: But Locklear
column3: a warehouse supervisor
column4: and his wife
column5: who owns a housecleaning business
column6: didn’t need the money to pay the bills.

column1: “It padded our savings account
column2: ” he says.

column1: Before Oct. 7
column2: my brother
column3: his girlfriend and his kids were just parts of my greater identity and what I love and hold dear in this world. Now
column4: as I live through a waking nightmare in which they have been taken hostage by Hamas − this part of my identity consumes me. And it's what drives and will drive my every action and thought
column5: until my family comes home.

column1: My heart is heavy with sorrow
column2: anger and
column3: most of all
column4: a profound sense of helplessness after an act so horrific and brutal that we never could have imagined it.

column1: Hell began for us when my wife and I called my brother
column2: Yair Yaakov
column3: during the first round of missile attacks the morning of Oct. 7
column4: to check in on him; his girlfriend
column5: Meirav Tal; and my two nephews
column6: who are 16 and 12. They live in Nir Oz
column7: a kibbutz in southern Israel
column8: near the Gaza border.

column1: My brother reassured my wife that they were in their shelter/safe room. His two sons were staying at their mother’s house
column2: and my brother
column3: no matter how much he may have wished he could race to the rest of his family and bring them all together to protect them
column4: couldn’t leave the safe room in his house at the kibbutz.

column1: We survived the Hamas attack on Israel.What haunts us now is the blockade of Gaza.
They were strictly instructed to stay in place
column2: and they heard gunshots outside the house. Everyone was frozen as they faced the approaching fear and horror of Hamas terrorists closing in.

column1: About a half hour later
column2: Meirav sent us an audio message on WhatsApp. Her voice was shaking as she told us that terrorists had entered their home. Yair held the shelter’s door to keep the attackers out. But in the end
column3: he did not prevail. This was the last time we had contact with them.

column1: Our family was thrown into darkness. We searched every minute of that day for any sign of them. We tried using Apple’s “Find my iPhone” feature to no avail. We fought fear and panic all day to remain focused on locating our family.
Later that afternoon
column2: the mother of my nephews shared with us through tears that she had confirmation that her two sons had been kidnapped. Our world collapsed around us.

column1: For nearly 30 agonizing hours
column2: we had no idea where any of them were. We reached out to every level of every authority we could
column3: asking for help in finding Yair
column4: Meirav and my nephews. The silence that returned became overwhelming as we learned that we were going to face this nightmare primarily on our own. We turned to social media
column5: sharing pictures and heartfelt pleas
column6: hoping someone in our connected web would come forward with information.

column1: Then we learned the fate of my family when a friend of Yair shared a video showing that Hamas had taken them hostage. It showed the terrifying moments of Yair and Meirav's abduction after Hamas terrorists threw grenades to break the safe room’s door.
This wasn't just a crime; it was an inversion of humanity. Innocent people
column2: including children and women
column3: were forcibly taken from their homes where they should feel safe and torn away from their lives
column4: their families and their communities. They are now pawns in a war.

column1: 'Take a lesson from the dead':Fatal stabbing of 6-year-old in Illinois serves as warning to divided US
The days since have been dark with just one glimmer of light. Yair's oldest daughter and her boyfriend
column2: who were staying in yet another house in the kibbutz
column3: managed to keep their shelter secure and were eventually rescued by the Israel Defense Forces.

column1: As a family
column2: we appeal to the world for one thing: the safe return of our loved ones. We were brought up to believe that everyone has a family and deserves to be treated humanely. Hamas operates in stark contrast to these principles.

column1: Our only plea is to bring our kidnapped family members back home safely. We don’t know if they are being fed. We don’t know the state of their health. We don’t know where they are. The uncertainty about their fate is what our lives are defined by now
column2: and we are desperate for the day that we can receive good news about their well-being.

column1: Until then
column2: I am a brother and an uncle who refuses to give up.

column1: Yaniv Yaakov works in information technology in Israel.
Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis was able to transport hundreds of people from Israel to Florida just days after announcing an evacuation initiative by tapping into an existing rescue program
column2: Project Dynamo
column3: that likely would have gone forward with the effort regardless of the state’s support.

column1: Florida has paid for five flights to evacuate people out of Israel between Friday and Sunday
column2: including one that landed in Tampa Sunday night with 270 people
column3: but Project Dynamo coordinated everything else
column4: according to the group’s CEO and founder Bryan Stern.

column1: Project Dynamo was founded in 2021 to help rescue people from Afghanistan after American troops withdrew from the country and has conducted missions everywhere from Ukraine to Sudan. The flight to Tampa Sunday was the group’s 602nd evacuation mission.
Stern spoke about the rescue missions during a news conference Monday and said he was raising money to pay for the Tampa flight when the state of Florida stepped in to offer assistance.
“We were fundraising right up until Gov. DeSantis and his office came in… bottom line is we would have figured it out
column2: ” Stern said. “We’ve done it six hundred and one times without government help
column3: six hundred and two was not going to be the one that we failed on. But it makes it so much easier when you have backing by a state entity for sure.”

column1: Many commercial flights out of Israel were canceled following a surprise attack by Hamas and subsequent retaliatory measures by Israel. That has left many Americans struggling to find a way out of Israel.
DeSantis declared a state of emergency last week and directed the Florida Division of Emergency Management to coordinate evacuation efforts. The governor
column2: running what now appears to be a longshot campaign for the Republican presidential nomination
column3: was at the Tampa airport Sunday to welcome the evacuees from Israel
column4: which included 269 Americans – including roughly 70 Floridians – and one native of the Czech Republic.

column1: Stern said he was grateful for Florida's financial support
column2: the first time a government agency has funded one of his evacuation efforts
column3: but also made it clear that he would've done everything to get people home safely
column4: regardless of whether Florida funded the effort.

column1: Would it have been possible? I'll tell you that I wasn't going to leave them behind and I'm not trying to stay in Israel a moment longer than I need to so we would've figured it out, for sure, Stern said.
DeSantis' trip to Tampa on Sunday was “the first time an American politician has ever met us home
column2: ” Stern said.

column1: The evacuation flight to Tampa involved gathering people from more than 12 different areas across Israel
column2: Stern said. On the flight were Ron and Linda Neumann
column3: who are trying to become dual citizens of Israel and the United States
column4: and their dog.

column1: The Neumanns have been living in Israel recently
column2: but also live in Melbourne.

column1: Ron Neumann said after two flights out of Israel were canceled he tried to find a way out of the country by contacting U.S. State Department officials and state officials in Florida. Neither effort was successful
column2: but he heard about Project Dynamo through a friend and they helped him get on the flight to Tampa.

column1: “It was a miracle from God because we had no way to get out
column2:
Neumann said.
Stern didn't know the exact cost of the most recent flight from Israel to Florida, but said the average cost to charter a plane from Tampa to Israel right now is around $2 million. The governor's office and the Florida Division of Emergency Management provided no answers to questions from the USA TODAY Network - Florida on costs of the trips.
The first Florida arrival of what supporters are calling DeSantis Airlines" come at the same time the Biden administration is chartering flights from Israel to European destinations so passengers could book connecting flights home. DeSantis has slammed the White House for "dragging its feet" on the charters and said its flights "dump people in Europe."

column1: “But people don't need to be dumped in Europe
column2: DeSantis said in a video posted on the social media website X by his campaign. They want to get home.”

column1: The flights from Israel occurred the same weekend CBS News' 60 Minutes aired a segment Sunday critical of DeSantis' actions in September 2022
column2: when his administration lured about 50 mostly Venezuelan asylum-seekers from Texas to Martha's Vineyard
column3: off the Massachusetts' coast
column4: with the false promise of jobs and housing.

column1: Money for that trip came from a $12 million fund established within the state's Division of Emergency Management for relocating undocumented migrants from within Florida to other locations. The program has since been expanded and rewritten by the Florida Legislature to authorize DeSantis' action
column2: after its legality was challenged in a handful of lawsuits.

column1: DeSantis while campaigning in Iowa
column2: home of the first Republican presidential nomination contest
column3: has cited the Martha's Vineyard trip as proof of his commitment to combating illegal immigration and to underscore the failures of the Biden administration. DeSantis' White House bid probably lives or dies based on how he performs in Iowa.

column1: Those evacuated from Israel by the state-financed effort focused their praise on Project Dynamo
column2: touting the team's skills and efficiency.

column1: I'm humbled, said Linda Neumann. "To think that people risked their lives to come get us and our fellow Jews out of a war zone. I thank God for getting us out."
John Kennedy of the USA Today Network-Florida's capital bureau contributed to this report.
WASHINGTON — The militant group Hamas launched a shocking attack against Israel less than two weeks ago on the Jewish holiday of Simchat Torah
column2: leading to thousands of deaths and retaliation by Israeli forces in an area known as the Gaza Strip.

column1: The conflict has put millions of Israeli and Palestinian lives at risk as attacks have intensified day by day with hospitals and homes destroyed and some civilians held hostage. The death toll of Americans in the country has risen to 30
column2: and more than a dozen Americans remain missing.

column1: The chaos embroiling the Middle East has also stirred confusion among people in the U.S. seeking to understand the devastation in the area. Here’s a closer look at some lingering questions about the conflict.
The Israel-Hamas war explained: Understanding the conflict in Gaza amid rush to evacuate
The Israeli-Palestinian conflict dates back to the early 20th century
column2: according to the Council on Foreign Relations. The tension began after the creation of the State of Israel in 1948
column3: following the Holocaust
column4: in which six million Jews were murdered by the Nazi regime.

column1: For decades
column2: Palestinians have fought for self-determination and self-governance
column3: while Israeli forces sought to expand territory.

column1: Hamas' offensive is connected not only to specific Israeli military activity but to what the group views as a campaign to rob Palestinians of their land and displace them by force. For years
column2: the group has vowed to annihilate the state of Israel and claimed responsibility for deadly attacks.

column1: It is very difficult for Palestinians to leave Gaza.
Gaza is surrounded by blockades imposed by Israel and Egypt
column2: which restrict movement. Israel prevents access to and from Gaza by sea and air. Land movement is restricted to three crossings: the Egypt-controlled Rafah crossing and Erez and Kerem Shalom crossings
column3: which Israel controls.

column1: The U.N. has said that mass evacuation orders in the area will affect more than a million people. A total evacuation would mean the entire 2.23 million population of Gaza would have to squeeze into the southern half of the strip. Gaza
column2: which is only 25 miles long in its entirety and just over twice the size of Washington
column3: D.C.
column4: is the 63rd-most densely inhabited urban region in the world.

column1: Many are voicing uncertainty about safety anywhere in the strip if they leave their homes.
The West Bank is east of Israel
column2: and about three million Palestinians live there
column3: most of them Muslim Arabs. The West Bank also contains a number of Jewish holy sites.

column1: Israel occupies the West Bank
column2: though the Palestinian Authority
column3: controlled by the Fatah movement
column4: administers semi-autonomous areas of the region.

column1: Small Israeli communities called kibbutzim have been affected by the conflict. A kibbutz
column2: which means gathering in Hebrew
column3: is a kind-of communal body traditionally focused around farming or other environmental goals.

column1: The first kibbutz was established 90 years ago. Today
column2: approximately 125
column3: 000 people live on about 250 kibbutzim
column4: CNN reported.

column1: David Leach
column2: author of the book "Chasing Utopia: The Future of the Kibbutz in a Divided Israel
column3:
told NPR that historically, early kibbutzim “were exercises in radical democracy.”
Former President Donald Trump had criticized Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at an event in Florida last week, saying that the countries’ intelligence failed and that its enemies were “very smart.” He also said Netanyahu was not prepared in a Fox News Radio interview.
However, Trump walked back his comments on Monday to Iowa voters, saying that he supported Israel in its war with Hamas. 
Other Republican candidates, such as Ron DeSantis, Mike Pence, Vivek Ramaswamy, Nikki Haley and Chris Christie, have all supported standing with Israel.
“I think it is wrong when we in the United States or in the UN or anybody else create a false equivalence between Israel defending its own homeland versus the behaviors of the terrorists who target Israel,” said Ramaswamy during a town hall event last week presented by Seacoastonline and the USA TODAY Network.
The incumbent, Democratic President Joe Biden, has expressed strong support for Israel since the beginning of the conflict and will visit the country Wednesday.
Many organizations are collecting donations to help families living in Israel and Gaza.
One such organization is the Palestine Children’s Relief Fund, which has provided medical attention and basic necessities to vulnerable children for the past 30 years and opened a new fundraising campaign after the latest attack. 
Another organization is IsraAID, an Israel-based group that is also collecting funds to help affected communities. IsraAID helps coordinate humanitarian activities in shelters housing Gaza border region evacuees and provides mental health resources to families, according to its website.

column1: A Monday Night Football matchup between the Dallas Cowboys and the Los Angeles Chargers led to two men being hospitalized after stabbing each other.

column3: and got into an argument over noise while watching the game.

column1: Both were soon after transported to local hospitals and are expected to make full recoveries.
The SAPD told KSAT that an investigation is ongoing and they have yet to determine what charges
column2: if any
column3: the men will be faced with.

column1: The names of the men involved in the altercation have not yet been released.
The SAPD did not immediately respond to request for comment.
Fan dies after fight at Dolphins game:Police look to charge 3 men after Patriots fan died following fight at Dolphins game
We always want what we don’t have
column2: whether it’s a different hair color or longer lashes. Now
column3: in what appears to be the rebirth of a beauty trend with a storied history
column4: people are giving themselves pseudo dimples — and not the surgical kind
column5: which yes
column6: is a thing.

column1: Behold the “dimple maker”: a cherry-shaped device with a curved wire sporting marble-like balls on each end. All you have to do
column2: according to people on TikTok
column3: is pry the device open and slip it onto your cheek as the balls clamp the inner and outer sides together.

column1: Over time
column2: the device may leave impressions on the muscles and fat pads in your cheek
column3: although plastic surgeons who spoke to USA TODAY aren’t convinced they’ll last long. Doctors came to the same conclusion nearly 90 years ago after a woman named Isabelle Gilbert invented a similar product.

column1: Today
column2: interest persists and is growing. The hashtag #dimplemaker has over 60 million views on TikTok
column3: with the devices springing up on Etsy and other shops for about $15.

column1: Dimple makers are relatively safe
column2: and are a less invasive alternative to a dimpleplasty — the surgical removal of muscle inside the cheek to create dimples — but experts say that they may still pose risks
column3: such as permanent nerve damage and scarring.

column1: “You want to be careful with home remedies and fads because nobody's counseling you about complications
column2: ” said Dr. Alan Matarasso
column3: board vice president of development for the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. “You especially have to be careful with anything on the face that's not reversible.”

column1: Dimple makers compress the skin and underlying fat in the cheek
column2: squeezing fluid out of surrounding tissue and creating a temporary inward dent
column3: according to Dr. Jonathan Kaplan
column4: a plastic surgeon with Pacific Heights Plastic Surgery in San Francisco
column5: California
column6: who likens the device to a waist trainer.

column1: It’s unclear how long it takes to work
column2: but results will vary depending on how tight the clamp is
column3: how long it’s worn and the amount of fat in the cheek
column4: experts say.

column1: Dimple makers can be helpful if you’re interested in getting a dimpleplasty
column2: Kaplan said
column3: because you can see how you’ll look with dimples and what placement best suits your face.

column1: Dimple makers that are too tight and worn for too long could potentially restrict blood flow to the spot on the cheek that’s being compressed
column2: leading to the death of fat tissue (necrosis)
column3: Kaplan said.

column1: A hard lump could develop in your cheek as a result
column2: but it’s unlikely to be noticeable from the outside and can go away with time
column3: Kaplan said. If enough blood supply is cut off
column4: your skin cells in the area could die
column5: which can leave a scab and scar.

column1: A more unlikely yet still plausible risk of wearing dimple makers is nerve damage in the face
column2: which could theoretically lead to paralysis in the upper and lower lip
column3: Matarasso  said
column4: giving you a "I just had a cavity filled at the dentist"-type of smile.

column1: “When you put pressure on a nerve
column2: you have a certain amount of time until the nerve dies and then it's not reversible
column3: ” Matarasso said. “Think of it as a wet match — sometimes it'll dry off
column4: but if you soak that match enough
column5: it's never going to strike a fire.”

column1: Dimplepasties carry similar risks because a surgical knife could pierce a nerve
column2: but the likelihood of that happening is “extraordinarily low
column3: ” Matarasso said. Dimple makers
column4: on the other hand
column5: may pose greater risks of nerve damage because you’re compressing a larger surface area of the cheek
column6: he added.

column1: However
column2: Kaplan speculates that most people wouldn’t be able to tolerate the pain associated with these kinds of injuries for long enough to sustain any kind of permanent damage.

column1: As dimple makers become more popular
column2: it's far from uncommon for 26-year-old Miya Ulatowski
column3: who was born with dimples
column4: to be accused of faking hers: “When I first started seeing those comments
column5: it threw me off because I didn’t even know dimple surgery was a thing.”

column1: While Ulatowski doesn’t understand dimples’ appeal
column2: the Ohio resident said that she’s “a big supporter of people doing whatever they need to feel happy and confident in how they look.”

column1: Meanwhile
column2: people who opt for a dimpleplasty are frequently bombarded with hate about their decision to pursue the procedure. Merissa Fernandes
column4: of Massachusetts
column5: said she has received pushback online since undergoing surgery in June
column6: but acknowledges that it’s a consequence of being open about body modifications.

column1: “I’ve always adored people who had dimples
column2: so I got the surgery because I wanted to
column3: ” Fernandes said. “I’m not doing anything for the opinions of others
column4: I just think it’s valuable to be as transparent as possible.”

column1: I realize this may be asking a lot
column2: but wouldn’t it be great if so many of our politicians weren’t unscrupulous creeps?

column1: These days
column2: after scanning the headlines about the folks “running” the government
column3: I often feel like I need a shower.

column1: It seems like an almost daily occurrence that a current or former elected official lands in court for one shady misdeed or another. Government corruption almost seems normal.
It shouldn’t be.
Between the alarming attack on Israel this month and the Republicans bungling their House leadership
column2: some of the latest scandals have gotten the amount of attention they deserve.

column1: Republicans fiddle while world burns:Listen up
column2: Republicans. The world is in chaos
column3: so why are you playing stupid games?

column1: Let me refresh you on what’s been happening.
The charges keep coming for Sen. Bob Menendez
column2: a Democrat from New Jersey. A career politician to his core
column3: Menendez has spent decades in Congress
column4: between his time in the House and now the Senate.

column1: His seniority earned him the powerful position of chair of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column2: which he is now charged with abusing for his personal gain. Menendez had to step down from that role while his case plays out
column3: but he doesn’t appear to be leaving office anytime soon – at least of his own accord.

column1: Last week
column2: Menendez was slapped with additional charges of conspiracy to act as a foreign agent. That is on top of last month's indictment on bribery charges.

column1: Stop and think about that: The (now former) chair of Foreign Relations
column2: a committee that reviews treaties with other nations and votes on all diplomatic nominations
column3: is accused of acting as a foreign agent for hire.

column1: Harvard for Hamas?Something is very twisted on America's university campuses.

What he’s accused of is extremely serious. Menendez – along with his wife – is charged in part with benefiting the Egyptian government as well as several businessmen in exchange for hundreds of thousands in gold bars and cash. Some of the loot was found at his home – hidden in closets and clothes
column2: which doesn’t seem suspicious at all.

column1: And for good measure
column2: throw in a Mercedes convertible worth more than $60
column4: which prosecutors say business executives purchased for the senator and his wife in exchange for Menendez interfering in an insurance fraud case.

column1: It's not the first time Menendez has had a run-in with the law involving bribery charges. In 2017
column2: a federal jury deadlocked on whether to convict the senator
column3: which led to a mistrial.

column1: See a pattern here?
Menendez
column2: according to historians
column3: may be the first sitting senator in U.S. history to have been indicted in two different criminal cases
column4: a distinction no one should strive for.

column1: Now
column2: if you’re a liberal
column3: I can bet what you’re thinking: “Well
column4: look at former President Donald Trump!” or “How about Rep. George Santos?”

column1: Trump has been indicted in four criminal cases
column2: as well as a civil fraud case
column3: all of which are unprecedented for a former president (who also is
column4: of course
column5: the leading Republican candidate for president in 2024).

column1: Time for change:Sure
column2: Trump is awful. But that doesn't mean Biden is a good choice for president.

column1: Then there's curious George. Last week
column2: a new indictment alleges Santos stole the identities of campaign donors and used donors’ credit cards as his own personal piggy bank. That comes five months after he was charged with other financial crimes.

column1: It’s really no wonder that his campaign coffers are in arrears.
There’s also the fact that Santos made up his entire résumé. He’s a first-class sleazebag.
Yet
column2: unlike Menendez
column3: Santos is a freshman congressman
column4: one who is unlikely to make it to his sophomore term (assuming voters are paying attention).

column1: Menendez had a position of leadership and real power
column2: and Democrats kept promoting him despite earlier warning signs. What Menendez is accused of doing deserves to be scrutinized on its own accord.

column1: Bribing for access:Menendez indictment raises questions about Hunter Biden case – and DOJ
The question remains: What to do with these bad actors?
It’s easy for Democrats to scream and yell that Santos is a disgrace and must go. And Republicans like to do the same to Democrats. For instance
column2: Republicans have called for Rep. Jamaal Bowman
column3: a Democrat from New York
column4: to be expelled from the House after he pulled a fire alarm before a key vote to keep the government open. Bowman says it was a "mistake
column5: and his office released a memo in his defense that labeled Republicans as Nazis."

column1: Regardless
column2: it’s an odd “mistake” for a former school principal to make and a bizarre incident
column3: even if it doesn’t rise to the level of expulsion. But I digress.

column1: The bar for expelling a House member is high
column2: and it has only happened a few times in our country’s history. Of the 15 times the Senate has expelled a member
column3: 14 occurred during the Civil War for supporting the Confederacy.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: partisanship often comes before principle. The fact remains that with thin margins of control in the House and Senate
column3: both sides need as many warm bodies as they can get
column4: regardless of how repugnant.

column1: Some New York Republicans have called for the House to expel Santos
column2: although that’s not likely to happen. The same goes for the Senate. Quite a few Democrats have called on Menendez to resign
column3: but they’re not likely to take the matter further.

column1: At the least
column2: Menendez and Santos could be censured by their colleagues and face that embarrassment.

column1: These men deserve their day in court
column2: but I'm less certain they should be roaming the halls of Congress.

column1: The surest way to rid the government of (alleged) weasels is for voters to make sure they don’t get the chance again.
Ingrid Jacques is a columnist at USA TODAY. You can contact her at ijacques@usatoday.com or on X
column2: formerly Twitter: @Ingrid_Jacques

The USA TODAY Opinion section publishes analysis
column2: argument and essays on a wide variety of subjects. We're looking for timeliness (pegged to news)
column3: persuasion pitched to the other side
column4: new information
column5: novel arguments
column6: revelatory insights
column7: passion without partisanship
column8: first-person experience
column9: original reporting that reveals fresh angles and makes news
column11: and/or a topic that will drive conversation on social media and in the real world.

column1: We accept only pieces that are submitted exclusively to USA TODAY. We do not accept material that has been published on blogs
column2: social media or anywhere else.

column1: Columns typically run 550 to 750 words. They should be pasted directly into an email and sent to theforum@usatoday.com. Pieces should include links (URLs
column2: not headlines or footnotes) to back up quotes and factual material. People featured in columns must be identified by their real
column3: full names.

column1: We do not publish open letters
column2: class projects or material that has been submitted to multiple outlets. Rebuttals to editorials and columns published in USA TODAY should be submitted as letters to the editor
column3: not as full-length op-eds.

column1: Due to the volume of submissions
column2: we can’t respond to all columns sent to us. If our Opinion team is interested in yours
column3: you will hear from us within three business days.

column1: Submissions may be edited for accuracy
column2: clarity
column3: style
column4: standards and length.

column1: Please include with your submission a short biography
column2: two sentences at most
column3: to run at the end of your column
column4: as well as a current photograph
column5: to which you own publishing rights. If you or a business
column6: trade group or other institution with which you are associated stands to gain financially or in any other way from your column
column7: you should disclose that information in detail. In most cases
column8: it should also be included in the body of the piece or in the author's biographical information.

column1: Columns are accepted for online publication; print publication is not guaranteed. All columns published by USA TODAY are available for use online and in print by the more than 250 properties in the USA TODAY Network. They include Austin; Bergen County
column2: New Jersey; Burlington
column3: Vermont; Cincinnati; Columbus
column4: Ohio; Des Moines; Detroit; El Paso
column5: Texas; Indianapolis; Louisville
column6: Kentucky; Memphis
column7: Tennessee; Milwaukee; Nashville
column8: Tennessee; Phoenix
column9: Reno

column1: Authors may post their columns elsewhere 48 hours after they are published at USA TODAY. By submitting a column to USA TODAY and agreeing to its publication
column2: authors are granting exclusive rights to the piece to the USA TODAY Network for 48 hours and non-exclusive rights thereafter.

column1: To get a sense of our range
column2: preferences and requirements
column3: check out our op-ed section
column4: follow us on Twitter and Facebook
column5: or sign up for our daily Opinion newsletter.

column1: If you're interested in joining conversations about topics in USA TODAY
column2: email letters@usatoday.com
column3: comment on Facebook or use #tellusatoday on Twitter.

column1: Letters are edited for accuracy
column2: clarity and length and to conform to our editorial style and standards. Submissions of 200 words or fewer have the best chance of being published. Letters must include a name
column3: address and phone number.

column1: Corrections to published letters or columns follow USA TODAY guidelines.
